flashcards.definition: [kəmˈpʌŋkʃn] ## n. a feeling of guilt or regret    ##  ## Those who read the manuscript felt little compunction about sharing their reactions with others, and the word of mouth quickly became toxic.

flashcards.name: concede
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsi:d] ## v. to say that you accept or do not deny the truth or existence of    ## acknowledge ##  ## Even Narendra Modi's most bitter enemies will concede that the Indian Prime Minister rarely makes a PR misstep.

flashcards.name: conceivable
flashcards.definition: [kən'sivəbl] ## adj. imaginable or possible      ## plausible ##  ## The Russia imbroglio, the newest chapter of which involves Jeff Sessions, is perhaps the only issue on which it is conceivable that large numbers of Republicans in Congress might break with President Trump.

flashcards.name: conciliatory
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsɪliətəri] ## adj. willing to end a disagreement with someone       ## placatory ##  ## The Virginia chapter of the U.D.C. has a collection of conciliatory and even pro-Confederacy remarks made by President Theodore Roosevelt, a New Yorker, on a Web page that was updated just a few weeks ago.

flashcards.name: concoct
flashcards.definition: [kənˈkɒkt] ## (1)v. to make by mixing different things together       (2)v. to invent or develop    ##  ## She concocted this whole lie about her age in order to build a career, not meet a man.

flashcards.name: condemn
flashcards.definition: [kənˈdem] ## v. to say in a strong and definitive way that someone or something is bad or wrong    ## decry ##  ## Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn both distanced themselves from Trump’s remarks following the Charlottesville violence for their failure to unequivocally condemn hate groups.

flashcards.name: condign
flashcards.definition: [kənˈdaɪn] ## adj. deserved, appropriate     ## meet ##  ## Where in this public morass of tearing down Confederate statues will we find condign justice for Native American Indians?

flashcards.name: conducive
flashcards.definition: [kən'dusɪv] ## adj. making it easy, possible, or likely for something to happen or exist ## ...  ##  ## The ambience is conducive less to learning than to dreaming.

flashcards.name: confessional
flashcards.definition: [kənˈfeʃənl] ## adj. telling private information about a person’s life     ##  ## Elsewhere, Gay catalogues her daily stresses as a fat woman, recalling the blunt, confessional voice she has assumed on her blogs since her early Tumblr days.

flashcards.name: confine
flashcards.definition: [kənˈfaɪn] ## v. to keep within limits    ## limit, circumscribe ##  ## Although Vitalie’s social life was confined to the church, shopping, and occasional games of whist, she somehow managed to meet a French army officer in 1852.

flashcards.name: conform to
flashcards.definition: [kənˈfɔ:m] ## (1)v. to obey or agree with something     (2)v. to be in agreement or harmony  ...   ## square with ##  ## Wotan’s defense of rebellious love in the face of cold morality resonated with listeners who had to suppress their natural urges and conform to norms, often by way of sham marriages.

flashcards.name: confound
flashcards.definition: [kənˈfaʊnd] ## (1)v. to surprise and confuse      (2)v. to prove wrong   ...   ## perplex, flummox ## 18 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## It is also a sort of mocking reversal of the “innocents abroad” motif of such Henry James novels as “Daisy Miller” and “The Portrait of a Lady,” in which fresh-faced, straightforward Yanks are confounded by the perilous subtleties of Europeans.

flashcards.name: confront
flashcards.definition: [kən'frʌnt] ## v. to oppose or challenge especially in a direct and forceful way  ...    ##  ## As Cohn and others in the White House steadily watered down Trump’s aggressive campaign rhetoric on trade, Bannon tried to fight back, particularly on the need to confront Chinese mercantilism.

flashcards.name: confused
flashcards.definition: [kənˈfju:zd] ## adj. unable to understand or think clearly     ## muddled ##  ## Like many young people who are insecure and confused, they had an inchoate sense that they were guilty of something; they just needed to be told what it was.

flashcards.name: conjecture
flashcards.definition: [kənˈdʒektʃə] ## n. an opinion or idea formed without proof or sufficient evidence    ## speculation ##  ## In “Loving”, probably his greatest novel, Green confined himself to a mixture of deduction and conjecture—“probably,” “you could safely say”—which worked in league not only with the characters’ chatter but also with the fevered notation of surfaces.

flashcards.name: consensus
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsensəs] ## n. a general agreement about something      ## accord ##  ## Both have dropped since 2011, which the President sees as evidence not of a bipartisan consensus on the need for sentencing reform but as proof of the laxity and the bad faith of members of the Obama Administration, who, he said, had “looked at this scourge, and they let it go by.”

flashcards.name: considerable
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsɪdərəbl] ## adj. large in extent or degree      ##  ## His “toughness” came at considerable cost to the taxpayers, who have had to pay for the tens of millions of dollars it has cost the county to respond to lawsuits against the former sheriff.

flashcards.name: consistent
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsɪstənt] ## adj. continuing to happen or develop in the same way       ##  ## There are three different takes from three different sets on August 17th and 18th, but the piano part is consistent.

flashcards.name: conspicuous
flashcards.definition: [kənˈspɪkjuəs] ## adj. very easy to see or notice     ## obtrusive, prominent, salient, remarkable ##  ## Though it seems churlish to pick away at a movie that offers so many and such conspicuous delights, it’s something of a frustration that it doesn’t push toward hidden mysteries.

flashcards.name: constitute
flashcards.definition: [ˈkɒnstɪtju:t] ## v. to make up or form something    ##  ## There have been at least thirty attacks carried out by white terrorists since 9/11; the victims of those attacks constitute the majority of people killed on American soil in acts of terrorism.

flashcards.name: constrain
flashcards.definition: [kənˈstreɪn] ## (1)v. to limit or restrict     ## (2)v. to use pressure to force to do something    ## deter ##  ## Speaking to a group of reporters recently, Mattis said that he remained critical of the nuclear deal, mainly because it did not constrain Iran’s aggressive activities in the region, but that he considered it binding.

flashcards.name: construe
flashcards.definition: [kən'stru] ## v. to understand in a particular way       ## interpret ##  ## “The Internationalists” has some lessons for today. One is a warning against the temptation nations have to construe threats of war as equivalent to acts of war.

flashcards.name: consummate
flashcards.definition: ['kɑnsəmət] ## adj. complete in every detail     ##  ## The comic actor who directs himself with a consummate mastery of technique—there’s a noble tradition at work, and when Lewis planned to direct he had that tradition, with Charlie Chaplin at the head of it, in mind.

flashcards.name: consumption
flashcards.definition: [kənˈsʌmpʃn] ## (1)n. the use of something     ## (2)n. the utilization of economic goods in the satisfaction of wants or in the process of production resulting chiefly in their destruction, deterioration, or transformation    ##  ## The most dramatic global increase in aggregate consumption is occurring in parts of the world where people who build roads are trying to keep pace with people who buy cars.

flashcards.name: contagious
flashcards.definition: [kənˈteɪdʒəs] ## (1)adj. having a sickness that can be passed to someone else by touching        ## (2)adj. capable of being easily spread to others       ##  ## Offering a nuts-and-bolts exploration of the English language, Stamper displays a contagious enthusiasm for words and a considerable talent for putting them together.

flashcards.name: contemplate
flashcards.definition: [ˈkɒntəmpleɪt] ## v. to think deeply or carefully about      ## ponder ## 19 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Very few people in Greene County want to contemplate a future without coal; most, like the Zaccones, hope that deregulation can preserve their way of life.

flashcards.name: contemptuous
flashcards.definition: [kən'tɛmptʃuəs] ## adj. feeling or showing deep hatred or disapproval     ## disdainful ##  ## Minchin was the perfect match for “Matilda the Musical,” since he shares Roald Dahl’s flair for contemptuous whimsy.

flashcards.name: contented
flashcards.definition: [kənˈtentɪd] ## adj. happy and satisfied     ##  ## In the morning, the pig’s mother sees the young bride “lying in the bed, muddy as it was, looking entirely pleased and contented.

flashcards.name: contentious
flashcards.definition: [kənˈtenʃəs] ## (1)adj. likely to cause people to argue or disagree        (2)adj. likely or willing to argue      ## controversial ##  ## Yet early Republican support for the Dream Act faded as immigration policy grew increasingly contentious during the Bush Administration.

flashcards.name: contingent
flashcards.definition: [kənˈtɪndʒənt] ## adj. depending on something else that might or might not happen      ## circumstantial ##  ## Diplo earned twenty-three million dollars in 2016, per a Forbes report, which makes him an easy target for laughs, especially because much of what he creates, artfully or not, is contingent upon the contributions and the ingenuity of others.

flashcards.name: contract
flashcards.definition: [ˈkɒntrækt] ## (1)v. to become smaller     ## (2)n. a legal agreement between people, companies, etc.     (3)v. to become affected with    ## dwindle ##  ## We still don’t know why some people contract the microbe with little or no illness, at most mild fever and muscle aches, while others suffer Guillain-Barré syndrome, a life-threatening paralysis.

flashcards.name: contradictory
flashcards.definition: [ˌkɒntrəˈdɪktəri] ## adj. involving or having information that disagrees with other information ##  ## dichotomous ##  ## Throughout his career, Trump has deliberately stirred conflict among his underlings, chafed at efforts to rein him in, and reserved the right to act in arbitrary and contradictory ways.

flashcards.name: contravene
flashcards.definition: [ˌkɒntrəˈvi:n] ## v. to fail to do what is required by    ## violate ##  ## So far, Republicans have been able to hide behind Trump, hoping that no one will notice how much his manufacturing deals contravene their small-government principles.

flashcards.name: controversial
flashcards.definition: [ˌkɒntrəˈvɜ:ʃl] ## adj. relating to or causing much discussion, disagreement, or argument ##  ## contentious ##  ## Their main obstacle was the F.C.C.’s Fairness Doctrine, which sought to protect public discourse by requiring controversial opinions to be balanced by opposing viewpoints.

flashcards.name: conundrum
flashcards.definition: [kəˈnʌndrəm] ## n. a confusing or difficult problem         ## riddle, puzzle, enigma ##  ## During Mitt Romney’s campaign for President, in 2012, he claimed that he could solve the political conundrum of immigration reform by getting undocumented immigrants to “self-deport” from the United States en masse.

flashcards.name: convoluted
flashcards.definition: [ˈkɒnvəlu:tɪd] ## adj. very complicated and difficult to understand       ## intricate, tortuous ##  ## According to The New Yorker, the corporate structures of his various enterprises are so convoluted that it is difficult to assess the true extent of his holdings.

flashcards.name: convulsion
flashcards.definition: [kənˈvʌlʃn] ## n. a sudden change or disturbance that affects a country, organization, etc.    ## upheaval ##  ## Residents of local villages who ate fish and shellfish from the bay suffered convulsions, psychosis, loss of consciousness and coma.

flashcards.name: cooperate
flashcards.definition: [kəʊ'ɒpəreɪt] ## v. to associate with another or others for mutual benefit    ##  ## The law would have not only outlawed sanctuary cities but also would penalize local officials who refused to cooperate with deportation officials.

flashcards.name: corroborate
flashcards.definition: [kə'rɑbəret] ## v. to support with evidence or authority    ##  ## According to the newspaper Welt am Sonntag, the German Embassy in Niger sent a cable to Berlin corroborating these weekly executions, and comparing the conditions in Libya’s migrant connection houses to those of Nazi concentration camps.

flashcards.name: corrupt
flashcards.definition: [kəˈrʌpt] ## (1)v. to cause to become dishonest, immoral, etc.  ...    ## (2)adj. doing things that are dishonest or illegal in order to make money or to gain or keep power     ## 20 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Spiro Agnew, elected in 1968 as Richard Nixon’s Vice-President, was under investigation for tax evasion, bribery, and various corrupt practices, most dating back to 1967, when Agnew became the governor of Maryland.

flashcards.name: counterforce
flashcards.definition: ['kaʊntəˌfɔ:s] ## n. a contrary or opposing force      ##  ## One of ligo’s systems responds to minuscule seismic tremors by activating a damping system that pushes on the mirrors with exactly the right counterforce to keep them steady.

flashcards.name: counterintuitive
flashcards.definition: [,kaʊntərɪn'tjuːɪtɪv] ## adj. not agreeing with what seems right or natural       ## unexpected ##  ## A literary critic who relished parsing the complex, the nuanced, and the counterintuitive, he would have rejected the idea of being reduced to a symbol.

flashcards.name: counterpart
flashcards.definition: [ˈkaʊntəpɑ:t] ## n. someone or something that has the same job or purpose as another ##  ## parallel ##  ## Tadej Rupel, the Ambassador of the Republic of Slovenia to the Court of St. James’s, had concocted the idea with his Slovakian counterpart.

flashcards.name: counterproductive
flashcards.definition: [,kaʊntɚprə'dʌktɪv] ## adj. tending to hinder the attainment of a desired goal       ## deleterious ##  ## All these initiatives are unwise, unjust, and counterproductive, but they nevertheless represent the kind of change that tends to occur when an Administration of one political party takes over from the other.

flashcards.name: courteous
flashcards.definition: ['kɜːtjəs] ## adj. very polite in a way that shows respect      ##  ## He appeared courteous in an old-fashioned way, yet still vaguely mischievous, as if he might call you ma’am but would wink at you as you left the room.

flashcards.name: covert
flashcards.definition: [ˈkʌvət] ## adj. made, shown, or done in a way that is not easily seen or notices      ## clandestine ##  ## Putin was not interested in keeping the operation covert, Albats said. “He wanted to make it as public as possible.

flashcards.name: covet
flashcards.definition: ['kʌvɪt] ## v. to want very much    ## envy ##  ## Standing out on the streets of New York has always been a combination of avant-garde theatre and non-contact sport—and hip- hop in the eighties hinted at how one could covet designer goods with a playful, self-touting irreverence.

flashcards.name: crab
flashcards.definition: [kræb] ## v. to complain about peevishly    ## excoriate ##  ## With all the non-stop all-night crying, will the neighbors crab, or will they be carted away under cover of darkness, never to be heard from again?

flashcards.name: craft
flashcards.definition: [krɑːft] ## n. skill in planning, making, or executing       ##  ## The baristas are cross-trained as mixologists, and the creative synergy between craft coffee and craft cocktails rises to the level of art.

flashcards.name: crass
flashcards.definition: [kræs] ## adj. having or showing no understanding of what is proper or acceptable     ##  ## On Thursday, people from across the political spectrum were unified in their condemnation of his incredibly crass and sexist attack on Mika Brzezinski, the co-host of MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.”

flashcards.name: credit
flashcards.definition: [ˈkredɪt] ## (1)n. a record of how well you have paid your bills in the past     (2)v. to give honor or recognition to for doing something or for making something happen    ##  ## The New Oxford Shakespeare, for which Taylor serves as lead general editor, is the first edition of the plays to credit Christopher Marlowe as a co-author of Shakespeare’s “Henry VI,” Parts 1, 2, and 3.

flashcards.name: credulous
flashcards.definition: [ˈkredjələs] ## adj. too ready to believe things     ## trusting ##  ## Batchelor tap-dances perilously close to the often repeated absurdity that a highly credulous belief about supernatural claims and an extremely skeptical belief about supernatural claims are really the same because they are both beliefs.

flashcards.name: crestfallen
flashcards.definition: ['krestfɔːlən] ## adj. very sad and disappointed      ## disgruntled ##  ## One day, the woman appeared in the bar looking crestfallen.

flashcards.name: crumble
flashcards.definition: ['krʌmbl] ## v. to break into small pieces       ## disintegrate ##  ## There were the hiking boots I've had since high school, so battered that one Sunday, near the Delaware Water Gap, the rubber sole started to crumble off in chunks.

flashcards.name: cryptic
flashcards.definition: [ˈkrɪptɪk] ## adj. difficult to understand     ## elusive ## 21 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## In a file in Hahn’s papers at the Lilly Library, in Bloomington, Indiana, I’d found a square of white silk, covered from edge to edge with typewritten names, cryptic messages, and several lines of Japanese poetry.

flashcards.name: cumbersome
flashcards.definition: [ˈkʌmbəsəm] ## (1)adj. hard to handle or manage because of size or weight      (2)adj. complicated and hard to do       ## unwieldy ##  ## Unlike some of the F.C.C.’s other initiatives, which critics oppose as being too expensive and cumbersome, video description is relatively cheap to implement.

flashcards.name: cunning
flashcards.definition: ['kʌnɪŋ] ## adj. getting what is wanted in a clever and often deceptive way     ## crafty ##  ## Moral: beware the devious, the slippery, the cunning Canadian.

flashcards.name: cure-all
flashcards.definition: [kjʊəɔ:l] ## n. a cure or solution for any illness or problem     ## panacea ##  ## Clearly, using technology to promote transparency and influence police behavior isn’t a cure-all for the problems of police brutality, overaggressive policing, and institutional racism, but it is a step in the right direction.

flashcards.name: cursory
flashcards.definition: [ˈkɜ:səri] ## adj. done or made quickly     ## perfunctory, casual ##  ## I read everything—thrillers, history, romance, classics—some in a cursory way, with passages skipped.

flashcards.name: curt
flashcards.definition: [kɜ:t] ## (1)adj. sparing of words      ## (2)adj. marked by rude or peremptory shortness       ## laconic, terse, taciturn ##  ## In answer, she offered a curt, dismissive, almost dainty dab, forehead to elbow-crook, and, in her own pointed time, obliged.

flashcards.name: curtail
flashcards.definition: [kɜː'teɪl] ## v. to reduce or limit    ## mitigate ##  ## The move will also likely curtail the numbers of Americans travelling to the island as well, by obliging them to provide proof that they are following the new rules.

flashcards.name: damp
flashcards.definition: [dæmp] ## v. to make less strong or active     ## palliate ##  ## When Song’s father died unexpectedly, in 2002, thrift gave way to hoarding, as if stuff could damp grief.

flashcards.name: darken
flashcards.definition: [ˈdɑ:kən] ## (1)v. to make dark or to become dark or darker in color      (2)v. to make less happy or to become less happy     ## dim ##  ## Soon enough, the skies darken and the rain comes down in sheets.

flashcards.name: dated
flashcards.definition: [ˈdeɪtɪd] ## adj. coming from or belonging to a time in the past     ##  ## Like many forward-thinking dispatches offered during the first dot-com bubble, “Hamlet on the Holodeck” can feel dated at times, superseded by a future that is, broadly speaking, darker and stranger than the one Murray anticipated.

flashcards.name: daunting
flashcards.definition: [dɔ:ntɪŋ] ## adj. tending to make people afraid or less confident       ## formidable, sensational, forbidding ##  ## The numbers are absolutely daunting — 52,000 overdose deaths in 2015; 33,000 of those approximately related to opioids. The numbers in 2016 are no better, and the numbers in 2017 are even worse than 2016.

flashcards.name: dearth
flashcards.definition: [dɜ:θ] ## n. the state or condition of not having enough of something    ## paucity, modicum ##  ## Ironically, the sharp drop in infections will make it difficult to demonstrate the efficacy of a candidate vaccine in field testing, since there is likely to be a relative dearth of new cases.

flashcards.name: debacle
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈbɑkəl] ## n. a great disaster or complete failure      ## fiasco ##  ## At heart, the debacle resulted from a collision of the ready-fire-aim approach of the tech industry and the “T”-crossing, “I”-dotting ethos that underlies securities regulation (even if it’s an ethos that’s often ignored).

flashcards.name: debase
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'beɪs] ## v. to lower the value or reputation of    ##  ## The President debased reporters, while relying on them to air it on TV—the media equivalent of the why-are-you-hitting-yourself bullying tactic.

flashcards.name: debunk
flashcards.definition: [ˌdi:ˈbʌŋk] ## v. to show that something is not true   ...   ##  ## That was when CNN broadcast a devastating series about the company, in which scientists and physicians debunked Herbalife’s claims for its products and challenged the company’s assertion that it employed medical experts and ran a research lab.

flashcards.name: decay
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈkeɪ] ## n. the process or result of being slowly destroyed by natural precesses ##  ## deterioration ## 22 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Everyone knew that the country was mired in poverty and decay and stagnation and degradation, drowning in lies and cynicism and all-out drunkenness.

flashcards.name: decisive
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈsaɪsɪv] ## (1)adj. resolute, determined      ## (2)adj. unmistakable, unquestionable       ## unmistakable ##  ## When there were limits on how much a single donor could give, however, it was much harder for an individual to have a decisive impact.

flashcards.name: decline
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈklaɪn] ## (1)v. to become worse in condition or quality     ## (2)v. to say that you will not or cannot do something    ## wane ##  ## Though Gibson had posted a Facebook video condemning Christian and acknowledging that his gatherings had attracted “legitimate Nazis,” he had declined to cancel the Sunday rally.

flashcards.name: decouple
flashcards.definition: [di:ˈkʌpl] ## v. to eliminate the interrelationship of  ...     ##  ## These efforts might serve to buy some time while the economists and diplomats in the Administration could find a palatable way to decouple the dollar from gold.

flashcards.name: decrepitude
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈkrepɪtju:d] ## n. the state of being old and in bad condition or poor health       ## senescence ##  ## But revulsion at the cronyism and the decrepitude of major-party politics can’t be what’s driving Jeb Bush and Mitt Romney, two eminent members of the establishment.

flashcards.name: decry
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈkraɪ] ## v. to say publicly and forcefully that you regard as bad, wrong, etc.       ## condemn ##  ## Even as a kid, Miller liked to fulminate against immigration and decry the ambient leftism of coastal California.

flashcards.name: defame
flashcards.definition: [di'feim] ## v. to hurt the reputation of especially by saying things that are false or unfair    ##  ## The Administration chose to defame me and, more importantly, the F.B.I. by saying the organization was in disarray, that it was being poorly led, that the workforce had lost faith in its leader.

flashcards.name: defect
flashcards.definition: ['diːfekt] ## n. an imperfection that impairs worth or utility    ##  ## A birth defect has left a lizard named Shyvana without a tail.

flashcards.name: defend
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈfend] ## (1)v. to drive danger or attack away from    ## (2)v. to maintain or support in the face of argument or hostile criticism  ...   ## champion ##  ## There’s a difference between speaking truth to power and seizing power to defend the truth.

flashcards.name: deferential
flashcards.definition: [ˌdefə'renʃl] ## adj. showing or expressing deference     ## respectful ##  ## Since the election, some journalists at the Wall Street Journal have expressed frustration with what they say is overly cautious and deferential reporting on Trump, at a time when competitors are aggressively scrutinizing the president.

flashcards.name: defiant
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'faɪənt] ## adj. refusing to obey something or someone         ##  ## In a climate of resurgent anti-Semitism, homophobia, and hostility to immigrants, the success of “Indecent” feels defiant, if not triumphant.

flashcards.name: defining
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'faɪnɪŋ] ## adj.         ##  ## When it was reported, last week, that Kyrie Irving, the Cleveland Cavaliers’ star point guard, wanted to be traded, many basketball fans thought back to the defining moment of his young and superlative career: his game-winning three-pointer in the 2016 N.B.A.

flashcards.name: definite
flashcards.definition: [ˈdefɪnət] ## (1)adj. said or done in such a way that others know exactly what you mean      ## (2)adj. not likely to change       ##  ## Charyn doesn’t try to provide a definite answer to the crucial question of why Kosinski passed off his most famous book as something it was not, but this last section goes some way toward suggesting why he felt the need to conceal himself behind a mask.

flashcards.name: deflate
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈfleɪt] ## v. to reduce or cause to contract     ## soothe ##  ## Jeff Zucker has gotten telephone calls of bitter complaint from Jared Kushner about the coverage of his father-in-law, but if the performance of Jake Tapper and others there is any indication, the attempt to intimidate CNN has not deflated any spirits.

flashcards.name: deflect
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'flekt] ## v. to cause to change direction     ## shrug off ## 23 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## I don’t want my attention deflected every two minutes.

flashcards.name: deft
flashcards.definition: [deft] ## adj. skillful and clever     ## canny ##  ## Dwayne Johnson does deft work in “Central Intelligence,” also starring Kevin Hart, but the film’s treatment of violence blunts its comedic energy.

flashcards.name: defy
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈfaɪ] ## v. to confront with assured power of resistance    ## disregard, flout ##  ## Despite all of the disadvantages Sanders faces, his supporters and allies are still hopeful that he can defy the polls and score an upset, as he did in Michigan.

flashcards.name: degenerative
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈdʒenərətɪv] ## adj. causing the body or part of the body to become weaker or less able to function as time passes     ##  ## Addiction is indeed a brain problem, but it’s not a degenerative pathology like Alzheimer’s disease or cancer, nor is it evidence of a criminal mind.

flashcards.name: degrade
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'ɡred] ## (1)v. to lower in grade, rank, or status     (2)v. to make the quality of worse     (3)v. to wear down by erosion    ##  ## It would feature artists whom Gouzer admired but whose work had not been doing well at auction; or artists who drew on failure as a theme; or works that were prone to degrade, because they contained nontraditional materials.

flashcards.name: deify
flashcards.definition: [ˈdeɪɪfaɪ] ## v. to treat like a god or goddess    ##  ## Any egoist can build a monument to himself, but it is an extraordinary accomplishment to deify oneself—or, at least, the personification of one’s better nature—and have it move as many grown men to tears as the “Rocky” films have.

flashcards.name: delegate
flashcards.definition: [ˈdelɪgət] ## v. to give (control, responsibility, authority, etc.) to someone    ##  ## For one thing, “defendants have cited no authority for the proposition that Congress can delegate to the president the power to violate the Constitution and its amendments.

flashcards.name: deleterious
flashcards.definition: ['dɛlə'tɪrɪəs] ## adj. damaging or harmful         ## counterproductive, detrimental, devastating ##  ## Our experiment was very rude and uncontrollable, and there will be other deleterious effects, as well as many unknowns.

flashcards.name: deliberate
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈlɪbərət] ## (1)v. to think about or discuss something very carefully in order to make a decision       ## (2)adj. done or said in a way that is planned or intended     ## (3)adj. done or decided after careful thought     ## calculated ##  ## Taplin draws extensively on this experience to illustrate the damage, both deliberate and collateral, that Big Tech is wreaking.

flashcards.name: delight
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈlaɪt] ## (1)n. a strong feeling of happiness    (2)v. to make very happy     ## relish ##  ## Shkreli himself seemed to delight in the idea of being the catalyst for one of the biggest insider-trading cases in U.S. history.

flashcards.name: demanding
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈmɑ:ndɪŋ] ## adj. requiring much time, effort, or attention     ## exacting ##  ## In each case, what the word described was a kind of outsize zealotry — a person who was too stern, too demanding, like an order-barking villain in a World War II movie.

flashcards.name: demarcation
flashcards.definition: [ˌdi:mɑ:ˈkeɪʃn] ## n. the establishment of boundaries or limits separating two areas, groups, or things    ##  ## For some years, I’m now prepared to admit, I somehow labored under the impression that Rocky Mount is the line of demarcation that separates the two principal schools of North Carolina barbecue.

flashcards.name: demise
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈmaɪz] ## n. the end of something that is thought of as being like a death        ##  ## Additionally, Taystee (Danielle Brooks) and Soso (Kimiko Glenn) may continue to mourn the shocking death of Poussey (Samira Wiley) since they staged the riot three days after her demise.

flashcards.name: demur
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈmɜ:] ## v. to disagree politely with another person’s statement or suggestion       ##  ## Yet Trump refused, just as he demurs when theres cause to criticize Vladimir Putin. ## 24 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: denounce
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈnaʊns] ## v. to publicly state that someone or something is bad or wrong    ## lambast ##  ## Attorney General Jeff Sessions also denounced the Charlottesville attack as an 'evil' act of domestic terrorism.

flashcards.name: deplete
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈpli:t] ## v. to empty of a principal substance    ##  ## The company is planning to resume excavation near that area, though, as other sources become depleted.

flashcards.name: deplorable
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'plɔrəbl] ## (1)adj. lamentable      ## (2)adj. deserving censure or contempt       ## reprehensible ##  ## An artist’s conduct alone, no matter how deplorable, doesn’t prevent him from making art that has significant merits.

flashcards.name: deprecatory
flashcards.definition: [ˌdeprə'keɪtərɪ] ## adj. disapproving     ## detracting ##  ## Originally from outside New England, she had taken to Concord’s self-deprecatory, old-station-wagon ways with the joy of a convert.

flashcards.name: depressing
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈpresɪŋ] ## adj. causing someone to feel sad or without hope       ##  ## To go from “Detroit” to “Whose Streets?,” a documentary about the disturbances that began in Ferguson, Missouri, three years ago, is both uncanny and deeply depressing.

flashcards.name: derision
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈrɪʒn] ## n. the feeling that people express when they criticize and laugh at someone or something in an insulting way    ## mockery ##  ## By the mid-nineties, he not only became the object of critical derision but was cited as evidence of an American culture in crisis and decline.

flashcards.name: derivative
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈrɪvətɪv] ## adj. not new or original      ##  ## There's nothing derivative about Dash's work; every image, every moment is a full creation.

flashcards.name: derive from
flashcards.definition: [diˈraiv] [frɔm] ## phrase. to take, receive, or obtain especially from a specific source    ##  ## The substantial revenues that governments derive from taxing motoring, drivers and transport in all their diverse ways will need to be reformed.

flashcards.name: design
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈzaɪn] ## (1)n. deliberate purposive planning     ## (2)n. the process of planning how something will look, happen, be made    ## purposefulness ##  ## We can make the decision to be different by design, and try some unconventional tactics to stand out from the herd.

flashcards.name: despair
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈspeə] ## v. to no longer have any hope or belief that a situation will improve or change    ##  ## He works construction in London (there are so few opportunities in Leenane), and even in his despair there is something like hope.

flashcards.name: destructive
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'strʌktɪv] ## adj. causing a very large amount of damage     ##  ## The concerns about the corporate culture are genuine, and potentially destructive to the company’s brand.

flashcards.name: detached
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'tætʃt] ## adj. not influenced by emotions or personal interest       ##  ## As a result, his detached observations are rather at odds with the spirit of Buddhist teachings, which regard direct experience rather than discursive thought as the primary basis of understanding.

flashcards.name: detect
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈtekt] ## v. to discover or notice the presence of    ## discern ##  ## He believes that the situation is more serious than it seems, since the parasite is difficult to detect and is not widely known among doctors.

flashcards.name: deter
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈtɜ:] ## (1)v. to prevent from happening     ## (2)v. to cause to decide not to do something    ## constrain ##  ## Through adamant protests and influence wielding, outspoken Greenwich natives were able to deter the UN from settling on their land.

flashcards.name: deterioration
flashcards.definition: [dɪˌtɪərɪə'reɪʃn] ## n. the act or process of becoming worse    ## decay, decline ##  ## The outbreak poses a significant threat given the drastic deterioration of the health care infrastructure after three years of civil war between forces loyal to President Abdrabbuh Mansour Hadi’s government.

flashcards.name: detestation
flashcards.definition: [ˌdi:te'steɪʃn] ## n. extreme hatred or dislike    ## 25 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## While 49 percent of registered voters “strongly dislike” Trump, 47 percent feel the same way about Clinton — in other words, a statistical dead heat of detestation.

flashcards.name: detract
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈtrækt] ## (1)v. to speak ill of    (2)v. to take away    ## deprecate ##  ## But that lapse in judgment on Romney’s part doesn’t detract from the power of his statement on Friday, or from the reality that Trump’s Presidency is in crisis, his very legitimacy in question.

flashcards.name: detrimental
flashcards.definition: [,detrɪ'mentl] ## adj. causing damage or injury     ## deleterious ##  ## There was, to begin with, no real attempt to explain why he had found, as the statute requires, that admitting these people would be detrimental to the United States.

flashcards.name: devious
flashcards.definition: [ˈdi:viəs] ## (1)adj. willing to lie and trick people in order to get what is wanted       ## (2)adj. not straight or direct     ## guile, indirect ##  ## Throughout Greek literature, Odysseus is a notorious trickster, given to devious twists and evasions.

flashcards.name: devolve
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'vɒlv] ## (1)v. to pass on from one person or entity to another             ## (2)v. to gradually go from an advanced state to a less advanced state     ##  ## A conventional conflict could then devolve into the now familiar kind of insurgency that U.S. forces face in the Middle East and South Asia.

flashcards.name: dexterous
flashcards.definition: [ˈdekstrəs] ## adj. having or showing great skills or cleverness     ## nimble ##  ## Despite his self-confessed deficiencies, or possibly because of them, Polk proves to be a nervy, dexterous trader and a shrewd corporate operator.

flashcards.name: diatribe
flashcards.definition: [ˈdaɪətraɪb] ## n. an angry and usually long speech or piece of writing that strongly criticizes someone or something    ## rant ##  ## Before “Fresh off the Boat” premièred on TV, in 2015, Huang wrote a striking diatribe in New York magazine, accusing the sitcom’s producers of whitewashing his memoir in order to pander to mainstream audiences.

flashcards.name: dichotomous
flashcards.definition: [daɪ'kɒtəməs] ## (1)adj. dividing into two parts      ## (2)adj. relating to, involving, or proceeding from dichotomy     ## contradictory ##  ## As Canada’s industrial center has shifted west and multiculturalism has thrown dichotomous equations of nationhood for a loop, the drama of Quebec separatism has abated.

flashcards.name: didactic
flashcards.definition: [daɪˈdæktɪk] ## adj. designed or intended to teach people something     ## preachy ##  ## Even “Pamela,” prudish and didactic as it is, feels far less limited or quaint than we might expect.

flashcards.name: diffident
flashcards.definition: [ˈdɪfɪdənt] ## (1)adj. lacking confidence        ## (2)adj. very careful about acting or speaking       ##  ## On the campaign trail, though, he was diffident and underpowered—except when the subject was Khan.

flashcards.name: diffuse
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈfju:s] ## (1)adj. spread out over a large space      ## (2)adj. to spread out     ## (3)adj. being at once verbose and ill-organized     ## spread, disperse, wordy ##  ## The full scope of the strike is difficult to know, given its diffuse nature.

flashcards.name: dilatory
flashcards.definition: [ˈdɪlətəri] ## adj. characterized by procrastination     ## sluggish, remiss, laggard ##  ## In fact, a new term was coined “High Broderism” which meant a long and dilatory paragraph that, once analyzed, said either very little or nothing, a gaseous obfuscation that had one objective: to defend the status quo.

flashcards.name: dilemma
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'lemə] ## n. a situation in which you have to make a difficult choice    ##  ## The governor might conceivably find a genuine resolution to the budgetary dilemma, but she may be tempted to engage in a deception: a specious exercise in fiscal prudence.

flashcards.name: diligent
flashcards.definition: [ˈdɪlɪdʒənt] ## adj. characterized by steady, earnest, and energetic effort     ## industrious ## 26 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Mary Garth, the quiet, diligent young woman whom many readers have seen as the alternative heroine of Eliot’s story, has been turned into Max Garth, a gay townie who resembles Mary in his humility and intelligence, if not in his appearance.

flashcards.name: dim
flashcards.definition: [dɪm] ## (1)adj. not bright or clear      ## (2)v. to make less bright or to become less bright     ## darken ##  ## The President has a dim view of extending visas to employees in the technology industry. But, when it comes to his club, it’s a different story.

flashcards.name: diminish
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈmɪnɪʃ] ## (1)v. to make less or cause to appear less     (2)v. to lessen the authority or reputation of    ##  ## The imperative is to find ways to counteract and diminish his malignant influence not only in the overtly political realm but also in the social and cultural one.

flashcards.name: diminutive
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈmɪnjətɪv] ## adj. very small     ## minuscule ##  ## Over the course of this immense time span, our species evolved from diminutive, small-brained bipeds eating fruit, digging for tubers, and catching the occasional lizard to what we are now: animals, as Friedrich Nietzsche put it, who can make promises.

flashcards.name: discard
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈkɑ:d] ## v. to throw away because it is useless or unwanted    ##  ## Baranova strongly encourages the men to discard their old phones and use only sim cards and handsets issued to them in Moscow.

flashcards.name: discern
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈsɜ:n] ## (1)v. to detect with the eyes     ## (2)v. to recognize or identify as separate and distinct    ## detect, discover ##  ## Trump’s statements on Chicago’s violence have been ambiguous, leaving observers to discern his intent, or, as Kellyanne Conway has suggested, to discern what is in his heart.

flashcards.name: disciple
flashcards.definition: [dɪ'saɪpl] ## n. a convinced adherent of a school or individual    ## adherent ##  ## Restless, he hitchhiked around the world and wound up in India, where he became a disciple of Neem Karoli Baba.

flashcards.name: discomfit
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'kʌmfɪt] ## v. to make confused or upset     ##  ## Like his name, the track is an enthusiastic but discomfiting homage that raises questions about appropriation and sincerity.

flashcards.name: discordance
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'kɔ:dəns] ## n. the state or an instance of disagreement     ## contention ##  ## He told me that he enters a meditative state behind the lens: waiting for the flickering moments of alignment that occur when a view of the landscape shifts from discordance into order.

flashcards.name: discredit
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'kredɪt] ## v. to damage the reputation of       ##  ## He encountered opposition and obstacles to his research every step of the way, and gradually became convinced that Syngenta was carrying out an orchestrated campaign to unsettle and discredit him.

flashcards.name: discrepancy
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'krɛpənsi] ## n. a difference especially between things that should be the same    ## incongruity ##  ## A recent episode of the sitcom dramatized a similar discrepancy with a plot line in which Evan applies for a bank account and must decide whether to sign his Chinese name or his English name on the official document.

flashcards.name: discretionary
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈskreʃənəri] ## adj. done or used when necessary       ##  ## It proposes eliminating all federal discretionary funding—the entirety—of 7 of the 12 federal programs that coordinate investments and other forms of assistance to support coal communities.

flashcards.name: discursion
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'kɜ:ʃən] ## n. the state of talking or writing about many different things in a way that is not highly organized      ##  ## They move easily between travelogue and historical analogy, personal experience and philosophical meditation, discursion and sharp statement.

flashcards.name: disdain
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈdeɪn] ## n. a feeling of contempt for someone or something regarded as unworthy or inferior    ## opprobrium, contempt ##  ## While blunt about his disdain for immigrants in general, and Mexican immigrants in particular, he was less consistent regarding children born in America to undocumented parents.

flashcards.name: disenchant
flashcards.definition: [,dɪsɪn'tʃænt] ## v. to free from illusion       ##  ## Rice’s production walks a tightrope between nostalgia and doubt, at once yearning for enchantment and seeking to disenchant.

flashcards.name: disgorge
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈgɔ:dʒ] ## v. to let out or release    ## dump ## 27 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## A few blocks from downtown, the beautiful historic train station, which disgorged thousands of tourists a week during peak hiking season, has shut.

flashcards.name: disgruntle
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'ɡrʌntl] ## v. to make ill-humored or discontented      ## crestfallen ##  ## In this episode of The Cartoon Lounge, with the help of the cartoonist Avi Steinberg, we read the sweetest complaint ever, from a disgruntled six-year-old girl who wants to know why kids can’t enter the caption contest.

flashcards.name: disinclination
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɪsˌɪnklɪˈneɪʃn] ## n. a feeling of not wanting to do something     ##  ## The author’s disinclination toward the private and the psychological leaves a reader of “Bush” wondering exactly when and how an “unnerving level of certitude” took hold of the title figure.

flashcards.name: disingenuous
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɪsɪnˈdʒenjuəs] ## adj. not truly honest or sincere      ##  ## Writing about characters having sex isn't very different from writing about characters doing anything else, but it would be disingenuous to act like I don't know that it can be received differently by readers.

flashcards.name: disintegrate
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'ɪntɪɡret] ## v. to break apart into many small parts or pieces    ## crumble ##  ## In 2016, my already strained relationship with my smartphone threatened to disintegrate completely.

flashcards.name: disinterested
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈɪntrəstɪd] ## (1)adj. not influenced by personal feelings, opinions, or concerns      (2)adj. not interested       ## fair, impartial ##  ## A statesman, the argument went, ought to have a disinterested view of the long-term welfare of the state, not a narrow factional wish for short-term power-grabbing on behalf of his friends and financiers.

flashcards.name: dismantle
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'mæntl] ## v. to take apart so that it is in separate pieces    ##  ## We have no intention to form a small group that would dismantle stability.

flashcards.name: dismiss
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈmɪs] ## (1)v. to decide not to think about or consider      (2)v. to permit or cause to leave     ## (3)v. to remove from position or service     ## (4)v. to reject serious consideration of    ##  ## He writes about race less regularly these days, and, when he does, it is often to dismiss the new mood as a kind of cult, long on shibboleths and pieties but woefully short on methods for bettering the lives of black Americans.

flashcards.name: disorganize
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'ɔ:gənaɪz] ## v. to destroy or interrupt the orderly structure or function of    ##  ## The real fear in the Trump era should be that everything will become disorganized, chaotic, degenerate, clownish and incompetent.

flashcards.name: disparage
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈspærɪdʒ] ## v. to describe as unimportant, weak, bad, etc.    ## slight ##  ## Republican members of Congress, who generally disagree with and disparage the idea of protectionism, applauded the line.

flashcards.name: disparate
flashcards.definition: [ˈdɪspərət] ## adj. different from each other     ## heterogeneous, diverse, dissimilar, variant ##  ## What Rooney loved about debating was entering a state of “flow,” that magical mental hum when disparate facts and ideas effortlessly assembled themselves in her mind and poured from her mouth as argument.

flashcards.name: dispassionate
flashcards.definition: [dɪs'pæʃənət] ## adj. not affected by personal or emotional involvement              ## temperate, analytical ##  ## Highly speculative theories of worldwide destruction—even the end of life on Earth—used as a call for a particular kind of political action serve neither the good reputation of science nor dispassionate political thought.

flashcards.name: dispatch
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈspætʃ] ## (1)v. to send quickly to a particular place for a particular purpose     (2)n. promptness and efficiency in performance or transmission    ## celerity ##  ## In the days that followed, investigators slowly sorted through the laptop’s contents, following standard protocols in a case that was anything but standard, and moving with surprisingly little dispatch to assess the significance of the e-mails.

flashcards.name: dispel
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈspel] ## (1)v. to make go away or end     ## (2)v. to drive away by or as if by scattering    ##  ## Despite the lengthy speeches and festive air, the conference did little to dispel what had become unmistakable: the slow expiry of a once vibrant movement.

flashcards.name: displace
flashcards.definition: [dɪsˈpleɪs] ## (1)v. to take the job or position of     ## (2)v. to force to leave the area where they live      ## obviate ## 28 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## In the early two-thousands, he did more than any other anchor to help Fox News displace CNN as the country’s most-watched cable-news network. ## Day 3 ## There are no secrets to success. It is the result of preparation, hard work, and learning from failure.

flashcards.name: disproportionate
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɪsprəˈpɔ:ʃənət] ## adj. being out of proportion       ##  ## The disproportionate stopping and frisking of blacks and Hispanics could be attributed to the disproportionate number of black and Hispanic people in the pool of criminals and potential criminals.

flashcards.name: dispute
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈspju:t] ## (1)v. to engage in argument     (2)v. to call into question    ##  ## Early Friday, CNN cited unnamed officials to report that the F.B.I. had rejected a White House request to dispute media reports that Trump’s campaign advisers were frequently in touch with Russian intelligence agents.

flashcards.name: disregard
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɪsrɪˈgɑ:d] ## (1)v. to pay no attention to    ## (2)v. to ignore or treat as unimportant    ## defy, contempt ##  ## Whether or not they actually are, members of the Trump Administration seem more than willing to disregard the ethics rules that they themselves created.

flashcards.name: dissemble
flashcards.definition: [di'sembl] ## v. to hide your true feelings, opinions, etc.    ## duplicity ##  ## American spies have killed ordinary people on the streets of Pakistani cities, while the United States government has dissembled about their status.

flashcards.name: dissimilar
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈsɪmɪlə] ## adj. different or unalike     ## heterogeneous ##  ## Even when Tri Angle records are structurally dissimilar, they share a fondness for odd noises that skitter through the music.

flashcards.name: distend
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈstend] ## v. to become larger and rounder because of pressure from inside    ##  ## Bubbles can cause bloating and gas, which distend your stomach, providing more surface area for alcohol to be absorbed (and mess with your sleep), according to Dasgupta.

flashcards.name: distinctive
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈstɪŋktɪv] ## adj. having a quality or characteristic that makes a person or thing different from others     ##  ## It veers off in directions that are as surprising as they are idiosyncratic; the movie’s identity is distinctive and integral—it really is a unique experience.

flashcards.name: distribution
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɪstrɪˈbju:ʃn] ## (1)n. the act of giving or delivering something to people     ## (2)n. the position, arrangement, or frequency of occurrence over an area or through a space or unit of time    ##  ## Relying on herd immunity is shortsighted, since over time fewer people will be infected and the virus can gain a new foothold. Indeed, the geographic distribution of Aedes aegypti, the mosquito species that transmits Zika, is expanding.

flashcards.name: divergent
flashcards.definition: [daɪ'vɜːdʒənt] ## adj. differing from each other or from a standard     ##  ## Has a national election ever suggested a more vividly divergent choice?

flashcards.name: diversity
flashcards.definition: [daɪˈvɜ:səti] ## n. the quality or state of having many different forms, types, ideas, etc. ##  ## heterogeneity ##  ## Last week, Google fired a software engineer for writing a memo that questioned the company’s gender diversity policies and made statements about women’s biological suitability for technical jobs.

flashcards.name: diverting
flashcards.definition: [daɪˈvɜ:tɪŋ] ## adj. providing amusement or entertainment     ## entertaining ##  ## Flight attendants on Southwest’s less-traveled routes are far funnier than the cast here. Watching a lonely suitcase circle a baggage claim conveyor belt is more diverting.

flashcards.name: divided
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈvaɪdɪd] ## adj. separated by different opinions      ##  ## The decision in the Castile case differed from other, similar cases of police violence in that it highlighted a kind of divided heart of Second Amendment conservatism, at least with regard to race.

flashcards.name: divorced
flashcards.definition: [dɪˈvɔ:st] ## adj. very different and separate from each other     ## untethered, abstracted ##  ## “Better Things,” like “Louie,” is an autobiographical portrait of a hardened divorced parent working in show business and raising precocious daughters, and it’s easy to find points of communion between them. ## 29 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: doctrinaire
flashcards.definition: [,dɑktrə'nɛr] ## adj. of, relating to, or characteristic of a person inflexibly attached toa practice or theory       ## dogmatic ##  ## Dissent’s socialism was never a doctrinaire program. It was closer to a spirit of criticism, a vision of a more just society, an openness to movements of democratic change, a refusal to accept the given on its own terms.

flashcards.name: documentary
flashcards.definition: [ˌdɒkjuˈmentri] ## adj. consisting of documents: written down     ##  ## For four days each March, Columbia, Missouri, is the epicenter of what might be called creative cinematic nonfiction— documentary films that probe, challenge, and expand the very nature of documentary filmmaking.

flashcards.name: dogmatic
flashcards.definition: [dɒgˈmætɪk] ## adj. expressing personal opinions or beliefs as if they are certainly correct and cannot be doubted           ## doctrinaire, rigid ##  ## By then, the rationalism of the Mu‘tazila school had been superseded by more dogmatic interpretations of Islam.

flashcards.name: doom
flashcards.definition: [du:m] ## (1)n. very bad events or situations that cannot be avoided     (2)v. to make certain to fail, suffer, die, etc.  ...     ##  ## His first album, “In Memory of Loss,” from 2010, was reissued in May, and it includes my go-to sad jam of the season, “You Should’ve Seen the Other Guy,” a tune about drinking and fighting, and about desperation and doom.

flashcards.name: douse
flashcards.definition: [daʊs] ## v. extinguish    ## extinguish ##  ## His lyrics were frequently doused with fatalism, yet he never seemed like a nihilist; Bennington was merely vexed by the futility of his love.

flashcards.name: dovish
flashcards.definition: [ˈdʌvɪʃ] ## adj. in favor of using peaceful and diplomatic methods to achieve something, rather than using force and violence       ## pacific ##  ## Like most other observers, I initially read it as a dovish document: it appeared to be designed to give Yellen and her colleagues the leeway to keep the funds rate low even well beyond the date when the unemployment rate drops below 6.5 per cent.

flashcards.name: downplay
flashcards.definition: [ˌdaʊnˈpleɪ] ## v. to make seem smaller or less important      ##  ## In previous White Houses, officials downplayed this sort of internal combat, insisting that everyone was united around the President’s agenda.

flashcards.name: drag
flashcards.definition: [dræg] ## (1)n. someone or something that makes action or progress slower or more difficult     ## (2)v. to pull (someone or something that is heavy or difficult to move)     ##  ## The older sister kicked it, wondering how to drag it through the forest toward the cove and the dock.

flashcards.name: dramatic
flashcards.definition: [drəˈmætɪk] ## (1)adj. sudden and extreme      (2)adj. attracting attention       ## spectacular ##  ## Dramatic declines in the numbers of new Zika cases have also been noted in South and Central America.

flashcards.name: draw
flashcards.definition: [drɔ:] ## v. to cause to come    ## elicit ##  ## Within months, Ms. Daniel, whose background is in retailing and fashion production, had introduced Harlem’s Fashion Row, a show conceived to draw attention to a roster of homegrown designers vying to make a name for themselves amid the hectic rounds of New York Fashion Week.

flashcards.name: dreary
flashcards.definition: [ˈdrɪəri] ## adj. causing unhappiness or sad feelings       ## tedious ##  ## Her father lived for a year so dreary and relentlessly full of pain that she was forced to wish him dead.

flashcards.name: droll
flashcards.definition: [drəʊl] ## adj. having and odd and amusing quality     ##  ## Shy and sheepish on first encounter, droll and mischievous on further acquaintance, fundamentally sweet in his dealings with the world, he was free of the coldness that so often appears in people of great talent.

flashcards.name: dubious
flashcards.definition: [ˈdju:biəs] ## (1)adj. unsure or uncertain       ## (2)adj. causing doubt, uncertainty, or suspicion     ## suspect ##  ## Even Chinese commentators who are utterly skeptical of the President have pointed to Ivanka as the most respectable of an otherwise dubious cohort.

flashcards.name: dull
flashcards.definition: [dʌl] ## adj. not exciting or interesting     ##  ## Some art demands awe, no matter how dull or corrupt the critical apparatus of the viewer.

flashcards.name: dump
flashcards.definition: [dʌmp] ## v. to leave or get rid of quickly or without concern       ## disgorge ##    30 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Jazz is when you dump a bucket of forks and knives down the basement stairs and then frantically look around, yelling, 'PLEASE tell me somebody got that!'

flashcards.name: duplicate
flashcards.definition: [ˈdju:plɪkeɪt] ## v. to make an exact copy of    ##  ## The hardest thing about pastiche is to duplicate the style and tone of the original without falling into parody—without the self- satisfying notion of superiority to an earlier age of artifice, as if only the past had style whereas the present day has a neutral, natural universality.

flashcards.name: duplicity
flashcards.definition: [dju:ˈplɪsəti] ## n. dishonest behavior that is meant to trick someone    ## dissemblance ##  ## The lies and duplicity became an unbearable burden.

flashcards.name: durable
flashcards.definition: ['dʊrəbl] ## adj. staying strong and in good condition over a long period of time      ##  ## At once aggressive and defensive, punitive and protective, the Venetian ghetto proved to be a remarkably durable arrangement —it was abolished, under Napoleon, only with the fall of the Serenissima in 1797.

flashcards.name: dwindle
flashcards.definition: [ˈdwɪndl] ## v. to gradually become smaller           ## contract ##  ## Such people still exist, but their number has dwindled, not least because rising ticket prices have made habitual attendance harder.

flashcards.name: easygoing
flashcards.definition: ['i:zɪˌgəʊɪŋ] ## adj. relaxed and casual in style or manner     ## affable ##  ## As Al Gore’s press secretary, in 2000, he led the double-black-diamond effort of making the Vice-President seem loose and easygoing on the campaign trail.

flashcards.name: ebb
flashcards.definition: [eb] ## v. to get worse    ## wane, decline ##  ## Those beloved tales had begun to ebb from memory by the beginning of the twentieth century, as the Arctic gradually lost its political and cultural stakes.

flashcards.name: eclipse
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈklɪps] ## (1)n. a loss of power, success, popularity, etc.     ## (2)v. to make less important or popular  ...       ## outdo ##  ## The government’s various financial scandals far eclipse the Palestinian question in the news.

flashcards.name: economic
flashcards.definition: [ˌi:kəˈnɑ:mɪk] ## adj. profitable       ## pecuniary ##  ## A peaceful vote in Kenya, which is regarded as the most vibrant economic and democratic power in East Africa, could unleash billions of dollars in infrastructure and development contracts.

flashcards.name: economy
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈkɑnəmɪ] ## n. careful use of money, resources, etc.    ## brevity ##  ## The Neoplatonists’ conception of a deity, in which perfection was measured by abundant fecundity, was contradicted by that of the Aristotelians, in which perfection was displayed in the economy of creation.

flashcards.name: ecstasy
flashcards.definition: [ˈekstəsi] ## n. a state of very great happiness    ## euphoria ##  ## The moment of ecstasy that Augustine and his mother shared was the most intense experience in his life—perhaps, as Rebecca West remarked, “the most intense experience ever commemorated.”

flashcards.name: efficacy
flashcards.definition: ['efɪkəsɪ] ## n. the power to produce a desired result or effect    ##  ## Ironically, the sharp drop in infections will make it difficult to demonstrate the efficacy of a candidate vaccine in field testing, since there is likely to be a relative dearth of new cases.

flashcards.name: effusive
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈfju:sɪv] ## adj. expressing a lot of emotion             ## emotional ##  ## He remained in good spirits the following day, although he was extremely garrulous, not in his usual effusive way but slightly manic, slightly off—a consequence, the doctors explained, of toxins building up in his bloodstream from temporary loss of kidney function.

flashcards.name: egalitarian
flashcards.definition: [iˌgælɪˈteəriən] ## adj. aiming for equal wealth, status, etc.       ##  ## Instead of becoming more egalitarian, the country has become less so: the gap between America’s rich and poor grows ever wider.

flashcards.name: egregious
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈgri:dʒiəs] ## adj. very bad and easily noticed       ## flagrant ##  ## In any case, King’s writing is affecting and engrossing, even as it’s egregious and frustrating.

flashcards.name: elate
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'leɪt] ## v. to make very happy and excited  ...   ##  ## McQueen worked the way a dreaming brain does, transmuting suppressed instinct into images that can trouble, mystify, and elate. ##    31 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: elegiac
flashcards.definition: [ˌelɪˈdʒaɪək] ## adj. written in or consisting of elegiac couplets     ## plaintive ##  ## The men fleeing our helicopter were transformed by his camera, their escape now framed as an elegiac narrative: solitary figures traversing an apocalyptic topography.

flashcards.name: elemental
flashcards.definition: [ˌelɪˈmentl] ## adj. of, relating to, or being the basic or essential constituent of something     ## rudimentary ##  ## After escaping the anxiety of influence, the poet discovered a brilliant, elemental poetry.

flashcards.name: elicit
flashcards.definition: [iˈlɪsɪt] ## v. to call forth or draw out    ## draw out ##  ## She did not inspire love, or affection, or even warm friendship, but she did elicit interest, respect, admiration, and enthusiasm.

flashcards.name: eliminate
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈlɪmɪneɪt] ## (1)v. to remove (something that is not wanted or needed)    (2)v. to defeat and remove from a competition    ## extirpate, put to rest ##  ## Gordon said that, at most banks today, the board members and senior staff don’t even have a credit card associated with the bank, in order to eliminate any appearance of a conflict of interest.

flashcards.name: elite
flashcards.definition: [eɪˈli:t] ## n. the people who have the most wealth and status in a society    ##  ## Fitzgerald, the author of The Great Gatsby and This Side of Paradise, became a fixture of US classrooms for the way he captured the extravagant lifestyles of the American elite, and the unsavory ways in which they sought to create legacies.

flashcards.name: elongate
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'lɔŋɡet] ## v. to make longer or to grow longer    ##  ## Even though Copeland now has a more elongated—more classical—physique, and no longer has a double-D chest, she remains more buxom than most ballet dancers, and also more visibly athletic.

flashcards.name: eloquent
flashcards.definition: ['eləkwənt] ## adj. marked by forceful and fluent expression     ## rhetoric ##  ## The best answer to the anthem conundrum, however, can be found in the most eloquent opinion in the history of the Supreme Court.

flashcards.name: elude
flashcards.definition: [iˈlu:d] ## (1)v. to avoid or escape by being quick, skillful, or clever     (2)v. to fail to be understood or remembered by    ...   ## puzzle ##  ## As a kid, Irving spent hours with his father practicing shooting the ball using fantastical spins so that his shots would elude the outstretched arms of the defender and bounce off the backboard into the hoop.

flashcards.name: elusive
flashcards.definition: [iˈlu:sɪv] ## (1)adj. hard to find or capture       ## (2)adj. hard to understand, define, or remember      ## slippery, evasive, cryptic ##  ## Beneath the madcap storytelling, there is an elusive coherence: the seventeenth chapter of each book is told backward, and the last lines in all three books rhyme.

flashcards.name: embed
flashcards.definition: [ɪm'bed] ## v. to place or set firmly in something else    ##  ## There are many insights in the essay collected in Observations on modernity, but they are embedded in a dense English translation of a dense German original that may make many of them opaque to most readers.

flashcards.name: emblematic
flashcards.definition: [ˌembləˈmætɪk] ## adj. representing something that cannot be seen by itself     ## totemic ##  ## Amusing as the gifts may be, they are emblematic of a more serious issue: Trump’s embrace of the Saudi regime, a stark reversal from his campaign rhetoric.

flashcards.name: embody
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈbɒdi] ## (1)v. to represent in a clear and obvious way     (2)v. to include as a part of feature    ##  ## The apathetic children embody the country’s worst fantasy of what will become of the most vulnerable if Sweden abandons its values.

flashcards.name: embrace
flashcards.definition: [ɛmˈbres] ## v. to accept readily or gladly      ##  ## When they arrive here, they embrace their new lives and, by language, habit, and culture, become American.

flashcards.name: embryonic
flashcards.definition: [ˌembriˈɒnɪk] ## adj. being in an early stage of development      ## rudimentary ##  ## Here is an embryonic single-payer system that is growing fast and could be further expanded pretty easily.

flashcards.name: emendation
flashcards.definition: [ˌi:menˈdeɪʃn] ## n. an alteration designed to correct or improve    ## revision ##  ## The cuts and emendations of the revised 1976 edition are interesting and authentic, of course, but also remove much of the grandeur and internal balance of what was clearly a grand opera. ##          32 ##   (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##

flashcards.name: emergent
flashcards.definition: [iˈmɜ:dʒənt] ## GRE     ##  ## (1)adj. arising unexpectedly      (2)adj. newly formed or prominent     ##  ## In Rousseau’s view, the newly emergent intellectual and technocratic class did little more than provide literary and moral cover for the powerful and the unjust.

flashcards.name: eminent
flashcards.definition: ['emɪnənt] ## adj. successful, well-known and respected     ## famous ## This novel offers a sideways look at the Victorian age through the story of a woman who, liberated by widowhood from a ghastly marriage, sets out to join the male-dominated ranks of eminent natural historians.

flashcards.name: empirical
flashcards.definition: [em'pɪrɪkl] ## adj. based on testing or experience          ## This ballet of musical objects not only illustrates Aristotle’s notion of a fundamental form outside the empirical realm—as matter decays, the spirit persists—but also celebrates the sonic diversity of avant-garde composition.

flashcards.name: employ
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈplɔɪ] ## (1)v. to use for a particular purpose or to do something     (2)v. to use or get the services of to do a particular job    ##  ## Early in the campaign, Smith decided that he would employ any means necessary to assure a victory for Hayes, who, at the time, was serving a third term as Ohio’s governor.

flashcards.name: empower
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpaʊə] ## v. to give official authority or legal power to    ##  ## FMNY is a nonprofit organization seeking to empower the women of New York state by advocating for changes to the political system.

flashcards.name: emulate
flashcards.definition: [ˈemjuleɪt] ## (1)v. to try to be like     ## (2)v. to strive to equal or excel      ## imitate ##  ## When I began to take classes at Yale, I could not understand, let alone emulate, the amused indifference of many of my classmates.

flashcards.name: enamor
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'næmə] ## v. to cause to be loved or admired     ## favor, captivate, hooked on ##  ## Watching highlights of Ntilikina’s defensive prowess will enamor the most pessimistic fan, but his offensive deficiencies can’t be ignored.

flashcards.name: encomium
flashcards.definition: [enˈkəʊmiəm] ## n. glowing and warmly enthusiastic praise    ## tribute ## A preschool in Chicago that I visited a few years earlier boasted that it was certified by the National Association for the Education of Young Children, the pre-K equivalent of the Good Housekeeping seal. But it didn’t merit that encomium.

flashcards.name: encumber
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈkʌmbə] ## v. to impede or hamper the function or activity of    ## Even encumbered by a giant prosthetic nose, he produced his characteristic virile tenor, his sound bright, taut and slightly metallic.

flashcards.name: encyclopedic
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˌsaɪkləˈpi:dɪk] ## adj. dealing with or knowing a subject thoroughly or completely          ## exhaustive, polymathic ##  ## Books are good at delivering essentially linear stories, she insists, while computers are good at telling stories of a different kind: procedural, participatory, encyclopedic, and spatial.

flashcards.name: endemic
flashcards.definition: [enˈdemɪk] ## adj. restricted or peculiar to a locality or region      ## native, domestic, indigenous ##  ## China is so big and so hungry that its appetites could well doom numerous species at once, from the armored pangolin to the Knysna sea horse, a monogamous fish endemic to South African estuaries.

flashcards.name: endorse
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdɔ:s] ## v. to publicly or officially say that you support or approve of    ## sanction, commend, support, authorize ##  ## Sessions is a singularly compromised choice to fill the role of protector of investigative independence, though, and not just because he was one of Trump’s earliest and most avid supporters and the first senator to endorse him.

flashcards.name: endowment
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdaʊmənt] ## (1)n. the act of providing money to create or support a school, organization, etc.     ## (2)n. a person’s natural ability or talent    ##  ## According to the Times, the fund-raising target is eight hundred million dollars, to cover construction costs and the initial endowment.

flashcards.name: enduring
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdjʊərɪŋ] ## adj. lasting, durable     ##  ##  Lula’s enduring appeal stems in part from the economic boom he oversaw during his term as President, when thirty million people in Brazil were lifted out of extreme poverty. ## 33 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: energize
flashcards.definition: [ˈenədʒaɪz] ## v. to give energy or excitement to  ...   ##  ## Upon waking, Vongerichten and Cole each drink water with lemon, and crave foods that will sustain and energize them throughout the day.

flashcards.name: enfeeble
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'fiːbəl] ## v. deprive of strength     ##  ## Humans are not the only creatures that benefit from a little companionship; isolation can also enfeeble rats, mice, pigs, rabbits, squirrel monkeys, starlings, and parrots.

flashcards.name: engaging
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈgeɪdʒɪŋ] ## adj. very attractive or pleasing in a way that holds your attention     ## winning ##  ## It’s a days-and-nights book, a detailed, sobersided, but very engaging and at times gripping chronicle of music and society, all of it devoted to the unending drive and conscientiousness that made Toscanini’s performances so riveting—and, to some, so repellent.

flashcards.name: engender
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdʒendə] ## v. to cause to exist or to develop    ## yield, induce ##  ## Anti-fur protestors crashing shows at New York Fashion Week are nothing new, but it seems their actions have rarely engendered change on the runways.

flashcards.name: enhance
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈhɑ:ns] ## v. to increase or improve       ## hone ##  ## They can be used to create a mood or a feeling for the entire book, be more specific to the text, or just be purely decorative and enhance the appeal of the overall book design.

flashcards.name: enigmatic
flashcards.definition: [ˌenɪgˈmætɪk] ## adj. full of mystery and difficult to understand       ## perplexing ##  ## Ashbery’s poetry is invariably described as difficult and enigmatic; in that sense, the man was distant from his writing, since, in person, he was anything but an enigma.

flashcards.name: enrich
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈrɪtʃ] ## v. to make rich or richer especially by the addition or increase of some desirable quality, attribute, or ingredient     ##  ## On this week’s Out Loud, Gopnik joins host Sasha Weiss, the literary editor of newyorker.com, for a stroll through SoHo and the Village to discuss how walking in the neighborhood has changed over time, and how walking can enrich the experience of urban life.

flashcards.name: ensue
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'su] ## v. to happen as a result      ##  ## Hilarious mishaps ensue, as the Young Pope is forced to complete the job himself.

flashcards.name: entailed by
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈteɪl] ## v. to impose, involve, or imply as a necessary accompaniment or result ##  ## inferable from ##  ## In the absence of a surface gradient, the new laws of refraction and reflection are entailed by the conventional law, so they represent more of an extension than a complete revolution.

flashcards.name: entangle
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'tæŋgl] ## v. to cause to get caught in or twisted with something else     ##  ## He doesn’t much like to talk about it in great detail, for fear of being entangled in it again.

flashcards.name: enterprising
flashcards.definition: [ˈentəpraɪzɪŋ] ## adj. having or showing the ability or desire to do new and difficult things ##  ##  ## As the cost of opening a restaurant in the city creeps ever skyward, a whole generation of enterprising young cooks is learning how to work all sorts of culinary miracles using less and less.

flashcards.name: entreat
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtri:t] ## v. to ask in a serious and emotional way    ##  ## A legal scholar who studied at Peking University, Cao will someday be in China’s history books for her courageous, persistent defense of Chinese “petitioners,” the common people who travel to the capital to entreat authorities to address injustices they have suffered in the provinces.

flashcards.name: entrench
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'trentʃ] ## v. to place in a very strong position that cannot easily be changed  ...       ##  ## You might see this as a problem, but turning to Big Data-driven algorithms to fix it will only further entrench our reliance on code to tell us what is important about the world—which is what led to the problem in the first place.

flashcards.name: enviable
flashcards.definition: [ˈenviəbl] ## adj. causing envy: very desirable       ## coveted ##  ## No mammal is known to share that enviable capability, but self-healing hair cells look enough like non-self-healing hair cells that scientists have been tantalized ever since by the possibility that human ears might be induced to repair themselves, too.

flashcards.name: ephemeral
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈfemərəl] ## adj. lasting a very short time     ## transitory, short-lived ##          34 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Indeed, its existence is so ephemeral that without special procedures medical researchers are unable to sample it before the body has destroyed it. The transient nature of the chemical transmitter is necessary to the normal functioning of the body.

flashcards.name: equable
flashcards.definition: ['ekwəbl] ## adj. tending to remain calm     ##  ## We expect them to be dispassionate in times of difficulty, equable and unruffled in the face of setbacks, slights, and partisan attacks.

flashcards.name: equanimity
