flashcards.definition: [,ekwə'nɪmɪtɪ] ## n. calm emotions when dealing with problems or pressure    ##  ## Psychological equanimity is restored by bolstering self-worth and faith in the cultural worldview, typically by engaging in culturally valued behaviors and by venerating people who are similar to oneself and berating, converting, or annihilating those who are different.

flashcards.name: equivalent
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'kwɪvələnt] ## adj. having the same value, use, meaning, etc.         ## commensurate ##  ## The meticulous dramatization of events intended to shock strikes me as the moral equivalent of pornography.

flashcards.name: equivocal
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'kwɪvəkl] ## adj. not easily understood or explained       ## ambiguous ##  ## Suu Kyi’s equivocal attitude towards the violence suffered by Burma’s Muslim minority has alarmed even her most dedicated fans.

flashcards.name: erode
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈrəʊd] ## v. to diminish or destroy by degrees    ##  ## If he pulls the U.S. out of the Paris Agreement, he will raise the risks of environmental calamities, erode America's claim to the moral high ground, and undercut the nation’s efforts to forge a leadership position in the transition to a low-carbon global economy.

flashcards.name: errant
flashcards.definition: [ˈerənt] ## (1)adj. moving about aimlessly or irregularly      (2)adj. behaving wrongly       ## wayward ##  ## The very conception of the modern corporation is that it limits individual liability. Yet, in the decades after the United Brands case, prosecutors often pursued both errant executives and the companies they worked for.

flashcards.name: erratic
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈrætɪk] ## adj. acting, moving, or changing in ways that are not expected or usual ##  ## fickle, versatile, volatile, flighty, capricious ##  ## Corporate executives increasingly view Trump as so erratic, unpredictable, and polarizing that being too close to him risks alienating employees and consumers.

flashcards.name: erroneous
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'ronɪəs] ## adj. not correct     ## inaccurate ##  ## The erroneous report has hindered Mrs. Trump’s potential of earning millions of dollars in her capacity as “one of the most photographed women in the world.”

flashcards.name: erstwhile
flashcards.definition: [ˈɜ:stwaɪl] ## adj. in the past     ## onetime ##  ## Of course, once the fanatics gained control of the state apparatus, or parts of it, they used it to consolidate power and eliminate their opponents and erstwhile allies.

flashcards.name: erudite
flashcards.definition: [ˈerudaɪt] ## adj. having or showing knowledge that is learned by studying     ## learned ##  ## John Harris was erudite and wild about garlic; he’d written a book on the subject and liked to wear this big old garlic hat, like a chef’s toque with a gigantic head of garlic at the top.

flashcards.name: eschew
flashcards.definition: [ɪsˈtʃu:] ## v. to avoid especially because you do not think it is right, proper, etc.     ##  ## David uses his expertise to help people challenge parking tickets and reduce or even eschew fines when possible.

flashcards.name: esoteric
flashcards.definition: [ˌesəˈterɪk] ## adj. hard to understand       ## recondite, arcane, abstruse ##  ## They continue to write in this way, deliberately obscure and esoteric, because it is a shortcut to being mysterious.

flashcards.name: espouse
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈspaʊz] ## v. to express support for    ## champion, advocate, defend ##  ## Alice espoused an eclectic set of beliefs drawn largely from Hindu texts such as the Bhagavad Gita and Vedas, but also from Taoism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, and ancient Egyptian religion.

flashcards.name: essential
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈsenʃl] ## (1)adj. extremely important and necessary        (2)adj. very basic     ## indispensable ##     35 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Trump, in the manic seven months since his Inauguration, has lacked the essential quality of Presidential leadership, which is to be able to hold the trust, respect, and confidence of a majority of Americans; its absence now casts doubt over any decision he makes.

flashcards.name: established
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈstæblɪʃt] ## adj. well known because it has existed for a long time            ##  ## Medzhitov believes that all our tissues have “established rules by which cells form engagements and alliances with other cells.

flashcards.name: estrange
flashcards.definition: [ɪs'treɪndʒ] ## v. to cause someone to be no longer friendly or close to another person or group     ## unlinked, disaffect ##  ## The song might be interpreted as a revenge tune directed at Tim Goldsworthy, who co-founded DFA, and from whom Murphy is now estranged.

flashcards.name: eternal
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈtɜ:nl] ## adj. lasting forever     ##  ## The comedy inherent in the setup is balanced by the bereaved couple’s anguish and longing; Lowery’s spare, ardent images take a practical look at both sides of the boundary between life and death, between the present day and the eternal.

flashcards.name: eulogize
flashcards.definition: [ˈju:lədʒaɪz] ## v. to speak or write in high praise of    ## lionize ##  ## William Dym eulogized his father Wednesday as “the greatest man” in his life — despite evidence to the contrary in the two caskets alongside his dad’s remains.

flashcards.name: euphoria
flashcards.definition: [ju:ˈfɔ:riə] ## n. a feeling of great happiness and excitement    ## ecstasy ##  ## The remark elicited laughs and lightened the mood. But the flyover dampened the euphoria and lingered on forebodingly.

flashcards.name: evanescent
flashcards.definition: [ˌi:vəˈnesnt] ## adj. lasting a very short time     ## momentary ##  ## The explanation is also ridiculous because a victory like this is the result not of evanescent events but rather the culmination of years in which the political stew of discontent was simmering until Trump brought it to a sizzling boil.

flashcards.name: evasive
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈveɪsɪv] ## adj. tending or intended to evade: equivocal           ## elusive, equivocal ##  ## If there was an organizing principle in Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday—which was by turns dismissive, incoherent, evasive, and shameful—it was that certain people are owed deference, and certain others are not.

flashcards.name: evenhanded
flashcards.definition: ['i:vən'hændɪd] ## adj. not favoring one side or group over another     ## impartial ##  ## The pathologies of American journalism are by now clichés: aversion to policy analysis; addiction to horse-race politics; smashing of walls that once separated news, opinion and advertising; an ideology that mistakes evenhandedness for objectivity.

flashcards.name: evolve
flashcards.definition: [iˈvɒlv] ## v. to change or develop slowly often into a better, more complex, or more advanced state      ##  ## Former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon offered his predictions about how the Trump administration will evolve now that he is no longer working for the president.

flashcards.name: exacerbate
flashcards.definition: [ɪɡ'zæsɚbet] ## v. to make more violent, bitter, or severe     ## aggravate ##  ## The cheapest PSAPS, some of which sell for less than fifty dollars, are notoriously junky and may even exacerbate hearing loss by indiscriminately amplifying harmful sounds.

flashcards.name: exacting
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzæktɪŋ] ## adj. requiring much time, attention, or effort from someone     ## prescriptive, rigorous, demanding ##  ## Some members of his band have been playing with him since the nineteen-seventies, and they know him as an easygoing but exacting leader who wants his songs to sound just the way fans remember them.

flashcards.name: exactitude
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzæktɪtju:d] ## n. the quality or state of being accurate and correct     ## meticulousness ##  ## Macho and minimalist alike, the sentences are thrilling still in their exactitude and audacity.

flashcards.name: exaggerate
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzædʒəreɪt] ## v. to think of or describe something as larger or greater than it really is ##  ## hyperbole, overrate ##  ## One of the dangers in covering an abnormal Presidency is that journalists will constantly be on the lookout for signs of normalcy, and exaggerate and even celebrate them as proof that things aren’t so unusual, after all.

flashcards.name: exalt
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzɔ:lt] ## v. to praise highly    ## valorize ##  ## The role of the critic, Scott says, is to resist the manufactured consensus—to interrogate the successful, to exalt the unknown, to argue for ambiguity and complexity.

flashcards.name: exasperation
flashcards.definition: [ɪɡˌzɑ:spə'reɪʃn] ## n. the state of being very annoyed or upset    ## irascibility ##  36 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Her forehands were suddenly sailing long, her double faults were mounting, and her body language was projecting exasperation and unease.

flashcards.name: exceptional
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈsepʃənl] ## (1)adj. not usual       ## (2)adj. much better than average     ## preternatural ##  ## It turned out to be an exceptional piece of work, and its production by the New York City Opera (which runs at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Rose Theatre through April 5th) has proved to be the finest effort so far of the recently reëstablished company.

flashcards.name: excoriate
flashcards.definition: [ˌeksˈkɔ:rieɪt] ## v. to criticize very harshly      ## indict, crab ##  ## Trump had been excoriated for his unwillingness to condemn the groups behind the violent protests that left one woman dead who was hit by a car allegedly driven by a man with ties to white supremacy groups.

flashcards.name: exculpate
flashcards.definition: [ˈekskʌlpeɪt] ## v. to prove that someone is not guilty of doing something wrong       ## vindicate ##  ## According to his attorney, the abiding amount of evidence and witness statements seem to exculpate him from the assault in Galveston earlier this season.

flashcards.name: exemplary
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzempləri] ## (1)adj. extremely good and deserving to be admired and copied      (2)adj. serving as an example of something     ## model ##  ## That’s why, though True/False marks a major trend in contemporary filmmaking, it also defines a crucial, exemplary exception to the rule.

flashcards.name: exhaustive
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzɔ:stɪv] ## adj. very thorough     ## encyclopedic, comprehensive ##  ## Hafner was not involved in the lunchbox paper, but from 2004 to 2012 he and a team of researchers conducted an exhaustive examination of nine hundred artifacts from a different mountain pass nearby.

flashcards.name: exigent
flashcards.definition: ['eksɪdʒənt] ## adj. requiring immediate attention     ## pressing ##  ## ICE said it currently prohibits agents from entering schools, hospitals or houses of worship “unless they have prior approval from an appropriate supervisory official or in the event of exigent circumstances

flashcards.name: exiguous
flashcards.definition: [egˈzɪgjuəs] ## adj. excessive scanty     ## tenuous ##  ## In a landmark ruling in October 2013, Justice Simon threw out the entire case, arguing that Karpov’s “connection with this country is exiguous and therefore there is a degree of artificiality about his seeking to protect his reputation in this country.

flashcards.name: exonerate
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzɒnəreɪt] ## v. to prove that someone is not guilty of a crime or responsible for a problem, bad situation, etc.    ## absolve ##  ## Some defendants argue they were wrongly convicted because the DNA analysis was flawed. In other cases, the DNA analysis has helped exonerate defendants.

flashcards.name: expansion
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈspænʃn] ## n. the act of becoming bigger or of making something bigger       ## augmentation, burgeoning ##  ## Following the defeat of the far right in the Austrian, Dutch, and French elections, a planned expansion to France and Germany has not happened.

flashcards.name: expel
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈspel] ## v. to officially force to leave a place or organization       ## oust ##  ## Charlottesville confronts Canadian Conservatives with a choice: to play footsy with intolerants, or to expel them from the party and the movement.

flashcards.name: experimental
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˌsperɪˈmentl] ## (1)adj. relating to a scientific experiment or to scientific experiments in general      ## (2)adj. using a new way of doing or thinking about something     ## innovative ##  ## This episode looks at houses that have really pushed the architectural boundaries by using experimental techniques.

flashcards.name: explicit
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈsplɪsɪt] ## (1)adj. fully revealed or expressed without vagueness, implication, or ambiguity        ## (2)adj. fully developed or formulated     ##  ## Sometimes the analysis is explicit and conscious, though in most cases it's subconscious and embedded in euphemism.

flashcards.name: exploit
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈsplɔɪt] ## (1)v. to get value or use form     ## (2)v. to use in a way that helps you unfairly    ##  ## If he’s not an outright racist—and many people would say that he is—he’s always eager to exploit the racial prejudices that some of his supporters harbor. ## 37 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: external
flashcards.definition: [ɪk'stɜːnl] ## adj. coming from outside     ##  ## Army's top commanders on Friday discussed internal and external security situation of the country and progress of operation Radd ul Fasaad at the Corps Commanders' Conference, the military said.

flashcards.name: extinguish
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈstɪŋgwɪʃ] ## (1)v. to cause to stop burning     (2)v. to cause the end or death of    ## douse ##  ## Like their penises are on fire and they will die if they can’t extinguish the flames in some damp, tight hole.

flashcards.name: extirpate
flashcards.definition: [ˈekstəpeɪt] ## v. to destroy or remove completely    ## eliminate ##  ## I would simply pack enough coffee to cover several months of severe withdrawal in order to extirpate the demons of caffeine.

flashcards.name: extol
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈstəʊl] ## v. to praise highly    ## applaud ##  ## People now look for ways of boosting the “good cholesterol” in their blood and extol the benefits of Mediterranean diets, with their emphasis on olive oil and fatty nuts.

flashcards.name: extraneous
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈstreɪniəs] ## adj. not forming a necessary part of something     ## irrelevant ##  ## Each movement dovetails perfectly with the next, with no extraneous steps or flourishes.

flashcards.name: extrapolate
flashcards.definition: [ɪk'stræpəleɪt] ## n. to form an opinion or to make an estimate about something from known facts    ##  ## Although not stated explicitly in the story, we can extrapolate that to acquire as much knowledge as she can is a way for her to exert some control on a world that would otherwise only worry and confuse her.

flashcards.name: extravagant
flashcards.definition: [ɪk'strævəgənt] ## adj. more than is usual, necessary, or proper         ##  ## The President bristled at the suggestion that paying Mexico to keep Trump was “reverse ransom” and an extravagant use of taxpayer money.

flashcards.name: extremist
flashcards.definition: [ɪkˈstri:mɪst] ## n. people who use violent or extreme methods      ## zealot ##  ## Acknowledging the frustrations and hopes of American Muslims, or of Afghans, of course, will not stabilize countries or counter extremist groups.

flashcards.name: exuberant
flashcards.definition: [ɪgˈzju:bərənt] ## (1)adj. very lively, happy, or energetic        (2)adj. existing in large amounts     ##  ## He was artistically ambitious and personally humble, exuberant, frantic, and funny.

flashcards.name: eye-catching
flashcards.definition: [aɪˈkætʃɪŋ] ## adj. very noticeable       ##  ## While there were some eye-catching exercises in bright color, particularly vibrant pinks and sunny yellows on tailored jackets that might be explained by Ford’s recent relocation to Los Angeles, there was plenty of dusty roses, dark denims and inky blacks on hand as well.

flashcards.name: facile
flashcards.definition: [ˈfæsaɪl] ## adj. not showing enough thought or effort         ##  ## That this cause, the one that the word “nigger” is meant to serve, might ever have found a place of honor is a more apt barometer of the country’s relationship to its own history than the facile concerns over the usage of the word.

flashcards.name: facilitate
flashcards.definition: [fəˈsɪlɪteɪt] ## v. help bring about       ## further ##  ## We sought to facilitate the process by proffering Bach, whose works are full of symmetry, and Beethoven, who championed Bach’s music and borrowed from it.

flashcards.name: factious
flashcards.definition: ['fækʃəs] ## adj. of or relating to faction         ## schism ##  ## Trump could not be easily normalized, even if the media had such a goal. But the country’s highly polarized electorate and its factious media environment are combining to produce a linguistic battle royale.

flashcards.name: fairness
flashcards.definition: [ˈfeənəs] ## n. the act of treating people in a way that does not favor some over others    ## objectivity ##  ## Although Bharara’s approach to policing white-collar crime found many critics, he was an effective, ambitious prosecutor, someone who strongly believed in the concept of justice and fairness, and who targeted corrupt Democrats as well as Republicans.

flashcards.name: fallacious
flashcards.definition: [fəˈleɪʃəs] ## adj. containing a mistake     ##  ## To portray Ronald Reagan as a friend of the working class is not only fallacious—it is dangerous. ##     38 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: fanciful
flashcards.definition: [ˈfænsɪfl] ## (1)adj. coming from the imagination      (2)adj. existing in fancy only       ##  ## It seems like even the most fanciful and absurd idea for a new show has a shot at being brought to life.

flashcards.name: fascinate
flashcards.definition: ['fæsɪneɪt] ## v. to cause to be very interested in     ##  ## Ants fascinate me, with their matriarchy, industry, and powerful sense of smell, which they use to recognize the caste of other colony members.

flashcards.name: fastidious
flashcards.definition: [fæ'stɪdɪəs] ## adj. showing or demanding excessive delicacy or care              ##  ## He descends from the cerebral and expressive jazz guitarist Jim Hall, and if he sometimes seems to lose his way it is usually in the direction of a too fastidious intellectual rigor.

flashcards.name: faultless
flashcards.definition: [ˈfɔ:ltləs] ## adj. irreproachable       ## perfect ##  ## Even if we are not faultless, the news media remain an essential component in the democratic process and should not be undermined by the president.

flashcards.name: favorable
flashcards.definition: ['feɪvərəbl] ## (1)adj. showing approval     (2)adj. marked by success     ## auspicious ##  ## He was, on the other hand, pleased to learn that the new Juno-Gett would be honoring the favorable commission rate Juno had been offering, at least for a few months.

flashcards.name: fealty
flashcards.definition: ['fiːəltɪ] ## n. loyalty to a person, group, etc.    ##  ## For the time being, at least, the former ExxonMobil executive is staying and even signalled his fealty by putting out an official statement in support of the president’s tax cut plan, an unusual intervention in domestic policy for a secretary of state.

flashcards.name: feckless
flashcards.definition: ['feklɪs] ## adj. having or resulting from a weak character or nature     ##  ## In China, a country that is trying to reconcile its system of stringent political control with the porousness of modern culture, even a feckless pop star like Justin Bieber can be a threat.

flashcards.name: feeble
flashcards.definition: [ˈfi:bl] ## adj. markedly lacking in strength     ##  ## Her daughter’s psyche is so feeble that anything can rattle her.

flashcards.name: feedback
flashcards.definition: [ˈfi:dbæk] ## n. helpful information or criticism that is given to someone to say what can be done to improve a performance, product, etc.    ##  ## Some passengers in the previous feedback suggested that staff deployed at the gate should greet passengers with a smile and should know the local language.

flashcards.name: feigned
flashcards.definition: [feɪnd] ## adj. not genuine or real    ## false ##  ## The response from Republican officials tended toward outrage, both feigned and genuine.

flashcards.name: fervor
flashcards.definition: [ˌfɜ:və] ## n. a strong feeling of excitement and enthusiasm    ##  ## Throughout the 2016 Presidential race, the Enquirer embraced Trump with sycophantic fervor.

flashcards.name: fester
flashcards.definition: ['festə] ## v. to become worse as time passes    ##  ## The Weimar-era silent film “Different from the Others” shows how hatred can fester even in liberal democracies.

flashcards.name: fickle
flashcards.definition: ['fɪkl] ## adj. changing often     ## versatile, volatile, flighty, erratic, capricious ##  ## How did the fickle sands of time slip through your fingers so easily?

flashcards.name: fiery
flashcards.definition: [ˈfaɪəri] ## (1)adj. full of or exuding emotion or spirit      (2)adj. easily provoked     ## impassioned ##  ## Cool, brutal, elegant, fiery, he established a kind of International Style in music, and propagated it in polemical writings and through institutional networks.

flashcards.name: figurative
flashcards.definition: [ˈfɪgərətɪv] ## adj. showing people and things in a way that resembles how they really look         ## symbolic ##  ## The artist has spent her career using abstract and figurative images to tell enigmatic stories. But a recent work has made her an incendiary figure. ##         39 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: filter
flashcards.definition: ['fɪltə] ## n. a device that is used to remove something unwanted from a liquid or gas that passes through it     ##  ## Their search turned up a number of misconduct-related e-mails, although further analysis was still required as a final filter.

flashcards.name: fitting
flashcards.definition: [ˈfɪtɪŋ] ## adj. of a kink that is appropriate for the situation or purpose     ## apposite ##  ## At a press briefing that was supposed to be about infrastructure, Trump tossed aside his previous condemnation of white nationalists like an ill-fitting suit.

flashcards.name: fixated
flashcards.definition: [fɪkˈseɪtɪd] ## adj. arrested in development or adjustment       ## obsessed ##  ## It was opened, in March, by Felipe Mendez Candelas, an obsessive record collector who has lately been fixated on African dance music, tropical house, and disco.

flashcards.name: flagrant
flashcards.definition: [ˈfleɪgrənt] ## adj. conspicuously offensive       ## egregious ##  ## One of the angriest Republicans, Senator Tom Cotton, of Arkansas, said he was “disgusted and offended” by the “flagrant exercise of freedom of speech” he witnessed at his town hall.

flashcards.name: fleeting
flashcards.definition: ['flitɪŋ] ## adj. lasting for only a short time     ## momentary ##  ## That fleeting period of time—shortly before the sun sets, or after it rises, when shadows grow longer and everything appears to glow—lends us an opportunity to reconsider the world around us, recast in warm color.

flashcards.name: flexibility
flashcards.definition: [ˌfleksə'bɪlətɪ] ## n. the state of being easily changed         ## adaptability, suppleness ##  ## The classic arcade game demands flexibility and quick decision-making—the same skills that artificial-intelligence researchers want in their algorithms.

flashcards.name: flourish
flashcards.definition: [ˈflʌrɪʃ] ## (1)v. to grow well     ## (2)v. to be very successful     ## (3)v. to hold up and show in an excited or proud way    ##  ## On the flip side, Van Berkel’s work illuminates the mental conditions in which equality might flourish.

flashcards.name: flout
flashcards.definition: [flaʊt] ## v. to break or ignore without hiding what you are doing or showing fear of shame      ## spurn, defy, disregard ##  ## The American people deserve an Attorney General who will come to work every day ready to flout the Constitution.

flashcards.name: fluctuate
flashcards.definition: [ˈflʌktʃueɪt] ## v. to change level, strength, or value frequently         ## vary, vacillate ##  ## Presidential powers are not fixed but fluctuate depending upon their disjunction or conjunction with those of Congress.

flashcards.name: flummery
flashcards.definition: [ˈflʌməri] ## n. mummery, mumbo jumbo          ##  ## The stars’ attitudes toward their glowing press are diametrically opposed: some think it flummery and others take the adulation seriously.

flashcards.name: flummox
flashcards.definition: [ˈflʌməks] ## v. confuse     ## confound ##  ## Under the leadership of Michels, and later as a manager himself, he helped to perfect the fluid playing style known as Total Football, in which, rather than executing set plays and chasing down long passes, players constantly exchanged positions, moving into open space and making sharp passes in order to flummox the opposing team’s defense.

flashcards.name: flush with
flashcards.definition: [flʌʃ] [wɪð] ## v.   ...    ##  ## Saul’s particular combination of intellectuality and vitality was not paradoxical; it was category-shattering. Energy was, in a way, his very theme. Was ever a bookish soul so cracklingly unmediated, so flush with raw life?

flashcards.name: forbear
flashcards.definition: [fɔ:ˈbeə] ## v. to choose not to do    ##  ## She was never precipitate; she was nothing if not discreet, so she forbore for the present to declare her passion.

flashcards.name: foreground
flashcards.definition: ['fɔrɡraʊnd] ## (1)v. to make more important          (2)n. an important position      ##  ## A border fence, snaking along a hill in the distance, is echoed, in the foreground, by a highway’s double yellow line—the kind that drivers aren’t legally allowed to cross.

flashcards.name: forerunner
flashcards.definition: [ˈfɔ:rʌnə] ## (1)n. someone or something that comes before another     (2)n. a sign of something that is going to happen    ## precursor ##     40 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The series was a forerunner to the conceptual approach to cartoons that blossomed decades later, in the works of artists such as William Steig and Saul Steinberg.

flashcards.name: foresee
flashcards.definition: [fɔ:ˈsi:] ## v. to see beforehand    ## anticipate ##  ## The way this institution operates against its own people provides a preview of the future that both American and Israeli officials will now foresee for Palestinians in the occupied territories.

flashcards.name: foresight
flashcards.definition: ['fɔːsaɪt] ## n. the ability to see what will or might happen in the future      ##  ## The University of Colorado’s Center of the American West, of which Limerick is the faculty director, has an official motto: “Turning hindsight into foresight.”

flashcards.name: forestall
flashcards.definition: [fɔ:ˈstɔ:l] ## (1)v. to stop from happening or to cause to happen at a later time        ## (2)v. to act before in order to prevent something      ## stave off, avert, prevent ##  ## To forestall further acts of terror, Bangladesh's government will have to face up to that grim new reality.

flashcards.name: forge
flashcards.definition: [fɔːdʒ] ## (1)v. to form by heating and hammering     ## (2)v. to make or imitate falsely especially with intent to defraud    ## fabricate ##  ## It could help to forge solidarity between women with favorable working conditions and women who have no such thing.

flashcards.name: forgo
flashcards.definition: [fɔ:'ɡəʊ] ## v. to give up the use or enjoyment of    ##  ## When a magnificent vessel the size of a human head lands on your table soon thereafter, you will be grateful that you didn’t forgo the entrée.

flashcards.name: formidable
flashcards.definition: ['fɔːmɪdəbl] ## (1)adj. causing fear, dread, or apprehension      (2)adj. tending to inspire awe or wonder        (3)adj. very difficult to deal with      ## daunting ##  ## The new action comedy “Keeping Up with the Joneses,” starring Jon Hamm, Zach Galifianakis, Isla Fisher, and Gal Gadot, is a formidable reminder of the power of the Hollywood star system.

flashcards.name: formulaic
flashcards.definition: [ˌfɔ:mjuˈleɪɪk] ## adj. being not original and having been used many times before in similar situations          ## canned ##  ## Jaime Javier Rodriguez notes that popular art forms often conceal a daunting complexity: frequently what appears formulaic becomes intricate and challenging when closely examined.

flashcards.name: forsake
flashcards.definition: [fəˈseɪk] ## v. to give up or leave entirely    ## neglect ##  ## He keeps her, to thread her way among the others or to start up a little something on the side—thus giving texture to what’s going on in the middle—or just to lie down and look bored, whereupon all the men forsake their partners and run to her.

flashcards.name: foster
flashcards.definition: [ˈfɒstə] ## (1)v. affording, receiving, or sharing nurture or parental care though not related by blood or legal ties     ## (2)v. to help grow or develop    ## spur, adopt ##  ## Larissa MacFarquhar’s article shines a light on the tragedy of children in the foster-care system by giving a voice to mothers, caseworkers, judges, and attorneys (“The Separation,” August 7th & 14th).

flashcards.name: foundation
flashcards.definition: [faʊnˈdeɪʃn] ## (1)n. the act of founding     ## (2)n. a basis upon which something stands or is supported       ## inception, bedrock ##  ## Chuck Berry takes up a lot of square footage in the foundation of rock music. And every musician knows it.

flashcards.name: founder
flashcards.definition: [ˈfaʊndə] ## (1)v. to experience failure     ## (2)n. one founds or establishes     ##  ## In the discussions on international patent law, many contentious issues will probably be pushed far into the future. This cautious approach makes diplomatic sense, since attempts over the past 15 years to reach international agreements on patents have foundered just such sensitive issues.

flashcards.name: fractious
flashcards.definition: [ˈfrækʃəs] ## (1)adj. full of anger and disagreement      (2)adj. hard to manage or control      ## restive, skittish ##  ## Even in a fractious era, the filmmaker still believes that his documentaries can bring every viewer in.

flashcards.name: fraudulent
flashcards.definition: ['frɔdʒələnt] ## adj. done to trick someone for the purpose of getting something valuable      ## malfeasant ##  41 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## I e-mailed Catherine Frazier, a spokeswoman for the Cruz campaign, and asked her what the campaign’s methodology was for arriving at its voting scores and whether the scores were fraudulent.

flashcards.name: fringe
flashcards.definition: [frɪndʒ] ## n. edge, periphery    ## marginal, peripheral ##  ## One might observe a fascination with fringe communities, or a belief that journalism should be dangerous if not borderline illicit, or a particular kind of humor that involves the unapologetic intermingling of high and low culture.

flashcards.name: frugal
flashcards.definition: ['fruɡl] ## adj. simple and plain     ## thrifty ##  ## Before there was Marie Kondo, who taught us the magic of tidiness, or Hillary Clinton, who made a white pantsuit into a mantra, there was Sara Berman, whose frugal all-white wardrobe is the subject of a new exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

flashcards.name: frustrating
flashcards.definition: [frʌˈstreɪtɪŋ] ## adj. causing feelings of anger and annoyance       ##  ## Investigative journalism can sound awfully dull and frustrating: endless hours spent trying to understand legal documents, calling people who refuse to talk, getting exciting breakthroughs that turn out to be incorrect.

flashcards.name: fund
flashcards.definition: [fʌnd] ## (1)n. an amount of money that is used for a special purpose     (2)v. to provide money for  ...     ##  ## Even though the source of funding has been determined to be a less significant cause of bias than other factors, industry support suffices, in the minds of many people, to vitiate the credibility of scientific work.

flashcards.name: fundamental
flashcards.definition: [fʌndə'mentl] ## adj. forming or relating to the most important part of something          ##  ## Claims about “the national interest” often hinder science in its pursuit of its most important goal: the unfettered and open questioning of even our most fundamental assumptions about reality.

flashcards.name: fungible
flashcards.definition: ['fʌndʒɪbl] ## adj. interchangeable      ## interchangeable ##  ## Seeming and being were, and remain, magnetic poles of Basquiat’s genius, and elements of a fungible myth.

flashcards.name: fusion
flashcards.definition: ['fjʊʒən] ## n. a combination or mixture of things    ## synthesis ##  ## Depending on the quality of your introduction to sesame-crusted tuna or similar sanitized novelties at trendier-than-thou enclaves, your opinion of Asian fusion may occupy some intersection of tortured and tacky.

flashcards.name: fusty
flashcards.definition: [ˈfʌsti] ## (1)adj. full of dust and unpleasant smells      (2)adj. very old-fashioned     ## obsolete, outmoded ##  ## The authoritarian reformers were less fusty country squires attached to old English institutions than an élite executive class of intellectuals and aristocrats.

flashcards.name: futile
flashcards.definition: ['fjʊtaɪl] ## adj. pointless or useless     ## pointless ##  ## It’s self-comforting, rather, in its exercise of Bush’s never-doubted sincerity and humility—virtues that were maddeningly futile when he governed, and that now shine brighter, in contrast with Trump, than may be merited.

flashcards.name: gaffe
flashcards.definition: [gæf] ## n. a mistake made in a social situation    ##  ## Hillary Clinton’s “basket of deplorables” gaffe has allowed Donald Trump, of all people, to pose as a uniting influence.

flashcards.name: galvanize
flashcards.definition: [ˈgælvənaɪz] ## v. to stimulate or excite as if by an electric shock    ## animate, rouse ##  ## Trump’s January executive order, he said, helped galvanize Republican support for the state law, and federal hostility to local power framed the terms of the debate.

flashcards.name: garrulous
flashcards.definition: [ˈgærələs] ## adj. tending to talk a lot       ## loquacious ##  ## He was naturally garrulous and jocose—indeed, by the time he was a celebrity he was so garrulous and jocose that it shocked people, though he was just being himself.

flashcards.name: gauge
flashcards.definition: [ɡeɪdʒ] ## (1)v. to measure exactly        ## (2)n. an instrument that is used for measuring something      ## reckon ##  ## He could no longer reliably gauge how irrational, irresponsible, and self-destructive members of his own party might be.

flashcards.name: general
flashcards.definition: ['dʒenərəl] ## (1)adj. involving, applicable to, or affecting the whole      (2)adj. not specific     ## abstract ##  ## In sharp contrast to the novel’s scenic realism and precisely characterized figure is its persistent philosophical generality.

flashcards.name: generate
flashcards.definition: [ˈdʒenəreɪt] ## v. to produce or cause to be produced    ## originate ##            42 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## A person’s capacity to generate a large number of e-mails is a key indicator that he or she has the stamina to perform well in a demanding executive position, a new medical report released on Monday asserts. ## Day 4 ## Few things are impossible in themselves; and it is often for want of will, rather than of means, that man fails to succeed.

flashcards.name: generic
flashcards.definition: [dʒəˈnerɪk] ## adj. of or relating to a whole group or class     ## inclusive ##  ## There’s an antique birdcage and a mellow oak bar, and cocktails like the Sunday Tea (peach moonshine, bourbon, sweet tea, lemon), which might lull you into a generic dream of the South.

flashcards.name: genial
flashcards.definition: [ˈdʒi:niəl] ## adj. kind and friendly     ## friendly ##  ## He was the genial overseeing adult of a beautiful children’s crusade, who helped keep it from chaos.

flashcards.name: genius
flashcards.definition: [ˈdʒi:niəs] ## (1)n. a very smart or talented person     (2)n. great natural ability    ##  ## Few performances—and few films—glow as brightly with the gemlike fire of precocious genius.

flashcards.name: germane
flashcards.definition: [dʒɜ:ˈmeɪn] ## adj. relating to a subject in an appropriate way       ## relevant, apposite ##  ## It is hard to imagine a more germane soundtrack to emotional upheaval than “Total Eclipse of the Heart”—it’s the song we reach for when we have grown tired of exhibiting graceful restraint.

flashcards.name: given
flashcards.definition: ['ɡɪvn] ## adj. specified, fixed         ##  ## Baker was struck by the amount of contention she saw at the renowned medical facility; for all their experience, the physicians could not seem to agree on the correct diagnosis for any given patient.

flashcards.name: glean
flashcards.definition: [gli:n] ## v. to gather or collect in a gradual way       ## obtain ##  ## I suspect that listeners in 2017—like me after my week of excessive emotion—will be highly receptive listeners, eager for any insights we can glean.

flashcards.name: gloat
flashcards.definition: [gləʊt] ## v. to show in an improper or selfish way that you are happy with you own success or another person’s failure      ##  ## To the Brits, the Fourth of July is a day for rebels to gloat, waste good tea, and serve bangers sans mash (gasp).

flashcards.name: gloomy
flashcards.definition: [ˈglu:mi] ## adj. sad or depressed     ## lugubrious, cheerless ##  ## Most Trump supporters, however, would not let such gloomy predictions about the future ruin what for them was a day of unbridled celebration.

flashcards.name: glut
flashcards.definition: [glʌt] ## n. to much of something    ## surfeit, plethora ##  ## Stamper displays a contagious enthusiasm for words and a considerable talent for putting them together, as when describing “the fusty glut of old papers bunged hastily into metal bookshelves” that fills the basement of Merriam-Webster.

flashcards.name: goose bumps
flashcards.definition: [guːsbʌmps] ## n. small bumps on your skin that are caused by cold, fear, or a sudden feeling of excitement      ##  ## My arms prickled with goose bumps, and the minute and a half of totality felt no longer than a head-spinning ten seconds.

flashcards.name: govern
flashcards.definition: [ˈgʌvn] ## (1)v. to exercise continuous sovereign authority over     (2)v. to control or guide the actions of    ## determine ##  ## Some have argued that naming scientific discoveries after the people who make them can hamper scientific progress, because the nomenclature lacks useful clarity, having no relationship to the underlying principles that govern nature.

flashcards.name: gratify
flashcards.definition: [ˈgrætɪfaɪ] ## v. to make happy or satisfied         ## please ##  ## The prospect of a retrospective would doubtless gratify him, although the skeptic in him would be astounded.

flashcards.name: gregarious
flashcards.definition: [grɪ'geərɪəs] ## (1)adj. marked by or indicating a liking for companionship       (2)adj. growing in a cluster or colony     ## sociable ##  ## A bar underneath Kaufman Astoria Studios hosts gregarious locals—and possibly a chainsmoking ghost.

flashcards.name: groundless
flashcards.definition: [ˈgraʊndləs] ## adj. not based on facts      ## unwarranted ##  ## It was a law of remarkable mean-spiritedness, seemingly intended to produce moral panic around groundless fears of cross- dressing men following women into bathrooms and high-school boys invading girls’ locker rooms.

flashcards.name: guardian
flashcards.definition: [ˈgɑ:diən] ## n. someone or something that washes or protects something     ## 43 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## He has shown through his actions that he regards his role as that of a guardian of the public interest in the purest sense.

flashcards.name: guile
flashcards.definition: [gaɪl] ## n. deceitful cunning    ## deviousness ##  ## He kept in touch with his friend, seeing him as a kind of career counsellor and, not without guile, as a potential source.

flashcards.name: hail
flashcards.definition: [heɪl] ## v. to greet with enthusiastic approval    ## acclaim ##  ## It is not unusual for American eduction leaders to hold up another nation as a model for school reform: in the mid-nineteenth century, such figures hailed the professionalism and structure of the Prussian school system.

flashcards.name: half-formulated
flashcards.definition: [hɑ:f ˈfɔ:mjuleɪted] ## adj.      ##  ## Partly because of Lee’s skill at synthesizing emergent trends drawn from many fields of study, her theories appeared to present, with uncanny aptness, ideas already half-formulated in the minds of her contemporaries.

flashcards.name: halfhearted
flashcards.definition: ['hɑ:f'hɑ:tɪd] ## adj. feeling or showing a lack of interest or enthusiasm      ## tepid, lukewarm ##  ## It was a halfhearted attempt at Obamacare reform, it was no interest really on the infrastructure—they’ll do a very standard Republican version of taxes.

flashcards.name: hallmark
flashcards.definition: [ˈhɔ:lmɑ:k] ## n. a quality, ability, etc., that is typical of a particular person or thing    ##  ## Fulfilling a promise that was a hallmark of his campaign, President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that on Day One of his Administration he would create jobs for two unskilled white males.

flashcards.name: hallow
flashcards.definition: ['hæləʊ] ## v. to respect greatly      ## respect ##  ## The global appeal of the novel has led some fans to hallow it as a classic, but, with all due respect, it is not to be confused with “Madame Bovary.”

flashcards.name: hamper
flashcards.definition: [ˈhæmpə] ## v. to slow the movement, progress, or action of    ## impede ##  ## Obama made it clear that the kind of hacking ”that could hamper vote counting, affect the actual election process itself” was his most urgent concern.

flashcards.name: hamstring
flashcards.definition: [ˈhæmstrɪŋ] ## v. to damage or ruin the force or effectiveness of       ## impair ##  ## Observers may be reminded of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell’s use of legislative tactics to hamstring Barack Obama’s Presidency.

flashcards.name: haphazard
flashcards.definition: [hæpˈhæzəd] ## adj. having no plan, order, or direction     ## random, helter-skelter ##  ## Shot by shot, line by line, moment by moment, Varda rescues the vitality and the beauty of the incidental, the haphazard, the easily overlooked—because she fills each detail with the ardent energy of her own exquisite sensibility.

flashcards.name: harmonize
flashcards.definition: ['hɑːmənaɪz] ## v. to bring into consonance or accord     ##  ## To me, this suffusion of language and light is like a chorus, because the scrolling words must harmonize with light, or push up against it.

flashcards.name: harsh
flashcards.definition: [hɑ:ʃ] ## (1)adj. having a coarse uneven surface that is rough or unpleasant to the touch      ## (2)adj. unduly exacting      ## (3)adj. severe or cruel     ##  ## The President-elect’s cabinet appointments speak to a harsh reality: this is an anti-science Administration.

flashcards.name: hasty
flashcards.definition: [ˈheɪsti] ## adj. fast and typically superficial         ## impulsive, rapid ##  ## You can see the decline in the once charming wooden structures that have needed a coat of paint for a long time, in the closed storefronts, and in the hasty and unlovely fixes to shops on the town’s main streets.

flashcards.name: heartless
flashcards.definition: [ˈhɑ:tləs] ## adj. very cruel     ## callous ##  ## “I might be accused of being heartless for saying this, but this person should be thrown out on the street,” he said.

flashcards.name: hedge
flashcards.definition: [hedʒ] ## v. to avoid giving a promise or direct answer    ##  ## As he has matured as a scholar, Felmar has come to see the merit of qualification. His conclusions, which early in his career he stated as absolutes, are now often hedged.

flashcards.name: heed
flashcards.definition: [hid] ## v. to pay attention to       ##  ## What else is there to do but listen and heed them when they shout

flashcards.name: helter-skelter
flashcards.definition: [ˌheltə ˈskeltə] ## adj. marked by a lack of order or plan     ## haphazard ## 44 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Clinton’s delivery of these ideas has become more effective, and Trump’s growing list of helter-skelter propositions and daily jolts of inspiration have helped enormously, like a hot-air balloon lifting her up.

flashcards.name: heterodox
flashcards.definition: ['hetərəʊdɒks] ## adj. not agreeing with established beliefs or standards     ## iconoclastic ##  ## It attempts to show, through prodigious but lightly worn scholarship, how complex and heterodox the Indian past was, and how it has been, and continues to be, constructed.

flashcards.name: heterogeneous
flashcards.definition: [ˌhetərəˈdʒi:niəs] ## adj. made up of parts that are different       ## disparate, dissimilar ##  ## Emily is the living embodiment of the joy of the heterogeneous family, the virtues of exogamy—and her parents’ idiosyncratic temperaments lend Emily substance that the character’s own actions and words never demonstrate.

flashcards.name: hew to
flashcards.definition: [hjuː] ## phrase.    ## conform to ##  ## Many scholars have argued that the United States Supreme Court usually hews to public opinion in its decisions because it fears that it will lose public support if does not; when it does depart from public opinion, it whips up political maelstroms.

flashcards.name: hidebound
flashcards.definition: ['haɪdbaʊnd] ## adj. not willing to accept new or different ideas       ##  ## Driving his Audi while gesticulating emphatically with both hands, he struck me as a bit of an Ahab-like madman, and therefore the right person to revolutionize the hidebound American orchestra.

flashcards.name: hierarchical
flashcards.definition: [ˌhaɪəˈrɑ:kɪkl] ## adj. of, relating to, or arranged in a hierarchy       ## stratified ##  ## Men and women are closer to each other in size than are the famously peaceful, and non-hierarchical, male and female bonobos.

flashcards.name: high-minded
flashcards.definition: [hai ˈmaindid] ## adj. having strong moral principles     ##  ## We must not question the good Lord” is raw, uncut doctrine, demanding and unrelenting, uninterested in academic theory or high-minded religious talk, and leaves a wall around the mind, especially to a generation taught to question everything.

flashcards.name: hinder
flashcards.definition: [ˈhɪndə] ## v. to make slow or difficult    ## stymie, inhibit, block ##  ## Claims about “the national interest” often hinder science in its pursuit of its most important goal: the unfettered and open questioning of even our most fundamental assumptions about reality.

flashcards.name: hitch
flashcards.definition: [hɪtʃ] ## n. a hidden problem that makes something more complicated or difficult to do    ## snag ##  ## A federal agency, U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, granted her permission for the trip, but there was a technical hitch.

flashcards.name: hodgepodge
flashcards.definition: [ˈhɒdʒpɒdʒ] ## n. a mixture of different things     ## patchwork, welter, pastiche ##  ## This début short-story collection moves through a hodgepodge of settings and periods, depicting characters on the edge of society and of disaster.

flashcards.name: homogeneity
flashcards.definition: [ˌhɒmədʒəˈni:əti] ## n. the state of having identical cumulative distribution function or values ##  ## resemblance, uniform ##  ## The homogeneity amounted to a defense of identity.

flashcards.name: hone
flashcards.definition: [həʊn] ## v. to make more acute, intense, or effective       ## enhance ##  ## Confirmation hearings have given Senate Democrats, like Tim Kaine and Elizabeth Warren, a chance to hone their party’s opposition message.

flashcards.name: honor
flashcards.definition: ['ɒnə] ## (1)n. respect that is given to someone who is admired     (2)v. to regard or treat with respect and admiration    ## venerate ##  ## Girls are born only to stay at home and to bring honor to the family by following family traditions, but Qandeel had never done that.

flashcards.name: hortatory
flashcards.definition: ['hɔ:tətərɪ] ## adj. hortative, exhortatory     ##  ## When depicting his main characters’ inner turmoil, Richardson moves well beyond his hortatory preoccupations.

flashcards.name: hubris
flashcards.definition: [ˈhju:brɪs] ## n. a great or foolish amount of pride or confidence      ## arrogance ##  ## They were movies that, in their exuberant exaggerations, wore their own absurdity with a fiercely straight face, even as they touched on underlying terrors—largely also focussed on the hubris of recklessly manipulating nature.

flashcards.name: humdrum
flashcards.definition: ['hʌmdrʌm] ## adj. dull, boring, and ordinary         ## dull ##  ## Benyamina had enlivened a mostly humdrum conversation by once again invoking her clitoris. ## 45 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: humility
flashcards.definition: [hju:ˈmɪləti] ## n. the quality or state of not thinking you are better than other people     ## modesty ##  ## There were artifacts illustrating that we want our leaders to inspire us but to express personal humility, paying respect to the citizens and the office, and artifacts illustrating how we then glorify those ideals, with music, with ceremony, with architecture.

flashcards.name: hyperbole
flashcards.definition: [haɪˈpɜ:bəli] ## n. language that describes something as better or worse than it really is ##  ## exaggeration ##  ## It reflects perfectly the American predisposition toward hyperbole under duress.

flashcards.name: hypocrisy
flashcards.definition: [hɪˈpɒkrəsi] ## n. a feigning to be what one is not or to believe what one does not    ## mendacity, insincerity ##  ## I think these discrepancies, which could be labelled hypocrisy, actually make people complex and endearing.

flashcards.name: iconoclast
flashcards.definition: [aɪˈkɒnəklæst] ## n. a person who criticizes or opposes beliefs and practices that are widely accepted      ##  ## Kid Rock has self-styled as a patriotic iconoclast, a rebel cowboy on a rampage against anything effete, élite, or soft.

flashcards.name: idealistic
flashcards.definition: [ˌaɪdiəˈlɪstɪk] ## adj. of or relating to idealists or idealism     ## quixotic ##  ## It is one of the great ironies of modern American politics that the candidate who most closely followed the advice of the Reformicons, a group of young and idealistic intellectuals, was Donald Trump, an authoritarian bigot.

flashcards.name: ideologue
flashcards.definition: ['aɪdɪəlɔɡ] ## n. someone who very strongly supports and is guided by the ideology of a particular group            ## zealot ##  ## He is not a conservative ideologue—he is pro-choice, a moderate on gun control, and anti-death penalty—and he is well-liked by reporters.

flashcards.name: ignorance
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪgnərəns] ## n. a lack of knowledge, understanding, or education    ## unfamiliarity ##  ## There was a lot that he didn’t know about robbing banks, and every moment was another opportunity to reveal his ignorance.

flashcards.name: illusory
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈlu:səri] ## adj. base one something that is not true or real     ##  ## None of these approaches has eradicated terrorism, a goal that is arguably illusory.

flashcards.name: imbibe
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈbaɪb] ## (1)v. to drink alcohol     ## (2)v. to receive into the mind and retain       ## quaff ##  ## As unappealing as a leafy Tostitos lime cocktail with hints of S.P.F. 50 may sound, this Bar Tabber managed to imbibe some winning drinks in the line of duty in 2015.

flashcards.name: imitate
flashcards.definition: ['ɪmɪtet] ## v. to follow as a pattern, model, or example    ## emulate ##  ## The editing and cinematography seem to imitate memory, in that the snapshots contain actions and visions at once fleeting and everlasting.

flashcards.name: immaterial
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪməˈtɪəriəl] ## adj. not important or significant      ## inconsequential ##  ## LoVid also performs; at the opening, Hinkis and Lapidus played synth music in costume to launch their new online work, “Young Antiquities,” a collection of intricate immaterial sculptures, spinning in virtual space.

flashcards.name: immense
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈmens] ## adj. very great in size or amount     ## colossal ##  ## A recent memorial for the choreographer paid tribute to a dancer of immense wit, courage, and nonchalant elegance.

flashcards.name: imminent
flashcards.definition: ['ɪmɪnənt] ## adj. happening very soon       ##  ## Trump supporters celebrated the imminent loss of their health insurance.

flashcards.name: immortality
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪmɔ:ˈtæləti] ## n. the quality or state of someone or something that will never die or be forgotten    ##  ## A viral multimedia project written by Jon Bois, of SB Nation, combines text, YouTube videos, and eerie graphics to explore sports, boredom, and immortality in the year 17776.

flashcards.name: immutable
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈmju:təbl] ## adj. unable to be changed       ##  ## Sex, like race, is an immutable characteristic determined solely by the accident of birth. ## 46 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: impair
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpeə] ## v. to make weaker or worse    ## hamstring, undermine, vitiate, compromise, undercut ##  ## Many parents worry that “screen time” will impair children’s development, but recent research suggests that most of the common fears about children and screens are unfounded.

flashcards.name: impartial
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpɑ:ʃl] ## adj. treating all people and groups equally     ## evenhanded, disinterested, fair, detachment ##  ## He added that the failure of previous Administrations to enforce immigration laws “has put our nation at risk of crime, violence, and terrorism,” and that it was his job to strengthen “the impartial rule of law.”

flashcards.name: impassioned
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpæʃnd] ## adj. showing or feeling very strong emotions     ## fiery ##  ## Last Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a lengthy and impassioned speech on Israel and Palestine that will go down as a major moment in American Middle East diplomacy.

flashcards.name: impassive
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpæsɪv] ## adj. not showing emotion     ##  ## An arrestingly creepy feature of many images is the discord between a dreamer’s impassive expression and her predicament: she is literally not awake to its horror.

flashcards.name: impecunious
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪmpɪˈkju:niəs] ## adj. having little or no money     ## indigent ##  ## He has set aside his matrimonial scruples long enough to have fathered a son with “an impecunious Spanish widow” whom he does not love

flashcards.name: impede
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpi:d] ## v. to slow the movement, progress, or action of    ## hamper ##  ## If Russia were to impede the flow of natural gas to the Baltic nations, their economies would tumble, which is the reason that Lithuania built a floating liquefied-natural-gas terminal off its coast, in 2014, and recently signed its first deal to buy natural gas from the United States.

flashcards.name: impenetrable
flashcards.definition: [ɪm'penɪtrəbl] ## adj. impossible to understand       ##  ## College friend groups form as ad-hoc families, so why wouldn’t they harbor family-type pathologies—rivalries, jealousies, impenetrable behavioral codes?

flashcards.name: imperceptible
flashcards.definition: [ɪmpə'septɪbl] ## adj. impossible to see or notice       ## gradual ##  ## He is known for the work he made in the Democratic Republic of the Congo using Kodak Aerochrome infrared film, which records light from parts of the spectrum imperceptible to the human eye.

flashcards.name: impermanent
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpɜ:mənənt] ## adj. not lasting forever     ##  ## His game-changing shows remind us that ours is an impermanent and fragile world.

flashcards.name: impetuous
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpetʃuəs] ## adj. acting or done quickly and without thought     ## precipitate ##  ## Ray (Richard Pryor) is a small-time gambling boss who adopts a hot-headed orphan who, as Ray comes up in the world, grows up to be his right-hand man, an impetuous trouble-maker nicknamed Quick (played by Murphy).

flashcards.name: implacable
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈplækəbl] ## adj. opposed to someone or something in a very angry or determined way that cannot be changed       ## unyielding, inexorable ##  ## Chris’s fierce efforts at self-liberation, and a self-image that’s deeply imbued with the memory of violence, make for a rhapsodic, visionary, yet harshly implacable drama.

flashcards.name: implement
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪmplɪment] ## v. to begin to do or use    ##  ## Customs and Border Protection is tasked with implementing the travel ban at the nation’s points of entry.

flashcards.name: impolitic
flashcards.definition: [ɪm'pɒlɪtɪk] ## adj. unwise      ## tactless ##  ## Stephens would play passively or press too hard, and then face the media—which was quick to make much of her impolitic comments—with a scowl.

flashcards.name: import
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪmpɔ:t] ## n. importance     ##  ## From sentence to story, she narrates with great skill and deliberation, so that the reader soon relaxes in the assurance that a hint or a brushstroke delivered in chapter 1 will be given import before the novel comes to an end.

flashcards.name: impotent
flashcards.definition: ['ɪmpətənt] ## adj. lacking power or strength         ##  ## Psychological name-calling is an impotent avoidance of our responsibility as citizens, and it represents a failure to try to get insight into us, which is much more important. ## 47 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: impressive
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpresɪv] ## adj. deserving attention, admiration, or respect             ##  ## In an official statement announcing the new world record, the White House called Trump’s second unconstitutional ban “especially impressive” because it came only thirty-eight days after his first.

flashcards.name: improvise
flashcards.definition: ['ɪmprəvaɪz] ## v. to speak or perform without preparation      ##  ## He and his photo assistant, Victoria Gonzalez-Figueras, who is also his wife, were forced to improvise a makeshift flash system using flashlights and duct tape.

flashcards.name: impudent
flashcards.definition: ['ɪmpjʊdənt] ## adj. failing to show proper respect and courtesy       ##  ## On Sunday, Dmitry Kiselev, the most bombastic and colorful of Kremlin propagandists, warned on his weekly newsmagazine show that “impudent behavior' toward Russia may have “nuclear” consequences.

flashcards.name: impugn
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpju:n] ## v. to assail by words or argument    ##  ## Perhaps his aides would have a clearer way of describing the man they are now trying to impugn.

flashcards.name: impulsive
flashcards.definition: [ɪmˈpʌlsɪv] ## adj. done suddenly and without planning     ## capricious, hasty ##  ## The worrying thing about Trump is that his impulsiveness is combined with authoritarian instincts and, according to some accounts, an unhealthy interest in populist dictators.

flashcards.name: inaccessible
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnækˈsesəbl] ## adj. difficult or impossible to reach, approach, or understand              ## opaque ##  ## Last year, you published a novel, “The Girls,” that centered on a teen-ager’s perspective; the adults and their mind-sets are viewed as nearly inaccessible.

flashcards.name: inadequate
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈædɪkwət] ## adj. not enough or not good enough     ##  ## The politicians who are the most incensed about the issue are also interested in using the episode as a way to strengthen the federal government’s woefully inadequate commitment to open-records laws.

flashcards.name: inborn
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnˈbɔ:n] ## adj. existing from the time someone is born     ##  ## French women have an inborn talent for recognizing quality and buying things that last.

flashcards.name: inception
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈsepʃn] ## adj. the time at which something begins    ## foundation ##  ## They were made, in short, by the force that has been at the heart of the national experience since the country’s inception, and that drives the national legend still.

flashcards.name: inclined
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'klaɪnd] ## adj. wanting to do something or likely to do something    ...  ##  ## In the background was London—a city of disease and murders, and perfect material for a mind inclined toward the gothic.

flashcards.name: inclusive
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈklu:sɪv] ## (1)adj. covering or including everything       ## (2)adj. including the stated limits and everything in between          ## generic, all- encompassing ##  ## One may get a sense of its scope and inclusiveness—its supermarket-ness—in the way that the Office of Personnel Management, which administers the program, explains it to federal employees.

flashcards.name: incommensurable
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnkəˈmenʃərəbl] ## adj. not commensurable broadly       ##  ## The moderation, the curiosity, the practical political concerns that inhabit “The Memory of Justice” make it seem much nearer at hand than Lanzmann’s film, which is unassimilable, incommensurable—and definitive.

flashcards.name: incomprehensible
flashcards.definition: [ɪn,kɑmprɪ'hɛnsəbl] ## adj. impossible to understand     ## inexplicable ##  ## Obama’s inaction is as incomprehensible as it is reprehensible, especially considering that the Obama Administration had several months to respond before the election, and that it was plain that Russian hacking was undermining the democratic process.

flashcards.name: incongruity
flashcards.definition: [,ɪnkɑŋ'grʊəti] ## n. something that is incongruous    ## discrepancy ##  ## In Wieland’s photos, though, pet owners are only offscreen presences; it’s the animals themselves, and the sometimes unsettling incongruity of their urban life styles, that captures his attention.

flashcards.name: inconsequential
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˌkɒnsɪˈkwenʃl] ## adj. not important      ## trivial, immaterial ##  ## As Donald Trump has attempted to become more specific about his economic proposals, Hillary Clinton’s inconsistencies seem inconsequential by comparison.

flashcards.name: inconsistent
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnkənˈsɪstənt] ## adj. not compatible with another fact or claim          ## mixed ## 48 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The approach of the United States has been inconsistent, and changed from President to President.

flashcards.name: inconstant
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈkɒnstənt] ## adj. likely to change frequently without apparent for cogent reason      ##  ## Leadership may be, by its nature, an anxious and inconstant idea. Like “status” or “alienation,” the word “leadership” points not toward a stable concept but toward a problem or affliction unique to modernity.

flashcards.name: incorporate
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈkɔ:pəreɪt] ## (1)v. to include as part of something else     (2)v. to blend or combine    ##  ## It treats perfectly competitive markets as special cases rather than the norm, trying to incorporate from the very beginning the progress economists have made during the past forty years or so in analyzing more complex situations

flashcards.name: incursion
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈkɜ:ʃn] ## n. a sudden invasion or attack    ##  ## Rangely is a conservative town, but it has welcomed the incursion of avant-gardists bearing didgeridoos, and some of the most dedicated sonic tinkerers are locals.

flashcards.name: indebted
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'detɪd] ## adj. owing gratitude or recognition to another     ## beholden ##  ## A blogger got it for free and thought it was just O.K. but felt indebted to the publicist who sent it to her, so she said something nice about it.

flashcards.name: indecorous
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'dekərəs] ## adj. conflicting with accepted standards of good conduct or good taste ##  ##  ## It was a little indecorous, perhaps, to hail Isabelle Huppert, the grandest of dames and the nominated star of “Elle,” by dissing the existence of her movie—“Nobody saw it, but we loved it,” Kimmel said.

flashcards.name: indict
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdaɪt] ## v. to charge with a fault or offense    ## excoriate ##  ## Israeli law prohibits public representatives from receiving any gift that isn’t “of small value and reasonable in context,” a somewhat ambiguous clause that will no doubt play a role in the Attorney General’s weighing of a potential indictment.

flashcards.name: indifferent
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdɪfrənt] ## (1)adj. not interested in or concerned about something      (2)adj. marked by impartiality     ## apathy ##  ## Nicolas Cage and Willem Dafoe as coldly indifferent, and mediocre, criminals, in Paul Schrader’s new film, “Dog Eat Dog.”

flashcards.name: indigent
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪndɪdʒənt] ## adj. very poor     ## impecunious ##  ## The bill passed on Thursday includes a substantial tax cut for the rich, financed by big cuts in Medicaid, the federal program that provides health care to the poor and indigent.

flashcards.name: indiscernible
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪndɪˈsɜ:nəbl] ## adj. impossible to see, hear, or know clearly       ## imperceptible ##  ## The process is so gradual as to be nearly indiscernible, and watching it is rather like watching a flower open.

flashcards.name: indiscriminate
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪndɪsˈkrɪmɪnət] ## (1)affecting or harming many people or things in a careless or unfair way      ## (2)not careful in making choices     ##  ## The Times reviewer, Howard Taubman, condescended approvingly to the show, calling it “a wild, indiscriminate explosion of exuberant, impertinent youthful talents.”

flashcards.name: indispensable
flashcards.definition: [ɪndɪ'spensəbl] ## adj. extremely important and necessary       ## essential, crucial ##  ## The jazz guitarist and banjoist Danny Barker is said to have appeared on more than a thousand recordings. He’s also responsible for one of the most indispensable accounts of the music’s early days.

flashcards.name: indubitable
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'djuːbɪtəbl] ## adj. too evident to be doubted       ## incontrovertible ##  ## Smith’s post-9/11 Bush is both doubt-free and indubitable, a man who effected the “personalization of the war on terror” and of Presidential power in general.

flashcards.name: induce
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'dus] ## v. to cause to do something    ## engender ##  ## Republican and Democratic Administrations alike have coaxed and cajoled, prodded and praised, and, most recently, confronted and condemned the Assads to induce policy changes.

flashcards.name: industrious
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdʌstriəs] ## adj. working very hard     ## diligent ##  ## Sunk in sloth, the narrator seeks redemption through marriage to a smart, industrious woman. ## 49 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: inert
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈnɜ:t] ## (1)adj. unable to move       (2)adj. very slow to move or act     ##  ## On “Sleep Well Beast,” the band seems to be reckoning with how inert and immovable feelings of regret and longing are.

flashcards.name: inevitable
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈevɪtəbl] ## adj. sure to happen     ## unavoidable, preordained, ineluctable ##  ## Errors are inevitable: even a competent and well-trained pilot will, eventually, glance at a lever in the “On” position and think that it is actually “Off.”

flashcards.name: inexplicable
flashcards.definition: [,ɪnɪk'splɪkəbl] ## adj. not able to be explained or understand     ## incomprehensible ##  ## Although an inexplicable illness afflicting millions of Americans is a cause for concern, the C.D.C. spokesman urged people to remain calm.

flashcards.name: infallibility
flashcards.definition: [in,fælə'biləti] ## n. incapable of error     ##  ## The combination of free-form opportunism, heroic self-regard, blithe contempt for expertise, and an airy sense of infallibility has contributed to Trump’s profound estrangement from the truth.

flashcards.name: infectious
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈfekʃəs] ## (1)adj. capable of causing infection       ## (2)adj. spreading or capable of spreading rapidly to others       ##  ## In honor of the Women’s March on Washington, Fiona Apple released a blunt and infectious chant to protest Donald Trump.

flashcards.name: inferable from
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'fɜ:rəbl] [frəm] ## phrase.   ...    ## entailed by ##  ## In the absence of a surface gradient, the new laws of refraction and reflection are inferable from the conventional law, so they represent more of an extension than a complete revolution.

flashcards.name: inflammatory
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈflæmətri] ## adj. causing anger      ## provocative ##  ## Coming a day after the horrific attack in Orlando, the address that he delivered in Goffstown, New Hampshire, on Monday afternoon was misleading, malevolent, and inflammatory.

flashcards.name: inflate
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈfleɪt] ## (1)v. to swell or distend with air or gas      ## (2)v. to think or say that is larger or more important than it really is    ##  ## While our crew members are sparring with neighboring passengers, you can inflate the life vest and wrap it around your head for protection when it is your turn to throw some punches.

flashcards.name: informative
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈfɔ:mətɪv] ## adj. providing information       ##  ## There is no single test that provides a conclusive diagnosis of white guilt, but a combination of the following tests can be informative.

flashcards.name: ingenuous
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈdʒenjuəs] ## (1)adj. showing innocent or childlike simplicity and candidness      (2)adj. lacking craft or subtlety     ##  ## The moment could have seemed smarmy, but it read as sweetly ingenuous—a tone that suffused the rest of his performance.

flashcards.name: inherent
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈhɪərənt] ## adj. belonging to the basic nature of someone or something     ##  ## “There’s drama inherent in every pitch,” Mark Ulriksen, the artist behind this week's cover, says, about the baseball season.

flashcards.name: inhibit
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'hɪbɪt] ## v. to keep from doing what he or she wants to do       ## hinder, bridle, suppress ##  ## Smoking is not permitted on any United flight because cigarettes inhibit your body’s ability to access enough oxygen to keep you in top fighting form for in-flight physical altercations.

flashcards.name: inimical
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈnɪmɪkl] ## (1)adj. likely to cause damage or have a bad effect      (2)adj. not friendly      ## antagonistic, deleterious ##  ## The environment itself—gravity, air, solidity or the lack of it, et cetera—is what is somehow wrong: ill-matched to the body’s abilities, inimical to its verticality, stability, or mobility.

flashcards.name: innate
flashcards.definition: [ɪ'neɪt] ## adj. existing from the time a person or animal is born     ## inborn ##  ## Was it Donald Trump’s innate political talent that got him this far, or the competition posed by the remnants of a pitiably weak party?

flashcards.name: innocuous
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈnɒkjuəs] ## (1)adj. causing no injury      ## (2)adj. not likely to bother or offend anyone       ## harmless, benign, inoffensive ## 50 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## There was a book on my parents’ shelves, which they, like most people, probably thought was pretty innocuous because of the anodyne takes that Disney wafted into the world.

flashcards.name: innovative
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪnəveɪtɪv] ## adj. introducing or using new ideas or methods     ## experimental ##  ## If the French Ministry of Culture were to hold hearings on why there are so few innovative young French filmmakers today.

flashcards.name: insatiable
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'seɪʃəbl] ## adj. always wanting more      ## voracious, quenchless ##  ## For Sade, she was an exotic “other,” a figure of insatiable sexual appetite and unspeakable savagery.

flashcards.name: inscrutable
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈskru:təbl] ## adj. difficult to understand       ## uninformative, impenetrable, abstruse ##  ## There may be other baseball players with something close to Bartolo Colón’s age or his girth. But none possesses his inscrutable Zen equanimity.

flashcards.name: insightful
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪnsaɪtfʊl] ## adj. having or showing a very clear understanding of something        ##  ## The portrait of Emily—and the vision of silent rapture shared only in a rare friendship and in work delivered to an uncertain, and often a cruel, reception—is not only a powerfully insightful and shatteringly empathetic bio-pic of a beautiful and tormented soul.

flashcards.name: insipid
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈsɪpɪd] ## adj. not interesting or exciting       ## bland ##  ## Body-bound as his figures often seem to be, Michelangelo had a matchless gift for creating faces that look intelligent without being insipid.

flashcards.name: inspire
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈspaɪə] ## (1)v. to cause to happen or be created      ## (2)v. to cause someone to have (a feeling or emotion)       ##  ## A theme of the night, inspired by life in 2017, was the John Cale lyric “Fear is a man’s best friend.”

flashcards.name: insufferable
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈsʌfrəbl] ## adj. not to be endured: intolerable       ##  ## I had just married my college boyfriend, a man who definitely thought his family was better than mine. I was proud, and insecure, and insufferable.

flashcards.name: insufficient
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnsəˈfɪʃnt] ## adj. not having or providing enough of what is needed      ## meager ##  ## This chronicle of the refugee crisis—since 2014, more than a million people from Africa, the Middle East, and beyond have tried to reach Europe—argues that it is largely a manufactured disaster, the result of insufficient political will.

flashcards.name: insular
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪnsjələ] ## adj. separated from other people or cultures     ## provincial, private ##  ## That realization inspired me to write a story about the closed and insular world of boarding school, and about the choices that teen-agers can make in the arrogant belief that they know everything.

flashcards.name: insulate
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪnsjuleɪt] ## v. to keep separate from something unpleasant, dangerous, etc.               ##  ## Once it became clear that Mirzakhani would come, Daubechies and a number of other distinguished women mathematicians devised a plan to insulate her.

flashcards.name: intelligible
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtelɪdʒəbl] ## adj. able to be understood      ## readable ##  ## Then there’s the fact that “The Good Fight,” like its predecessor, takes place in an intelligent and intelligible world—a world of systems, institutions, and incentives in which the smartest and most farsighted survive.

flashcards.name: intensity
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtensəti] ## n. the degree or amount of strength or force that something has    ##  ## It has become almost a cliché of basketball fandom to appreciate the ferocious intensity and reckless control of the Oklahoma City Thunder’s Russell Westbrook.

flashcards.name: interchangeable
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪntəˈtʃeɪndʒəbl] ## adj. capable of being used in place of each other      ## fungible ##  ## The most striking part of the report on Baltimore is the extent to which it is interchangeable with the reports on race and policing that have come out of Chicago, Cleveland, Ferguson, and Newark in the past two years.

flashcards.name: interdependent
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪntədɪˈpendənt] ## adj. depending on each other       ## interrelated ##  ## In these episodes, the characters’ interdependent narcissism generally becomes unwieldy.

flashcards.name: interrelated
flashcards.definition: [,ɪntərɪ'leɪtɪd] ## adj. having a mutual or reciprocal relation       ## interdependent ## 51 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## At the time of his speech at Riverside Church, King had come to see war, poverty, and racism as interrelated; taking on one necessarily meant confronting the others.

flashcards.name: interweave
