flashcards.definition: [ɪntə'wiːv] ## v. to twist or weave together    ##  ## The filmmakers interweave tales of local life with wider historical elements.

flashcards.name: intimate
flashcards.definition: ['ɪntɪmət] ## (1)adj. having a very close relationship      (2)v. to say or suggest in an indirect way    ##  ## Antifa activists don’t often speak to the media, but Bray is a former Occupy Wall Street organizer and an avowed leftist; he has intimate access to his subjects, if not much critical distance from them.

flashcards.name: intransigent
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtrænsɪdʒənt] ## adj. completely unwilling to change      ## obdurate, resolute ##  ## When the building—the Whitney’s third home—first opened, in 1966, Marcel Breuer’s gloriously intransigent upside-down ziggurat, made of granite-clad concrete, proved controversial.

flashcards.name: intricate
flashcards.definition: [ˈɪntrɪkət] ## adj. having many parts       ## convoluted ##  ## In his fiction, Énard is constructing an intricate, history-rich vision of a persistently misunderstood part of the world.

flashcards.name: intrinsic
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtrɪnsɪk] ## adj. belonging to the essential nature of a thing     ## inherent ##  ## As we in the United States have lately had occasion to remember, humor is often intrinsic to political protest—funny signs and chants, illustrations and effigies of the leader under scorn.

flashcards.name: intuitive
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈtju:ɪtɪv] ## adj. agreeing with what seems naturally right      ## spontaneous ##  ## I am fairly intuitive in my writing, and I feel that the clues to how each story should be written lie within the idea for the story itself.

flashcards.name: invalidate
flashcards.definition: [ɪnˈvælɪdeɪt] ## (1)v. to weaken or destroy the effect of      ## (2)v. to show or prove to be false or incorrect   ...   ##  ## Lynch’s Justice Department filed a lawsuit to invalidate North Carolina’s “bathroom law.”

flashcards.name: invention
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'venʃən] ## n. product of the imagination    ##  ## Invention was a hallmark of the work of the ancient Greek historians, whose writings were filled with long and often purely fictitious speeches by great historical figures.

flashcards.name: inverse
flashcards.definition: [ˌɪnˈvɜ:s] ## (1)adj. opposite in nature or effect      ## (2)n. something that is the opposite of something else               ##  ## Since the election, the value of the peso, which is widely seen as an inverse indicator of the Administration’s protectionist intent, has risen sharply.

flashcards.name: involved
flashcards.definition: [ɪn'vɒlvd] ## adj. very complicated     ##  ## A misconception frequently held by novice writers is that sentence structure mirrors thought: the more convoluted the structure, the more involved the ideas.

flashcards.name: irascible
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈræsəbl] ## adj. becoming angry very easily     ## exasperation ##  ## We talked to Clowes about the conception of the original book, the making of the movie adaptation, and the travails of his irascible anti-hero across the page and the screen.

flashcards.name: irenic
flashcards.definition: [aɪ'ri:nɪk] ## adj. favoring, conducive to, or operating toward peace, moderation, or conciliation       ##  ## Several irenic uses for the base have already been suggested. These include converting it into a research center for tropical diseases and turning it into a medical school.

flashcards.name: irksome
flashcards.definition: ['ɜːksəm] ## adj. annoying or irritating     ##  ## Reading that second line, I immediately thought of an irksome scene in Megyn Kelly’s memoir.

flashcards.name: ironic
flashcards.definition: [aɪˈrɒnɪk] ## adj. using words that mean the opposite of what you really think especially in order to be funny     ## paradoxical ##  ## S. Y. Agnon’s exquisite ironic fiction examined traditional Jewish life through a twentieth-century lens.

flashcards.name: irrefutable
flashcards.definition: ['ɪrɪ'fjʊtəbl] ## adj. not able to be proved wrong       ## undeniable ##  ## The logic seems irrefutable. ## 52 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: irreparable
flashcards.definition: [ɪˈrepərəbl] ## adj. too bad to be corrected or repaired       ##  ## Like Khrushchev, Putin in Syria was forced to take a step back, so as to avoid irreparable damage and to preserve hope that things will improve in the future.

flashcards.name: irresistible
flashcards.definition: [ɪrɪ'zɪstɪbl] ## adj. impossible to resist especially because of strength or attractiveness ##  ##  ## For some reptile enthusiasts, known as herpers, the draw of an illegal snake can be irresistible.

flashcards.name: irresolution
flashcards.definition: [ɪˌrezə'lu:ʃn] ## n. the state of not being certain about what to do      ## vacillation ##  ## Spicer said the White House condemned the attack, but told reporters that “these heinous actions by the Bashar al-Assad regime are a consequence of the last Administration’s weakness and irresolution.”

flashcards.name: isolationism
flashcards.definition: [ˌaɪsəˈleɪʃənɪzəm] ## n. the belief that a country should not be involved with other counties       ##  ## While the Conservatives kept a low profile, the new debates over nativism and isolationism receded, and Corbyn was able to campaign against older enemies: austerity, privatization, and the gap between the rich and poor.

flashcards.name: itinerant
flashcards.definition: [aɪˈtɪnərənt] ## adj. traveling from place to place         ## peripatetic ##  ## The song’s wistfulness brings to mind an image of the rapper that went viral last year in which, astride a horse in downtown Atlanta, he looked like some itinerant, storybook hero.

flashcards.name: jarring
flashcards.definition: ['dʒɑ:ɪŋ] ## adj.          ##  ## The idea of a “language instinct” may seem jarring to those who think of language as the zenith of the human intellect and of instincts as brute impulses.

flashcards.name: jealous
flashcards.definition: ['dʒeləs] ## adj. hostile toward a rival or one believed to enjoy an advantage     ##  ## Twitter is a beautiful, magical bird trapped in the body of a Web site by a jealous underworld demigod.

flashcards.name: jejune
flashcards.definition: [dʒɪˈdʒu:n] ## (1)adj. not interesting      (2)adj. too simple     ## vapid ##  ## Commercial novels, in general, whether they’re thrillers or romance or science fiction, employ language that is at best undistinguished and at worst characterized by a jejune mentality and a tendency to state the obvious.

flashcards.name: jettison
flashcards.definition: [ˈdʒetɪsn] ## v. to get rid of    ##  ## If anybody could isolate the truly astounding aspects of Melo’s game and convince him to jettison, or at least minimize, the rest, the Zen master could.

flashcards.name: judicious
flashcards.definition: [dʒuˈdɪʃəs] ## adj. having or showing good judgment     ##  ## The odd thing—for a group that has usually been judicious about its claims and accurate in its facts—is that it got key details wrong.

flashcards.name: justify
flashcards.definition: ['dʒʌstɪfaɪ] ## v. to prove or show to be just, right, or reasonable   ...   ##  ## The White House made several efforts to justify Trump’s claim, including using Devin Nunes, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, as a conduit for the documents, which allegedly offered some substantiation.

flashcards.name: keen
flashcards.definition: [kiːn] ## adj. very excited about and interested in something     ## eager ##  ## Wouter De Backer, known as Gotye, has a keen understanding of the electronic musician Jean-Jacques Perrey’s discography, and of the nuances it contains. ## keep abreast of ## phrase.   ...      ##  ## Given the flood of information presented by the mass media, the only way for someone to keep abreast of the news is to rely on abridged accounts

flashcards.name: kindred
flashcards.definition: ['kɪndrɪd] ## adj. alike or similar         ## affiliated ##  ## The director of “A Quiet Passion” visits the Morgan Library and considers why he sees Emily Dickinson as a kindred spirit.

flashcards.name: kinfolk
flashcards.definition: ['kɪnfəʊk] ## n. a person's relatives    ## relative ##  ## As with Al Qaeda and its Islamist extremist kinfolk, the Shabaab views all nonbelievers—or even Muslims espousing different versions of the faith—as heretics and belligerents.

flashcards.name: knotty
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɒti] ## adj. difficult or complicated         ## complicated ##  ## For weeks and months, a burgeoning-until-overwhelming majority of Americans told their senators and congressmen that they did not want Obamacare declared null and void, its knotty flaws notwithstanding. ## 53 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: laborious
flashcards.definition: [lə'bɔːrɪəs] ## adj. devoted to labor     ## arduous ##  ## The laborious process of categorizing the cucumbers had remained essentially the same for decades, until last spring, when Koike began developing a new approach.

flashcards.name: laconic
flashcards.definition: [ləˈkɒnɪk] ## adj. using few words in speech or writing     ## taciturn, terse, curt ##  ## Its rhetoric may be laconic and folksy, but its fury and its nobility seem distilled from Shakespeare

flashcards.name: lambaste
flashcards.definition: [læm'beɪst] ## v. to criticize very harshly      ## denounce ##  ## In his Sunday newsletter, the journalist Mike Allen asked if anyone had noticed “the crude, discriminating language and signs used by some to lambaste a president they condemn as crude and discriminating.

flashcards.name: languish
flashcards.definition: [ˈlæŋgwɪʃ] ## (1)v. to continue for a long time without activity or progress in an unpleasant or unwanted situation       ## (2)v. to suffer neglect     ##  ## Next weekend, Hollande, who is quitting the Élysée Palace after one term, and whose approval ratings languish in single figures, will be hopping onto his little scooter and returning to obscurity.

flashcards.name: lapse
flashcards.definition: [læps] ## (1)n. an occurrence in which you fail to think or act in the usual or proper way for a brief time and make a mistake     ## (2)n. an occurrence in which someone behaves badly or usually a short period of time       ## (3)v. to stop for usually a brief time    ##  ## The limitations of human attention cause us to miss much of what goes on around us. The real problem here is that we are often unaware of these limitations: we think that we see the world as it really is, but our ostensibly reliable visual experience belies striking mental lapses.

flashcards.name: largesse
flashcards.definition: [lɑː'dʒes] ## n. the act of giving away money or the quality of a person who gives away money    ##  ## He would gaze out over his guests, the grizzled political bosses, lawyers, judges, businessmen, journalists, boyfriends, and other recipients of his largesse, and call on them to speak.

flashcards.name: laudatory
flashcards.definition: [ˈlɔ:dətəri] ## adj. expressing or containing praise     ##  ## He is a beacon of conspicuous consumption, incessantly self-laudatory, treats beautiful women as accessories, has his name on a fashion line; the deductive leap is a small one.

flashcards.name: layperson
flashcards.definition: ['leipə:sən] ## n. a member of the laity     ## nonspecialist ##  ## To a layperson, it wouldn’t have made much sense, but to sophisticated Wall Street traders it meant that the information about Dell’s as yet nonpublic earnings had come from someone inside the company who had provided valuable information in the past.

flashcards.name: legitimate
flashcards.definition: [lɪ'dʒɪtɪmət] ## adj. allowed according to rules or laws     ##  ## Legitimate questioning of how we measure and what we measure is not only defensible; it’s imperative.

flashcards.name: lethargic
flashcards.definition: [lə'θɑ:dʒɪk] ## adj. feeling a lack of energy or a lack of interest in doing things        ## somnolent, slumberous ##  ## There is occasionally something proud, almost, in Gay’s lethargic prose, as if to focus on language would be beside the point.

flashcards.name: liberation
flashcards.definition: [ˌlɪbə'reɪʃn] ## (1)n. the act or process of freeing someone or something from another’s control     ## (2)n. the removal of traditional social or sexual rules, attitudes, etc.    ## rejection ##  ## Over six days in late November and early December, 2016, Fatah, the Palestinian national liberation movement, convened its seventh congress in Ramallah, the de-facto capital of the Palestinian Authority.

flashcards.name: limpid
flashcards.definition: [ˈlɪmpɪd] ## adj. marked by transparency     ## pellucid ##  ## It ’s harder to breathe in the humid north, up there so close to Brazil and Paraguay, the rushing river guarded by mosquito sentinels and a sky that can turn from limpid blue to stormy black in minutes.

flashcards.name: lionize
flashcards.definition: [ˈlaɪənaɪz] ## v. to treat as a very important and famous person     ...     ## eulogize ##  ## In politics and business, we lionize leadership. But how much do we really know about what makes a great leader?

flashcards.name: list
flashcards.definition: [lɪst] ## v. to tile to one side especially of a boat of ship    ## tilt ##  ## The painter has emphasized the figure’s erect posture by making it contrast so starkly with the list exhibited by trees of the windswept orchard in the background. ## 54 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ## live up to ## phrase.        ##  ## The smallest human societies that we can identify, either among living groups or among the populations of prehistory, do not appear to live up to the image of primitive affluence that has become popular among anthropologists in the past twenty years.

flashcards.name: loath
flashcards.definition: [ləʊθ] ## adj. not wanting or willing to do something      ## reluctant, unwilling, disinclined ##  ## “I am loath to erase history.” He suggested that the statues that were removed should be grouped together in new spaces and contextualized.

flashcards.name: long-winded
flashcards.definition: ['lɔŋ'wɪndɪd] ## adj. using too many words in speaking or writing     ## verbose, prolix ##  ## We believe that, in this instance, inept texting combined with numerous long-winded tangents about what constitutes a 'low-key date spot' prevented or delayed a serious crime.

flashcards.name: loquacious
flashcards.definition: [ləˈkweɪʃəs] ## adj. liking to talk and talking smoothly and easily     ## garrulous ##  ## We also had a collection of loquacious greetings from United Nations representatives, edited down and cross-faded to make them more listenable.

flashcards.name: lowly
flashcards.definition: [ˈləʊli] ## adj. in a low position, manner, or degree     ##  ## The American photographer Emmet Gowin does for the moths of Central and South America what the influential German duo Bernd and Hilla Becher once did for the water towers of Western Europe, transforming an apparently lowly subject into riveting art.

flashcards.name: lucid
flashcards.definition: [lu:'sɪd] ## adj. very clear and easy to understand         ##  ## Walking into the reincarnation of the beloved Alphabet City bar Elsa, which closed in 2014 and reopened this spring, in Cobble Hill, is like having a lucid dream.

flashcards.name: lucrative
flashcards.definition: [ˈlu:krətɪv] ## adj. producing money or wealth       ##  ## In boxing, the right person doesn’t always win, and being hated is nearly as lucrative as being loved.

flashcards.name: ludicrous
flashcards.definition: ['ludɪkrəs] ## adj. very foolish       ## risible ##  ## It is a ludicrous situation, and one that makes a mockery of the idea of the Senate as a highfalutin deliberative body.

flashcards.name: lugubrious
flashcards.definition: [ləˈgu:briəs] ## adj. full of sadness or sorrow     ## gloomy ##  ## Paintings, prints, and statuary of the extinct beast, a lugubrious mascot, lurk everywhere you look

flashcards.name: lull
flashcards.definition: [lʌl] ## (1)v. to cause to sleep or rest      ## (2)v. to cause to feel safe and relaxed instead of careful and alert     (3)n. a brief time when an action or activity stops    ## respite ##  ## Its noises—slight splashes, fish thrashing on the bottom of a boat—threatened, several times, to lull me to sleep.

flashcards.name: luxuriant
flashcards.definition: [lʌgˈʒʊəriənt] ## (1)adj. yielding abundantly      ## (2)adj. abundantly and often extravagantly rich and varied     ## rampant ##  ## In the amber glow of Highlands, waitresses wear tartan skirts and bartenders pour cocktails with luxuriant slowness.

flashcards.name: madcap
flashcards.definition: [ˈmædkæp] ## adj. marked by capriciousness, recklessness, or foolishness          ##  ## Beneath the madcap storytelling, there is an elusive coherence: the seventeenth chapter of each book is told backward, and the last lines in all three books rhyme.

flashcards.name: maintain
flashcards.definition: [meɪnˈteɪn] ## (1)v. to cause to exist or continue without changing     (2)v. to affirm in or as if in argument    ## assert ##  ## Although its director maintains that the movie uses a documentary approach in portraying the famous sit-down strike, in practice its characters are heavily fictionalized and fall into familiar Hollywood types.

flashcards.name: malady
flashcards.definition: [ˈmælədi] ## n. a disease or illness    ##  ## For Marnell, as for Phillips, it turns out that, in the end, not even a nervous breakdown can provide a release from that very American malady: the compulsion to become a focussed, sharply whittled point of pure motion and ambition.

flashcards.name: malfeasance
flashcards.definition: [ˌmæl'fi:zəns] ## n. wrongdoing or misconduct especially by a public official    ## fraudulence ##  ## This week also brought new revelations in an unfolding scandal concerning malfeasance within Wells Fargo. ## 55 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: malignant
flashcards.definition: [mə'lɪgnənt] ## adj. aggressively malicious     ##  ## McCain’s surgery revealed a glioblastoma, an aggressively malignant brain tumor.

flashcards.name: malleable
flashcards.definition: [ˈmæliəbl] ## adj. capable of being easily changed or influenced         ## plastic ##  ## Even as the anthem settled into the American patriotic canon, it remained a malleable entity.

flashcards.name: malodorous
flashcards.definition: [ˌmælˈəʊdərəs] ## adj. having a bad smell     ## noisome ##  ## The body was decomposed and swollen almost to the point of bursting and very malodorous.

flashcards.name: manacle
flashcards.definition: ['mænəkl] ## v. to restrain from movement, progress, or action    ##  ## When Suzie produces for her guests’ delectation an actual fulminating terrorist called Mohammed (Amir Arison), he turns out to be a ghost—but not before attacking his fellow-Arab and being gang-tackled by the group, who first manacle him with napkins and then allow him a place at the table.

flashcards.name: manifest
flashcards.definition: [ˈmænɪfest] ## (1)adj. able to be seen      (2)v. to show clearly      ## reveal, self-evident, obvious ##  ## It’s always been dispiriting to see the latent resentments that Clinton’s political ambitions brought forth—she’s like one of those chemical solutions which make invisible writing manifest, only to reveal a message that we’d rather had remained hidden. ## Day 5 ## Genius only means hard-working all one's life.

flashcards.name: manipulate
flashcards.definition: [məˈnɪpjuleɪt] ## v. to use or change in a skillful way or for a particular purpose        ##  ## Gun owners, contemplating whether to re-up their forty-dollar annual memberships or hand over their credit cards for the first time, might consider the fact that they’re being manipulated.

flashcards.name: marginal
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɑ:dʒɪnl] ## (1)adj. not very important       ## (2)adj. not included in the main part of society or of a group     ## peripheral ##  ## Her photographs range from the marginal to the mainstream, capturing things that are invisible to the rest of us.

flashcards.name: marked
flashcards.definition: [mɑ:kt] ## adj. very noticeable     ##  ## According to the poll, Americans have been sleeping more, eating better, and enjoying a markedly greater sense of well-being following Conway's sudden departure.

flashcards.name: martinet
flashcards.definition: [,mɑːtɪ'net] ## n. a person who is very strict and demands obedience from others           ##  ## At first, Detective Mick Kennedy, a rule-loving martinet, and his rookie partner suspect the dead husband, a financial-industry recruiter who was laid off in the economic bust, unable to find new work, and held captive by an underwater mortgage.

flashcards.name: mask
flashcards.definition: [mɑ:sk] ## (1)v. to keep from being known or noticed     ## (2)n. a cover or partial cover for the face used for disguise    ## belie ##  ## That admission was also far more open, and far more heartfelt, than anything either prince says in “Diana, Our Mother,” where their light chat over family photos seems contrived to mask a depth of feeling.

flashcards.name: master
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɑ:stə] ## (1)n. an artist, performer, or player of consummate skill     (2)n. one having control         ## (3)v. to become skilled or proficient in the use of    ##  ## The European master Peter Eötvös’s adaptation of Tony Kushner’s play gets its New York première, at New York City Opera.

flashcards.name: match
flashcards.definition: [mætʃ] ## (1)v. to cause to correspond  ...    ## (2)v. to set in competition or opposition  ...    (3)n. an exact counterpart      ##  ## The cognitive flexibility of successful fictional detectives is often matched by their cultural ambivalence: detectives’ intellectual acumen, it seems, exists in direct proportion to their uneasy place in society.

flashcards.name: materialize
flashcards.definition: [məˈtɪəriəlaɪz] ## (1)v. to become visible     ## (2)v. to begin to happen or exist    ##  ## According to legend, the impish goblins like to materialize in dark, humid corners, mostly after dusk, and sometimes when the air moistens with rain. ##  56 ##   (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: maudlin
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɔ:dlɪn] ## adj. weakly and effusively sentimental       ## When the Los Angeles Unified School Board—“out of the graciousness of its repressive little heart”—sent him a copy of Maya Angelou’s “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” he made it through a few “maudlin” pages before he grew suspicious, he wrote.

flashcards.name: maverick
flashcards.definition: [ˈmævərɪk] ## n. a person who refuses to follow the customs or rules of a group         ## nonconformist ##  ## The centennial of the late Lou Harrison, the gentle maverick of postwar U.S. composition, will be marked by concerts in New York and California.

flashcards.name: meager
flashcards.definition: ['mi:gə] ## (1)adj. not having enough of something for comfort or happiness      (2)adj. having little thin     ## insufficient, paltry ##  ## The expectation that I'll be able to participate in a discussion of professional sports that requires more than a meager understanding of the Steelers’ record last year.

flashcards.name: measured
flashcards.definition: [ˈmeʒəd] ## adj. done with thought and care     ##  ## The stories in Yiyun Li’s recent collection are distinctive particularly for the strong contrast between their emotional intensity and their consistently measured tone.

flashcards.name: meet
flashcards.definition: [mi:t] ## adj. precisely adapted to a particular situation, need, or circumstance      ## condign ##  ## Debate rages on between proponents of corporal punishment and the death penalty and their detractors, though even the most rabid supporter agrees that punishments must be meet and the justice system evenhanded and thorough.

flashcards.name: meld
flashcards.definition: [meld] ## v. merge, blend    ## combine ## Her canvases can be viewed as theatres of cultural encounter, where references from the history of art meld with figures drawn from the Japanese anime that she loves to watch or from the Ladybird children’s books that served as her introduction to the English language.

flashcards.name: mendacity
flashcards.definition: [menˈdæsəti] ## n. lacking of honesty     ## hypocrisy ## Following the lamentable campaign of 2016, people surely had modest expectations for the manner in which Trump would conduct himself in office, but his belligerence and his mendacity have been astonishing even by his standards.

flashcards.name: mercurial
flashcards.definition: [mɜ:ˈkjʊəriəl] ## adj. changing often       ## volatile, inconstant ##  ## metaphor

flashcards.name: MOMA’s retrospective of the mercurial Bay Area artist showcases his work as a sculptor, filmmaker, painter, photographer, and puller of stunts.
flashcards.definition: [ˈmetəfə] ## (1)n. a figure of speech in which a word or phrase literally denoting one kind of object or idea is used in place of another to suggest a likeness or analogy between them     ## (2)n. an object, activity, or idea that is used as a symbol of something else    ##  ## Water has been a prevailing metaphor for this season’s Warriors, and not just because their logo includes a bridge.

flashcards.name: meticulous
flashcards.definition: [məˈtɪkjələs] ## adj. very careful about doing something in a extremely accurate and exact way           ## thorough, exact, painstaking ##  ## The meticulous dramatization of events intended to shock strikes me as the moral equivalent of pornography.

flashcards.name: mimic
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɪmɪk] ## (1)v. to copy especially of humor     (2)v. to naturally look like  ...   ## camouflage, replicate ##  ## Several scenes in the video mimic Parks’s photographs from the fifties and sixties.

flashcards.name: minimize
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɪnɪmaɪz] ## (1)v. to make as small as possible  ...        ## (2)v. to treat or describe as smaller or less important than it is    ##  ## An American military officer who recently returned from a second tour in Afghanistan told me that pressure to minimize American casualties had made it extremely difficult for U.S. military trainers to make progress in the country.

flashcards.name: minuscule
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɪnəskju:l] ## adj. very small     ## diminutive ##  ## The budget for the N.E.A. is a hundred and forty-eight million dollars—so minuscule a percentage of the national budget that its elimination can only be read as symbolic.

flashcards.name: misconception
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɪskənˈsepʃn] ## n. an idea that is not correct      ##  ##  Contrary to a common misconception, agoraphobia is often less a fear of open spaces than it is a fear of losing control. ## 57 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: misconstrue
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɪskənˈstru:] ## v. to interpret wrongly    ##  ## If I make eye contact with him, he might misconstrue that to mean that I want to talk to him.

flashcards.name: misgiving
flashcards.definition: [,mis'ɡiviŋ] ## n. a feeling of doubt or suspicion especially concerning a future event ##  ## trepidation, qualm ##  ## The whole aura of Woollcott was theatrical and delightful and you approached him as you did the theatre—with misgiving but with vast fascination.

flashcards.name: misguide
flashcards.definition: [mɪs'gaɪd] ## v. to lead astray: misdirect    ##  ## Unfortunately, this misguided notion recently has captivated several West Coast mayors, who have in consequence eagerly pursued the implementation of ferry service in their cities.

flashcards.name: mishandle
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɪsˈhændl] ## (1)v. to deal with or manage wrong or ignorantly        (2)v. maltreat    ##  ## In this episode of The Cartoon Lounge, we turn over (and otherwise mishandle) leaves that are not only old but dead

flashcards.name: misnomer
flashcards.definition: [,mɪs'nomɚ] ## n. a name that is wrong or not proper or appropriate      ##  ## The title of the book, “Generation Wealth,” seems at first to be a misnomer.

flashcards.name: misrepresent
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɪsˌreprɪˈzent] ## v. to describe in a false way especially in order to deceive someone     ##  ## In one sense, this is a story about the exploitative possibilities of online matchmaking: the opportunities to flagrantly misrepresent oneself, the ease of trawling for specific targets.

flashcards.name: misuse
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɪsˈju:z] ## (1)v. to use incorrectly     (2)v. abuse, mistreat    ## abuse ##  ## Few ideas are more misused than the notion that cultures evolve in Darwin fashion; many academics have begun writing about cultural evolution, but few treat the underlying Darwinian logic with the care it deserves.

flashcards.name: mitigate
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɪtɪgeɪt] ## v. to make less severe, harmful, or painful    ## abate, curtail, temper, ameliorate ##  ## The fact that Harry’s best friend and fellow-officer, Horace, played by Albert Popwell, is black does little to mitigate the stereotype that the diner scene embodies and perpetuates.

flashcards.name: mixed
flashcards.definition: [mɪkst] ## (1)adj. combining characteristics of more than one kind      (2)adj. including or accompanied by inconsistent, incompatible, or contrary elements     ## inconsistent ##  ## Although movie critic Pauline Kael had a distaste for sycophancy, she also had a need for obeisance; as a consequence of these competing feelings, she sent very mixed signals to friends and colleagues.

flashcards.name: mockery
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒkəri] ## n. insulting or contemptuous action or speech    ## derision ##  ## The decision was met with mockery from those interested in government transparency and with insinuations, from Republican quarters, that it was a symptom of the Obama Administration’s unwillingness to openly call acts like this works of Islamic terrorism.

flashcards.name: modest
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒdɪst] ## (1)adj. not too proud or confident about yourself or your abilities      (2)adj. unpretentious        ## (3)adj. limited in size, amount, or scope         ## unassuming, unostentatious ##  ## Modest does not have to mean timid.

flashcards.name: modicum
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒdɪkəm] ## n. a small amount    ## dearth ##  ## This flawed structure was also based on the premise, a naïve one at best, that the United States had a national interest in moderating Israeli behavior and achieving a modicum of justice in the Middle East.

flashcards.name: modulate
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒdjuleɪt] ## v. to adjust to or keep in proper measure or proportion    ## temper ##  ## Ferris relies on her voice to build character, but Gold doesn’t seem to have worked with her on how to modulate it to Williams’s natural and poetic language.

flashcards.name: mollify
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒlɪfaɪ] ## v. to make less angry       ##  ## In this new era of trying to pass bills that a Republican President will sign, the Freedom Caucus is among the first groups that Ryan needed to mollify. ##   58 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: momentary
flashcards.definition: [ˈməʊməntri] ## adj. lasting a very short time     ## evanescent ##  ## Jeremy Lin, who rose to fame almost five years ago as a momentary folk hero for the New York Knicks, is set to return to the boroughs this year, this time as the starting point guard for the Brooklyn Nets.

flashcards.name: monitor
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒnɪtə] ## v. to watch, observe, listen to, or check for a special purpose over a period of time       ##  ## The novel presents him as a man who monitors his state of mind and emotions as though he were doing so externally, taking and thinking about himself as if he were someone else.

flashcards.name: monolithic
flashcards.definition: [ˌmɒnə'lɪθɪk] ## (1)adj. consisting of or constituting a single unit      ## (2)adj. constituting a massive undifferentiated and often rigid whole        ##  ## These variances are one reason to start to unravel the myth of a monolithic black vote.

flashcards.name: monstrous
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɒnstrəs] ## (1)adj. extremely or unusually large      (2)adj. extraordinarily ugly or vicious     ##  ## His project seems to suggest that rehabilitation, whether of a person or of a nation, requires an empathy and inquisitiveness toward even the most monstrous chapters of the past.

flashcards.name: morbid
flashcards.definition: ['mɔrbɪd] ## adj. not healthy or normal     ##  ## A thread of self-deprecating humor transforms what could have been a morbid meditation on aging into a tale of common humanity.

flashcards.name: mordant
flashcards.definition: [ˈmɔ:dnt] ## adj. expressing harsh criticism especially in a way that is funny     ## acerbic ##  ## The dialogue is as mordant as a Joe Orton play, and just as dirty.

flashcards.name: mount
flashcards.definition: [maʊnt] ## v. to increase in amount    ##  ## The director Tom Ridgely, of the theatre troupe Waterwell, will mount “Blueprint Specials” Jan. 6-11, on the hangar deck of the Intrepid.

flashcards.name: muddle
flashcards.definition: [ˈmʌdl] ## (1)v. to cause confusion in  ...    ## (2)n. a state of confusion or disorder    ## confuse ##  ## More broadly, the Administration’s policy in the region has evolved into a destabilizing muddle.

flashcards.name: multifaceted
flashcards.definition: [,mʌltɪ'fæsɪtɪd] ## adj. having many different parts      ##  ## Kean’s goal, in this multifaceted history, is to get at the many reasons for the unprecedented event, which was voluntary, advised against by major governmental bodies, and premature.

flashcards.name: mundane
flashcards.definition: [mʌnˈdeɪn] ## (1)adj. dull and ordinary          ## (2)adj. relating to ordinary life on earth rather than to spiritual things      ##  ## In these moments, the details are sarcastic and eerie, disturbingly mundane.

flashcards.name: mutable
flashcards.definition: [ˈmju:təbl] ## adj. able or likely to change often     ## liquid ##  ## Her most notable innovation with “Middlemarch: The Series” is gender-bending the cast, envisioning a social group in which gender identity and sexual orientation are variable and possibly mutable.

flashcards.name: naiveté
flashcards.definition: [na:'i:vtei] ## n. the state or quality of being inexperienced or unsophisticated    ##  ## Both “Get Out” and the documentary “I Am Not Your Negro” mock and unmask white America’s show of naïveté at entrenched racism.

flashcards.name: narcissism
flashcards.definition: ['nɑrsɪ'sɪzəm] ## n. egoism, egocentrism    ## self-flattery ##  ## Once you’ve actually read his late-night musings, the fact that he thought they should be professionally bound and promptly read by everyone at his company looks more like evidence of a towering narcissism that is neither heroic nor endearing.

flashcards.name: nascent
flashcards.definition: [ˈnæsnt] ## adj. beginning to exist      ## budding, unformed ##  ## The online world, with all its nascent norms, is a place that involves a lot of complicated posturing—a careful negotiation between irony and joy, imprecise standards on what and when to share.

flashcards.name: naysayer
flashcards.definition: ['neɪˌseɪə] ## n. a person who says something will not work or is not possible        ##         59 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The value of Cage to “Records Ruin the Landscape” is not that he was a naysayer or heel-dragger or scourge but, rather, that he persisted in coming up with ingenious solutions to what he took to be the downside of making and releasing recordings.

flashcards.name: nebulous
flashcards.definition: [ˈnebjələs] ## adj. not clear     ## vague ##  ## Several of the command’s deployments are civil-affairs teams, but the secrecy surrounding many missions has led observers to suspect that the U.S. government is more involved in nebulous warfare than it is letting on.

flashcards.name: negligent
flashcards.definition: ['neɡlɪdʒənt] ## adj. failing to take proper or normal care of something or someone        ##  ## Chloe Coscarelli, the restaurant’s namesake and the originator of many of the recipes, was recently forced out of the business she founded three years ago, after the company she had partnered with alleged that she had become negligent.

flashcards.name: negligible
flashcards.definition: ['nɛɡlɪdʒəbl] ## adj. very small or unimportant            ## insignificant, inconsequential, trifling ##  ## Earth’s orbit is essentially circular, so the effect on our climate is negligible.

flashcards.name: negotiable
flashcards.definition: [nɪˈgəʊʃiəbl] ## adj. able to be discussed and changed before an agreement or decision is made      ##  ## My grandsons had made one non-negotiable demand (another spoiler alert): at the end of the movie, someone had to eat the golden egg, probably scrambled.

flashcards.name: nettle
flashcards.definition: ['netl] ## v. to make angry    ##  ## There is nothing that nettles scientists more than having an old problem in their field solved by someone from outside.

flashcards.name: neutrality
flashcards.definition: [njuː'trælɪtɪ] ## n. the quality or state of not supporting either side in an argument, fight, war, etc.    ## impartiality ##  ## In the various media frenzies surrounding the President, it was easy to miss the significance of this astounding rejection of ecclesial neutrality.

flashcards.name: nimble
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɪmbl] ## (1)adj. able to move quickly, easily, and lightly      ## (2)adj. able to learn and understand things quickly and easily     ## adroit dexterous, skillful ##  ## The movie was written by Bryan Sipe and directed by Jean-Marc Vallée, a filmmaker of considerable cunning, who takes predicaments that should by rights deflate the heart—an H.I.V. diagnosis in “Dallas Buyers Club”, a psychological debacle in “Wild”—and turns them into nimble entertainments.

flashcards.name: no-nonsense
flashcards.definition: ['nəu'nɔnsəns] ## adj. very serious about doing things in a direct and efficient way without any foolishness or nonsense           ## businesslike ##  ## The Leipzig academy for painting and architecture opened in 1764, but its emphasis, in keeping with the city’s no-nonsense attitude, had become more practical by the end of the nineteenth century.

flashcards.name: noisome
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɔɪsəm] ## adj. offensive to the senses and especially to the sense of smell            ## malodorous ##  ## Most people deal with overwhelming anger or hurt or humiliation or shame—any of the hot, noisome feelings that form in the gut and move slowly up the throat—by marshalling their strength and batting those thoughts back down.

flashcards.name: nonchalant
flashcards.definition: [,nɑnʃə'lɑnt] ## adj. having an air of easy unconcern or indifference     ## insouciant ##  ## A recent memorial for the choreographer paid tribute to a dancer of immense wit, courage, and nonchalant elegance.

flashcards.name: nonconformist
flashcards.definition: [ˌnɒnkənˈfɔ:mɪst] ## n. a person who does not behave the way most people behave        ## maverick ##  ## He plays Mr. Keating, a nonconformist teacher at an all-boys school, the part made famous by Robin Williams.

flashcards.name: nondescript
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɒndɪskrɪpt] ## adj. lacking distinctive or interesting qualities      ## unexceptional ##  ## The place was a nondescript peach color on the outside, wood-panelled on the inside, and sat at the top of a large hill.

flashcards.name: nonspecialist
flashcards.definition: [nɒns'peʃəlɪst] ## n. someone who does not specialize in a particular area, activity, field of research, etc.       ## layperson ##  ## The city should try to diversify its tech growth away from Internet firms to include industries like biotech, which supplies large numbers of both specialist and nonspecialist jobs. ##        60 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: nostalgia
flashcards.definition: [nə'stældʒə] ## (1)n. pleasure and sadness that is caused by remembering something from the past and wishing that you could experience it again     ## (2)n. the state of being homesick    ##  ## Really, he added, the show’s overriding theme is “nostalgia, and how we all yearn for our past and how that can be really destructive.”

flashcards.name: novel
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɒvl] ## adj. new and different from what has been known before     ## original, unexampled, unprecedented ##  ## The baseball players performance during last nights game was impressive, although not novel; others have performed similar feats.

flashcards.name: novice
flashcards.definition: [ˈnɒvɪs] ## n. a person who has just started learning or doing something    ## tyro ##  ## McGregor is a mixed-martial-arts champion but a boxing novice.

flashcards.name: noxious
flashcards.definition: ['nɑkʃəs] ## adj. harmful to living things         ##  ## For a PBS series exploring “American Angst,” Demme, who died last week, made a little-known teleplay about family life as a noxious cauldron of clashing agendas.

flashcards.name: nuance
flashcards.definition: ['nju:ɑ:ns] ## n. a very small difference in color, tone, meaning, etc.      ## subtlety ##  ## Jim and I shared many qualities: an unending appetite, inhaling life to the full chorizo, finding hilarious and playful nuance in every breath and every moment, but I always was and remain the student.

flashcards.name: numinous
flashcards.definition: [ˈnju:mɪnəs] ## adj. having a mysterious, holy, or spiritual quality     adj. supernatural, mysterious          ## occult ##  ## The work he turned in for class was often untethered, a beautiful little wreck on its way to being numinous.

flashcards.name: obdurate
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒbdjərət] ## adj. refusing to do what other people want     ## intransigent, fortitude ##  ## Her photograph shows an aged and obdurate man with a tinge of uncertainty in his face.

flashcards.name: obedience
flashcards.definition: [ə'bi:dɪəns] ## n. the act of obeying    ## submission ##  ## There’s something about the song’s audacity: the kids sing with defiance about total obedience to an authority.

flashcards.name: obeisance
flashcards.definition: [əʊˈbeɪsns] ## n. respect for someone or something    ##  ## Gorsuch portrayed himself as a kind of judicial automaton, obligated to pay mindless obeisance to the Court’s prior rulings.

flashcards.name: obfuscate
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒbfʌskeɪt] ## v. to make more difficult to understand        ## obscure, mystify ##  ## Now is the time to call things what they actually are, because language can illuminate truth as much as it can obfuscate it.

flashcards.name: objectionable
flashcards.definition: [əbˈdʒekʃənəbl] ## adj. causing people to be offended       ##  ## The video series “Dark Content,” by the artists Franco and Eva Mattes, explores the hidden world of the workers who help scrub the Internet of objectionable material.

flashcards.name: objective
flashcards.definition: [əbˈdʒektɪv] ## adj. based on facts rather than feelings or opinions         ## fair ##  ## Games are affordable and, with their formally described rules for scoring, winning, or losing, are often a powerful and convenient way to provide an objective context within which to balance theory and practice.

flashcards.name: obligatory
flashcards.definition: [əˈblɪgətri] ## (1)adj. required by a law or rule       ## (2)adj. always or often included as a familiar and expected part of something      ##  ## He explained to them, politely, that there were certain obligatory regulations, and they shot him.

flashcards.name: obliterate
flashcards.definition: [əˈblɪtəreɪt] ## v. to destroy completely so that nothing is left       ##  ## We might expect Thernstrom to be suspicious now of claims that differences in class could be obliterated if only the public schools did a better job.

flashcards.name: obscure
flashcards.definition: [əbˈskjʊə] ## (1)adj. not well-known       ## (2)adj. difficult to understand      ## (3)v. to make difficult to understand or know  ...    (4)v. to hide or cover    ## anonymous, opaque, obfuscate ##  ## In order to cultivate new repertoire, the music industry is providing a hearing for previously obscure composers. ##     61 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: obsequious
flashcards.definition: [əbˈsi:kwiəs] ## adj. too eager to help or obey someone important     ## sycophantic ##  ## Publicly, Pence has shown nothing but unconditional—at times even obsequious and worshipful—support for Trump. His private actions, however, suggest a more calculating and realistic mind-set.

flashcards.name: observation
flashcards.definition: [,ɑbzɚ'veʃən] ## (1) n. a comment or remark     ## (2) n. something you notice by watching and listening     ## (3) n. an act or instance of observing a custom, rule, or law    ##  ## Both very good and very bad books are easy to review. Praise and censure come easily. But what of books that contain a muddle of virtues and vices? Here the reviewer’s task is more demanding: the author’s useful and thought-provoking observations need to be sifted from the useless and tedious.

flashcards.name: obsessed
flashcards.definition: [əb'sest] ## adj. if someone is obsessed with a person or thing, they keep thinking about them and find it difficult to think about anything else     ## fixated ##  ## The year is 1776, and Americans are still obsessed with football.

flashcards.name: obsolete
flashcards.definition: [ɑbsəˌlit] ## adj. no longer used by anyone         ## outmoded, fusty ##  ## Blake Fall Conroy‘s “Police Flag” in the Museum of Capitalism, an installation that envisions a world in which capitalism is obsolete.

flashcards.name: obstacle
flashcards.definition: ['ɑbstəkl] ## n. something that impedes progress or achievement    ##  ## I wasn’t directed so much as given a series of props to make my way through, like an obstacle course.

flashcards.name: obtain
flashcards.definition: [əbˈteɪn] ## v. to gain or attain usually by planned action or effort    ## glean ##  ## Currently, houses of worship, religiously affiliated colleges and hospitals, and certain corporations can obtain an exemption from the requirement.

flashcards.name: obtrusive
flashcards.definition: [əbˈtru:sɪv] ## adj. noticeable in an unpleasant or annoying way     ## conspicuous ##  ## We all stayed up late and I tried to take notes without looking too obtrusive.

flashcards.name: obviate
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒbvieɪt] ## v. to make no longer necessary       ##  ## Unconventional war fits no pattern, defies the military planner's imagination—and might obviate the use of force in the first place.

flashcards.name: occlude
flashcards.definition: [əˈklu:d] ## v. to close up or block off    ##  ## In six hundred million years, the moon will be distant enough that it will no longer fully occlude the sun.

flashcards.name: occult
flashcards.definition: [əˈkʌlt] ## adj. not easily apprehended or understood     ## numinous ##  ## He is now known mainly to scholars of Symbolism, connoisseurs of the occult, and devotees of the music of Erik Satie.

flashcards.name: offset
flashcards.definition: [,ɔf'sɛt] ## v. to create an equal balance between two things       ## compensate ##  ## But optics soon caught him up, too, when the public learned that the M.T.A. had funnelled almost five million dollars to three upstate ski areas to offset losses incurred during a recent warm winter.

flashcards.name: old-fashioned
flashcards.definition: [ˈəuldˈfæʃənd] ## (1)adj. of, relating to, or characteristic of a past era      (2)adj. outmoded     ##  ## John Ridley’s show is serious in an old-fashioned sense: sincere, thoughtful, and heartbreaking.

flashcards.name: ominous
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒmɪnəs] ## adj. suggesting that something bad is going to happen in the future      ## inauspicious ##  ## Iranian forces stand guard at the site of a terrorist attack in Tehran, at the parliament building. The rampage marked an ominous escalation of regional tensions.

flashcards.name: omit
flashcards.definition: [ə'mɪt] ## v. to leave out    ##  ## So they ignore, omit, bury, tidy up, or even invent evidence, all for the sake of preserving an “accurate end.

flashcards.name: omnipresent
flashcards.definition: [,ɑmnɪ'prɛznt] ## adj. present in all places at all times       ## ubiquitous, universal ##  ## Sullivan spoke with David Remnick about how the Clinton campaign has adapted under the omnipresent threat of hacking, and how Clinton would approach conflicts with Putin if she is elected President

flashcards.name: onerous
flashcards.definition: [ˈəʊnərəs] ## adj. difficult and unpleasant to do or deal with     ## burdensome ##          62 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## When you can’t ban something outright, it’s possible to make the process of obtaining it so onerous as to be a kind of punishment.

flashcards.name: onetime
flashcards.definition: ['wʌntaɪm] ## adj. having been someone or something specified in the past     ## erstwhile ##  ## Formerly incarcerated undergrads started a group on campus to offer mentoring, support, and advocacy to other onetime inmates.

flashcards.name: onset
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒnset] ## n. the beginning of something    ##  ## Later, after the onset of puberty, the Rock spent time doing various strength-training exercises and acquired more muscle than he’d had as a baby.

flashcards.name: opaque
flashcards.definition: [əʊˈpeɪk] ## (1)adj. not letting light through       (2)adj. difficult to understand or explain     ## obscure, inaccessible ##  ## The smoke thickened into an opaque black funnel. The air smelled like a tire shop.

flashcards.name: opinionated
flashcards.definition: [əˈpɪnjəneɪtɪd] ## adj. unduly adhering to one’s own opinion or to preconceived notions        ##  ## Criticism can assume many forms: essays, profiles, reported pieces, opinionated rants.

flashcards.name: opportune
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒpətju:n] ## adj. done or happening at the right time     ## timely ##  ## Perhaps it was personally difficult, but politically the arrangement is opportune.

flashcards.name: oppressive
flashcards.definition: [əˈpresɪv] ## (1)adj. very cruel or unfair     ## (2)adj. overwhelming or depressing to the spirit or senses       ##  ## Os Mutantes recast an oppressive regime in their technicolor image.

flashcards.name: opprobrium
flashcards.definition: [əˈprəʊbriəm] ## (1)n. very strong disapproval or criticism of a person or thing especially by a large number of people     ## (2)n. something that brings disgrace    ## disdain, vitriol ##  ## Although Pound tried hard to play the clavichord and the bassoon (earning the opprobrium of Ernest Hemingway), his general musical training was rudimentary in the extreme.

flashcards.name: optimism
flashcards.definition: ['ɒptɪmɪzəm] ## n. a feeling or belief that good things will happen in the future    ##  ## What is the basis of optimism In Israel about Donald Trump? For many, it seems to be his apparent endorsement of an “outside- in” peace process.

flashcards.name: opulent
flashcards.definition: [ˈɒpjələnt] ## (1)adj. having a large estate or property      ## (2)adj. amply or plentifully provided or fashioned often to the point of ostentation         ## affluent ##  ## Based on the frequency of Trump’s visits to the opulent club since he took office, Mar-a-Lago appears to be a place—unlike Washington—where he feels at home. It is also a business that, for the past decade, has taken advantage of the H-2B program.

flashcards.name: orderly
flashcards.definition: [ˈɔ:dəli] ## adj. arranged or organized in a logical or regular way      ## coherent ##  ## More recently, her daughter and grandson, Maira and and Alex Kalman, turned her belongings—frugal, elegant, orderly—into an unconventional exhibit.

flashcards.name: orientation
flashcards.definition: [ˌɔ:riənˈteɪʃn] ## n. a main interest, quality, or goal       ## bias ##  ## As scientists learn more about how genes affect everything from hair color to sexual orientation and mental health, we’re faced with moral and political questions about how we allow science to intervene in the genetic code.

flashcards.name: original
flashcards.definition: [əˈrɪdʒənl] ## (1)adj. made or produced first      (2)adj. not like others     ## novel ##  ## “A Ghost Story” ’s fiercely audacious originality is on view from the start, before any ghosts make their appearance.

flashcards.name: orthodox
flashcards.definition: ['ɔrθədɑks] ## adj. accepted as true or correct by most people     ##  ## An orthodox Christian says his side has lost the culture wars—and argues for a “strategic retreat.”

flashcards.name: oust
flashcards.definition: [aʊst] ## (1)v. to cause or force to leave a position of power, a competition, etc.        ## (2)v. to take the place of    ## expel, banish ## 63 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The Iraqi Army had set its sights on the al-Nuri Mosque as the ultimate prize in the campaign to oust ISIS from Mosul, which was launched eight months ago.

flashcards.name: outdated
flashcards.definition: [aʊt'deɪtɪd] ## adj. no longer useful or acceptable     ##  ## The reasons that musicians record on outdated, archaic, and less flexible equipment are, in some sense, surprising.

flashcards.name: outdo
flashcards.definition: [ˌaʊtˈdu:] ## v. to be better than    ## eclipse ##  ## The night felt like the exhausted hours after a small-club comedy show, when comedians stand around at the bar, casually trying to outdo each other.

flashcards.name: outmoded
flashcards.definition: [aʊt'məʊdɪd] ## adj. not modern or current     ## unfashionable, obsolete, fusty ##  ## This move represents a staggering postmodern achievement, forcing us to question corporate funding of the arts, as well as outmoded notions of the artist-as-brand.

flashcards.name: outstanding
flashcards.definition: [aʊtˈstændɪŋ] ## (1)adj. extremely good or excellent      ## (2)adj. easy to notice especially because of being important or very good     ##  ## Anthology Film Archives shows outstanding works in “The Cinema of Gender Transgression: Trans Film.”

flashcards.name: outstrip
flashcards.definition: [ˌaʊtˈstrɪp] ## v. to get ahead of    ##  ## Does Donald Trump outstrip the novelist’s imagination?

flashcards.name: overbearing
flashcards.definition: [əʊvə'beərɪŋ] ## adj. harshly and haughtily arrogant         ##  ## This movie is not just bad. It’s terrible; it’s dreadful. Overbearing, pretentious, madly repetitive.

flashcards.name: overblown
flashcards.definition: [ˌəʊvəˈbləʊn] ## adj. inflated         ##  ## A child psychologist—and grandmother—says such fears are overblown.

flashcards.name: overlook
flashcards.definition: [ˌəʊvəˈlʊk] ## (1)v. to fail to see or notice     ## (2)v. inspect     ## (3)v. to look down upon from above    ##  ## History shows that if voters like a candidate they’re willing to overlook a lot.

flashcards.name: oversell
flashcards.definition: [ˌəʊvəˈsel] ## (1)v. to make excessive claims for     (2)v. to sell too much or too many      ##  ## Enthusiasts, including researchers, perpetually oversell the microbiome.

flashcards.name: overshadow
flashcards.definition: [əʊvə'ʃædəʊ] ## v. to exceed in importance    ## outlast, obscure ##  ## When, during the first days of the Administration, his mug appeared on the front of Time magazine next to the headline “The Great Manipulator,” he breached the first rule of the Trump world: never overshadow the boss.

flashcards.name: overstate
flashcards.definition: [əʊvə'steɪt] ## v. to say that is larger or greater than it really is    ##  ## The practical significance of the Court’s decision is difficult to overstate.

flashcards.name: overthrow
flashcards.definition: [ˌəʊvəˈθrəʊ] ## v. to remove from power especially by force       ##  ## In 1971, after a military coup, the new regime arrested Gülen on charges of conspiring to overthrow the secular order, and he served seven months in prison.

flashcards.name: pacific
flashcards.definition: [pəˈsɪfɪk] ## adj. loving peace       ## dovish ##  ## Daniel looked over at Sister Mary, now responding in what seemed like unusual vehemence for so pacific a personality.

flashcards.name: painstaking
flashcards.definition: [ˈpeɪnzteɪkɪŋ] ## adj. showing or done with great care and effort       ## meticulous ##  ## Until recently, reconstructing a lineage required painstaking guesswork based on tiny variations in anatomy and appearance.

flashcards.name: palliate
flashcards.definition: [ˈpælieɪt] ## (1)v. to moderate the intensity of     ## (2)v. the cover by excuses and apologies    ## damp ##  ## He was hoping that the lorazepam he’d take to palliate the flight north would keep him tranquillized for the duration. ##   64 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: paltry
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɔ:ltri] ## (1)adj. very small or too small in amount      ## (2)adj. having little meaning, importance, or worth      ## meager, insufficient ##  ## To maintain that Caesar is merely played by Serkis, or voiced by him, does paltry justice to his skills, and, in truth, we need a new vocabulary to cope with such innovation.

flashcards.name: panacea
flashcards.definition: [ˌpænəˈsi:ə] ## n. something that will make everything about a situation better     ## remedy, cure-all ##  ## Paris may not have been a panacea, but it was, for some musicians, a respite and, for others, even a refuge.

flashcards.name: paradigm
flashcards.definition: [ˈpærədaɪm] ## n. a model or pattern for something that may be copied       ## model ##  ## The grappling guru is inventing a new paradigm for bringing opponents to submission.

flashcards.name: paradoxical
flashcards.definition: [ˌpærə'dɒksɪkl] ## adj. of the nature of a paradox     ## ironic ##  ## Scott-Young’s shows have a paradoxical mission—to dignify her subjects while teasing out the melodrama of their lives.

flashcards.name: parity
flashcards.definition: [ˈpærəti] ## n. the quality or state of being equal or equivalent       ## equality ##  ## Nichols intently focuses on specific characters and always there’s a sense of parity with himself.

flashcards.name: parochial
flashcards.definition: [pəˈrəʊkiəl] ## adj. limited to only the things that affect your local area     ## provincial ##  ## This saga is an unlikely candidate for a major Hollywood production, especially one written and directed by the maker of the “Dark Knight” trilogy. It’s hard to think of a more parochial tale.

flashcards.name: parsimonious
flashcards.definition: [ˌpɑ:sɪˈməʊniəs] ## adj. very unwilling to spend money     ## stingy, illiberal ##  ## I wrote a proposal, and eventually Tom persuaded Roger Straus, the house’s famously parsimonious founder, to put up an advance of three thousand dollars.

flashcards.name: partisan
flashcards.definition: ['pɑrtəzn] ## adj. devoted to or biased in support of a party, group, or cause      ##  ## A tenuous partisan coalition exists in the Senate, and its cohesion depends upon McConnell’s power to persuade.

flashcards.name: passive
flashcards.definition: [ˈpæsɪv] ## adj. used to describe someone who allows things to happen or who accepts what other people do or decide without trying to change anything     ##  ## If you have so much as tiptoed into the arena of personal finance over the past few decades, you will have heard about the virtues of passive investing.

flashcards.name: pastiche
flashcards.definition: [pæˈsti:ʃ] ## n. a mixture of different things     ##  ## There’s nothing wrong with pastiche or stylization, of course. Plenty of recent series have used these techniques wonderfully— or, at least, effectively.

flashcards.name: pastoral
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɑ:stərəl] ## adj. of or relating to the countryside or to the lives of people who live in the country     ## bucolic ##  ## The pastoral wind-band music, once reflective in mood, is now sucked in and slashed off by the big, loud, tutti chords, executed with frightening precision.

flashcards.name: patchwork
flashcards.definition: [ˈpætʃwɜ:k] ## n. something that is made up of different things     ## hodgepodge ##  ## After he enrolled at Virginia Commonwealth University, in 2006, he began releasing patchwork cyberpunk instrumentals under the name Diamond Black Hearted Boy.

flashcards.name: patent
flashcards.definition: ['pætnt] ## (1)n. an official document conferring a right or privilege     (2)adj. obvious or clear       ##  ## This information was fed into a database, which, Sprigman said, was cleverly “organized according to existing prior-art classifications, so that patent examiners looking through it would find it familiar and would know where to look.”

flashcards.name: pathetic
flashcards.definition: [pə'θetɪk] ## adj. causing feelings of sadness and sympathy     ##  ## The images out of Charlottesville, Virginia, are unsettling—but also pathetic, also exasperating—for their boring timelessness.

flashcards.name: paucity
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɔ:səti] ## n. a small amount of something    ## dearth ##  ## His biggest challenge had been the paucity of top opponents willing to fight him.

flashcards.name: peculiar
flashcards.definition: [pɪ'kjuːlɪə] ## adj. not usual or normal     ##  ## The state of Maine has carved out a peculiar place in American political life in recent years. ##       65 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: pecuniary
flashcards.definition: [pɪˈkju:niəri] ## adj. of or relating to money     ## economic ##  ## A more worthwhile question is whether Basquiat rates high in valuations of recent art apart from the pecuniary.

flashcards.name: pedestrian
flashcards.definition: [pəˈdestriən] ## adj. commonplace, unimaginative     ##  ## The laser has been widely utilized in many industries such as the packaging industry, CD player manufacturing, and all sorts of commonplace articles; however, the everyday presence of the laser doesn’t mean the laser can only be used in pedestrian ways.

flashcards.name: peer
flashcards.definition: [pɪə] ## (1)n. a person who belongs to the same age group or social group as someone else            ## (2)v. to look searchingly at something difficult to discern    ##  ## We can think of ourselves as an animal’s peer—or its protector. What will robots decide about us?

flashcards.name: pejorative
flashcards.definition: [pɪ'dʒɔrətɪv] ## adj. insulting to someone or something     ##  ## their debate, which ran a little more than an hour, was as amicable and consensus-oriented as the actual Presidential debates have been pejorative-laden and divisive.

flashcards.name: pellucid
flashcards.definition: [pəˈlu:sɪd] ## adj. very clear     ## limpid ##  ## They moved on to the show’s penultimate scene, a tender, halting exchange between Pierre and the heartbroken Natasha who, on Broadway, is played by the pellucid soprano Denée Benton.

flashcards.name: penalty
flashcards.definition: [ˈpenəlti] ## (1)n. punishment for breaking a rule or law     ## (2)n. a disadvantage or difficulty you experience      ##  ## Even as the number of executions continues to fall in the U.S., public support for the death penalty persists.

flashcards.name: penchant
flashcards.definition: ['pentʃənt] ## n. a strong and continued inclination       ##  ## Stone’s penchant for exaggerating his role in political events may be what got him in trouble.

flashcards.name: perceptible
flashcards.definition: [pəˈseptəbl] ## adj. able to be seen or noticed          ## discernible ##  ## The expectation that the U.S. would withdraw from the Paris climate accord drove me to seek out the delicate climate-change novel “Autumn,” by Ali Smith, who suggests that the catastrophe comes slowly and in barely perceptible increments.

flashcards.name: peregrinate
flashcards.definition: ['perɪgrɪˌneɪt] ## v. to walk or travel over    ##  ## She demonstrates a great extent of peregrination, as she has traveled to many more countries and places around the world than any of her kindred.

flashcards.name: perennial
flashcards.definition: [pəˈreniəl] ## adj. existing or continuing in the same way for a long time     ## long-standing ##  ## Armenia is chess’s perennial overachiever, and Levon Aronian, its greatest player, is a swashbuckling throwback.

flashcards.name: perfunctory
flashcards.definition: [pəˈfʌŋktəri] ## adj. used to describe something that is done without energy or enthusiasm because of habit or because it is expected     ## cursory, casual ##  ## The baby bass, the second-most-expensive item on offer, is more perfunctory than memorable.

flashcards.name: perilous
flashcards.definition: [ˈperələs] ## adj. full of danger     ## dangerous, precarious ##  ## Video can record the harrowing journey of Syrian refugees making the perilous trek to Europe to seek a better life, or the dazzling display of thousands of pigeons outfitted with L.E.D. lights taking flight in the Brooklyn dusk.

flashcards.name: peripatetic
flashcards.definition: [ˌperipəˈtetɪk] ## adj. pedestrian, itinerant     ## itinerant ##  ## The scope of Ossorio’s peripatetic life reflects Piglia’s vast literary ambition—he tries, in his work, to include everything.

flashcards.name: peripheral
flashcards.definition: [pəˈrɪfərəl] ## adj. of, relating to, involving, or forming a periphery or surface part      ## marginal ##  ## Movement in the peripheral vision is easy to observe.

flashcards.name: permeable
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɜ:miəbl] ## adj. allowing liquids or gases to pass through      ## porous ##  ## Lionel needed and loved her—but he shuddered at the love and revolted against the need, as both were tokens of his dependency and his permeable, precarious life.

flashcards.name: perpetuate
flashcards.definition: [pəˈpetʃueɪt] ## v. to make perpetual or cause to last indefinitely  ...   ##        66 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The whole premise of baseball-umpire camp is to perpetuate naïve realism.

flashcards.name: perplex
flashcards.definition: [pəˈpleks] ## v. to confuse very much    ## confound ##  ## A good number of Williams’s stories turn, I now see, on the question of hallucination, on facts and details that perplex the reader but make private sense to the characters.

flashcards.name: persist
flashcards.definition: [pəˈsɪst] ## v. to continue to do something or to try to do something even though it is difficult or other people want you to stop      ##  ## In “One Year in a Life of Crime,” Alpert films three professional shoplifters, Rob, Fred, and Mike, young men from Newark who have long criminal records and persist in their illicit activities.

flashcards.name: perspicacious
flashcards.definition: [ˌpɜ:spɪˈkeɪʃəs] ## adj. having or showing an ability to notice and understand things that are difficult or not obvious       ## discernible ##  ## The latest edition, which opens on March 17, was overseen by the perspicacious young curators Mia Locks and Christopher Y. Lew (pictured outdoors at the Whitney with Larry Bell’s 2017 sculpture “Pacific Red II”).

flashcards.name: pertain
flashcards.definition: [pəˈteɪn] ## (1)v. to relate to someone or something    ## (2)v. to belong as a part, member, accessory or product    ##  ## I believe the next tranche of his documents pertain to the Clinton Foundation, but there's no telling what the October surprise may be.”

flashcards.name: pervasive
flashcards.definition: [pəˈveɪsɪv] ## adj. existing in every part of something         ## rife ##  ## The tech industry has pervasive issues with hiring—and retaining—women, black, and Latino employees. Now a bevy of startups hopes to expand the recruiting process.

flashcards.name: pessimistic
flashcards.definition: [ˌpesɪˈmɪstɪk] ## adj. having or showing a lack of hope for the future     ##  ## This profoundly pessimistic memoir about fifteen years of reporting on global jihad and the war on terror brims with hair-raising, saddening, and often absurd stories.

flashcards.name: philosophy
flashcards.definition: [fəˈlɒsəfi] ## (1)n. the study of ideas about knowledge, truth, the nature and meaning of life, etc.     ## (2)n. a set of ideas about how to do something or how to live    ##  ## It is part of a shift in philosophy in the museum’s architecture and design department, which in the past has championed architecture’s artistic value over its real-world consequences.

flashcards.name: pilfer
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɪlfə] ## v. to steal things that are not very valuable or to steal a small amount of something    ## appropriate ##  ## Hans Zimmer’s music may pilfer from Elgar’s “Nimrod,” the most patriotically charged of the Enigma Variations, yet such bombast is not really required, and the rest of the score is more attuned to the film’s suspense.

flashcards.name: pioneering
flashcards.definition: [ˌpaɪəˈnɪərɪŋ] ## adj. doing something that has not been done before      ##  ## Long before artificial intelligence came into its own, a pioneering programmer taught a computer to write love letters.

flashcards.name: pivotal
flashcards.definition: ['pɪvətl] ## adj. very important     ##  ## The New York primary is less than three weeks away, and, regardless of what happens in Wisconsin, next Tuesday, it could be a pivotal moment.

flashcards.name: plague
flashcards.definition: [pleɪg] ## (1)n. a large number of harmful or annoying things          (2)v. to cause constant or repeated trouble, illness, etc.       ##  ## The killings in Dallas are one more reminder that guns are central, not accessory, to the American plague of violence.

flashcards.name: plaintive
flashcards.definition: [ˈpleɪntɪv] ## adj. expressing suffering or sadness     ## elegiac ##  ## Then a cut, and there, kneeling on a stretch of sidewalk, is a young man in jeans and a red hoodie, an obscure, plaintive expression on his face as he holds your gaze.

flashcards.name: plastic
flashcards.definition: [ˈplæstɪk] ## (1)adj. capable of adapting to varying conditions      (2)adj. not real or sincere     ## malleable ##  ## The clear plastic device that has kept one American typewriter company afloat.

flashcards.name: platitudinous
flashcards.definition: [ˌplætɪ'tju:dɪnəs] ## adj. having the characteristics of a platitude     ##  ## Her primary message—be yourself—has always felt both platitudinous and profound. ##  67 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: plausible
flashcards.definition: ['plɔzəbl] ## (1)adj. believable or realistic      ## (2)adj. superficially fair, reasonable, or valuable but often specious              ## conceivable ##  ## If there is no true news, false news can be made very plausible.

flashcards.name: plentiful
flashcards.definition: [ˈplentɪfl] ## adj. containing or giving large amounts of something     ##  ## The purple asters were less plentiful than they had been on her previous trips, but the monks were pleased to see her, and she chatted agreeably with them for an hour or so.

flashcards.name: plethora
flashcards.definition: [ˈpleθərə] ## n. excess, superfluity    ## surfeit, glut ##  ## There’s a plethora of paunchy men in ill-fitting suits, paired with leggy, stiletto-heeled counterparts.

flashcards.name: plodding
flashcards.definition: [ˈplɒdɪŋ] ## adj. unexciting       ##  ## As for a successor, Nixon chose the popular House Minority Leader, Gerald Ford, of Michigan, described by the Journal as “pleasant but plodding party wheelhorse who often speaks and apparently thinks in clichés”.

flashcards.name: plummet
flashcards.definition: ['plʌmɪt] ## v. to fall or drop suddenly in amount, value, etc.            ##  ## Evidence suggest that populations of migratory birds in both the New and Old Worlds have plummeted, a decline that carries the potential for significant ecological damage far beyond the shrinking numbers of the birds themselves.

flashcards.name: pointless
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɔɪntləs] ## adj. having no meaning, purpose, or effect      ## futile ##  ## To say that our lives are pointless and our achievements meaningless is to state the obvious.

flashcards.name: polemic
flashcards.definition: [pəˈlemɪk] ## (1)n. a strong written or spoken attack against someone else’s opinions, beliefs, practices, etc.       ## (2)n. the art or practice of using language to defend or harshly criticize something or someone              ##  ## The Northwestern University professor strengthens her polemic against campus sexual culture.

flashcards.name: polymath
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɒlimæθ] ## n. someone who knows a lot about many different things     ## encyclopedic ##  ## The polymath writer, known for defying expectation, turned a treatment for her unstable moods into her latest project.

flashcards.name: ponder
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɒndə] ## v. to think about or conducer carefully      ## contemplate ##  ## At the end of the pilot, when Diplo runs into Calvin Harris, with whom he has been embroiled in a caustic and increasingly absurd Twitter beef, they ponder the true purpose of the work.

flashcards.name: porous
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɔ:rəs] ## (1)adj. having small holes that allow air or liquid to pass through      (2)adj. easy to pass or get through      ## permeable ##  ## The border has long been an active and porous one, going back to the days when Duke Ellington adopted symphonic forms and Maurice Ravel assimilated the blues.

flashcards.name: portend
flashcards.definition: [pɔ:ˈtend] ## v. to give an omen or anticipatory sign of    ## predict, presage ##  ## These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend no good to us.

flashcards.name: posture
flashcards.definition: ['pɒstʃə] ## (1)n. the attitude a person or group has toward a subject     (2)v. to assume an artificial or pretended attitude     ##  ## With a President in power who often adopts a punitive posture toward those critical of him and hails those who praise him, the old point that government should not disfavor people’s speech based on the message has a jolting contemporary resonance.

flashcards.name: potential
flashcards.definition: [pəˈtenʃl] ## (1)adj. capable of becoming real      ## (2)n. a chance or possibility that something will happen or exist in the future      ## (3)n. an ability that someone has that can be developed to help that person become successful    ##  ## Even nostalgists can agree that Mario Carbone’s iteration has institutional potential.

flashcards.name: pragmatic
flashcards.definition: [prægˈmætɪk] ## adj. dealing with the problems that exist in a specific situation in a reasonable and logical way instead of depending on ideas and theories ##  ## realistic ##  ## Should we be surprised that the pragmatic son fared so much worse than his unpragmatic father? ##     68 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: preachy
flashcards.definition: [ˈpri:tʃi] ## adj. trying to teach something in a way that is annoying or unwanted       ## sanctimonious, didactic ##  ## Scott understood this, and, in a particularly preachy letter to Zelda, in 1932, he attributed his own success, and Lucienne’s, to their “long desperate heart-destroying professional training beginning.

flashcards.name: precarious
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈkeəriəs] ## adj. not safe, strong, or steady          ## perilous ##  ## Crowley’s other photos showed equally precarious scenes: the same toddler nonchalantly holding a large kitchen knife, climbing up a narrow ladder to the attic, or standing close to the edge of a seaside pier.

flashcards.name: precede
flashcards.definition: [prɪ'sid] ## v. to happen, go, or come before  ...    ## predate, antedate ##  ## We ask that your animals remain leashed or in pet carriers, and that birds be confined to cages and do not precede you onto the plane.

flashcards.name: precipitate
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈsɪpɪteɪt] ## (1)v. to cause to happen quickly or suddenly        ## (2)n. a solid substance that is separated from al liquid especially by a chemical process     ## (3)adj. happening very quickly or too quickly without enough thought or planning         ##  ## Democrats staged an all-night session in which Senators Chuck Schumer, Elizabeth Warren, and others voiced their objections to DeVos’s ideology, and to the precipitate process of her confirmation.

flashcards.name: preclude
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈklu:d] ## v. to make impossible by necessary consequence: rule out in advance ##  ## prevent, rule out ##  ## This had a kind of elegance that seemed to preclude the more brutish ambitions of Everest.

flashcards.name: precocious
flashcards.definition: [prɪ'kəʊʃəs] ## adj. exhibiting mature qualities at an unusually early age     ## mature ##  ## Few performances—and few films—glow as brightly with the gemlike fire of precocious genius.

flashcards.name: preconception
flashcards.definition: [ˌpri:kənˈsepʃn] ## n. an idea or opinion that someone has before learning about or experiencing something directly      ## prejudice ##  ## Generic environments are useful when the author needs the freedom to invent the peculiarities of the setting without disrupting a preconception of a real place.

flashcards.name: precursor
