flashcards.definition: [pri:ˈkɜ:sə] ## n. something that comes before something else and that often leads to or influences its development    ## forerunner ##  ## At that time, John Cassavetes had just made his first film, “Shadows” (the Criterion Channel), with the precursor to a Kickstarter campaign—he had gone on the radio to ask listeners to send money.

flashcards.name: predate
flashcards.definition: ['pri:'deɪt] ## v. to exist or happen at an earlier time than    ## antedate, precede ##  ## Though recent instances of terrorism in Europe are often claimed by isis, Belgium’s jihadi networks predate the Syrian war; after it began, they helped fuel the rise of its most extreme groups.

flashcards.name: predilection
flashcards.definition: [ˌpri:dɪˈlekʃn] ## n. a natural liking for something    ## proclivity, preference ##  ## President Trump’s world view seems to combine a distaste for Islam with a predilection for monarchs of any background—for anyone with a decent palace, really.

flashcards.name: predominant
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈdɒmɪnənt] ## adj. more important, powerful, successful, or noticeable than other people or things          ##  ## He told me that, since the attack, the predominant feeling in the area is still one of shock and horror.

flashcards.name: preeminent
flashcards.definition: [pri'ɛmɪnənt] ## adj. more important, skillful, or successful than others         ##  ## America’s preeminent museum finally embraces contemporary art.

flashcards.name: prefigure
flashcards.definition: [ˌpri:ˈfɪgə(r)] ## v. to show or suggest something that will happen or exist at a future time    ## anticipate ##  ## My favorite of the segments I’ve seen, the one featuring Miranda July in a set of visionary projects and performances that both prefigure and inform her own movies, isn’t online yet.

flashcards.name: prejudice
flashcards.definition: [ˈpredʒudɪs] ## (1)n. a feeling of like or dislike for someone or something especially when it is not reasonable or logical     ## (2)n. preconceived judgment or opinion      ## preconception ##       69 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The act of interfacing with prejudice itself has profound psychological implications, resulting in the sorts of trauma that last long beyond the incidents themselves.

flashcards.name: preoccupy
flashcards.definition: [priˈɒkjupaɪ] ## v. to be thought about or worried about by (someone) very often or constantly       ##  ## If Harpo had been endowed with the power of speech, he might have touched on the subjects that urgently preoccupy McBurney, which are mystery, love, and the nature of time.

flashcards.name: presage
flashcards.definition: [ˈpresɪdʒ] ## v. to give or be a sign of    ## portend ##  ## Even in Britain, whose unexpected vote in favor of exiting the E.U. seemed to presage its collapse, Theresa May and her pro- Brexit party fared poorly in the recent general election.

flashcards.name: prescient
flashcards.definition: [ˈpresiənt] ## adj. able to know or predict what was going to happen in the future         ## prophetic ##  ## Connie Converse’s songs, misfits in their own time, seem eerily prescient today in expressing our ache and ambivalence.

flashcards.name: prescriptive
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈskrɪptɪv] ## adj. giving exact rules, directions, or instructions about how you should do something         ## exacting ##  ## The changes sought to make the text descriptive, rather than prescriptive. ## Day 6 ## Great works are performed not by strength, but by perseverance.

flashcards.name: preside
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈzaɪd] ## v. to be in charge of something    ##  ## During the Harlem Renaissance, Alain Locke presided over the first flourishing of a self-consciously racial art movement in America and was widely credited with providing the philosophical basis for its emergence.

flashcards.name: pressing
flashcards.definition: ['prɛsɪŋ] ## adj. urgently important         ## exigent, critical ##  ## Will these measures help alleviate the most pressing economic problems facing the country, such as sharply rising inequality and the stagnant growth in wages and productivity?

flashcards.name: prestige
flashcards.definition: [preˈsti:ʒ] ## n. the respect and admiration that someone or something gets for being successful or important    ##  ## While the show begins with a Schadenfreudian air—a prestige-TV twist on “Real Housewives”—it deepens, and becomes a sensitive reflection on trauma.

flashcards.name: preternatural
flashcards.definition: [ˌpri:təˈnætʃrəl] ## adj. very unusual in a way that does not seem natural       ## exceptional ##  ## Harris notes “Nick’s desire to understand and convey the interior lives of his subjects,” which explains why many of his images “burn with such preternatural intensity and eloquence.”

flashcards.name: pretext
flashcards.definition: [ˈpri:tekst] ## n. a reason that you give to hide your real reason for doing something ##  ##  ## According to ICE, these measures will help combat “a constant humanitarian threat,” but the agent said that rationale was just a pretext to increase arrests and eventually deport more people.

flashcards.name: prevail
flashcards.definition: [prɪˈveɪl] ## (1)v. to be usual, common, or popular     ## (2)v. to defeat an opponent especially in a long or difficult contest      ##  ## Despite some bitter exchanges between the Clinton and Sanders camps this week, cooler heads are likely to prevail after the primaries on June 7th.

flashcards.name: prevalent
flashcards.definition: [ˈprevələnt] ## adj. accepted, done, or happening often or over a large area at a particular time         ## widespread, extensive ##  ## The type is so prevalent that it even has a name: flower boys.

flashcards.name: prevaricate
flashcards.definition: [prɪ'værə'ket] ## v. to deviate from the truth      ##  ## The state continues to waver and prevaricate.

flashcards.name: primitive
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɪmətɪv] ## (1)adj. of, belonging to, or seeming to come from an early time in the very ancient past      ## (2)adj. very simple and basic         ## rudimentary, ancient ##  ## Because the single most striking thing about his matchlessly strange first week is how primitive, atavistic, and uncomplicatedly brutal Trump’s brand of authoritarianism is turning out to be. ## 70 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: pristine
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɪsti:n] ## (1)adj. belonging to the earliest period or state      (2)adj. not spoiled, corrupted, or polluted     ## unblemished ##  ## Stephen, with your eyes closed, I want you to imagine you’re on a pristine white-sand beach.

flashcards.name: privilege
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɪvəlɪdʒ] ## n. a right or immunity granted as a peculiar benefit, advantage, or favor ##  ##  ## I’m not at the Sundance Film Festival this year, but I’ve had the privilege of seeing some films that are playing there.

flashcards.name: probity
flashcards.definition: [ˈprəʊbəti] ## n. the quality of a person who is completely honest       ##  ## Kushner seems to see himself and his wife, Ivanka, as lonely voices of probity and moderation in an otherwise unhinged West Wing.

flashcards.name: proclaim
flashcards.definition: [prəˈkleɪm] ## (1)v. to say or state in a public, official, or definite way     (2)v. to show clearly    ## profess ##  ## Three years ago, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi chose the Great Mosque of al-Nuri, in Mosul, as the site to proclaim his new Islamic State.

flashcards.name: proclivity
flashcards.definition: [prəˈklɪvəti] ## n. a strong natural liking for something that is usually bad       ## predilection ##  ## In the case of Iran, while a formal policy “review” is still ongoing, Trump’s own proclivity for bluster, and apparent obsession with undoing whatever President Barack Obama did, is already leading in a dangerous direction.

flashcards.name: prodigious
flashcards.definition: [prə'dɪdʒəs] ## adj. extraordinary in bulk, quantity, or degree     ## voracious ##  ## Joshua Cohen’s stylistic gifts are prodigious, but does “Moving Kings” live up to its ambitions?

flashcards.name: profess
flashcards.definition: [prəˈfes] ## (1)v. to say or declare openly       (2)v. to believe in (a particular religion)    ## proclaim ##  ## The reason that the Clinton and the Trump campaigns are embracing negativity, a strategy that so many voters profess to detest, is somewhat paradoxical: it works.

flashcards.name: proficient
flashcards.definition: [prə'fɪʃənt] ## adj. good at doing something     ## adept ##  ## At I.B.M., engineers have used natural-language processing and enormous computational power to beat the most proficient humans at our own games, like chess and “Jeopardy!”

flashcards.name: profitmonger
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɒfɪt'mʌŋgə] ## n.           ##  ## Attacking what he calls the “auteur myth”—the idea of the director as the single purveyor of art in an industry otherwise peopled with profitmongers—he places at the heart of his book an image of the producer, not the director, as the primary creative force in the development and production of a movie.

flashcards.name: profligate
flashcards.definition: [prɑfləɡɪt] ## adj. wildly extravagant     ## extravagant, prodigal ##  ## Nonetheless, I had a lot more fun with “Hudson Hawk” than I ever did with “Die Hard” or “The Terminator,” because it offers, from beginning to end, such a prodigious, even profligate, display of imagination.

flashcards.name: profound
flashcards.definition: [prəˈfaʊnd] ## (1)adj. having or showing great knowledge or understanding      (2)adj. difficult to understand      ## (3)adj. coming from, reaching to, or situated at a depth     ## trenchant ##  ## The pleasure of being necessary to my parents was profound. I was not like the children in folktales: burdensome mouths to feed.

flashcards.name: profusion
flashcards.definition: [prəˈfju:ʒn] ## n. a large amount of something    ## wealth ##  ## “Song to Song” offers a dazzling profusion of perspectives and angles, in some of the most radically inflected points of view since the heyday of Dziga Vertov.

flashcards.name: proliferate
flashcards.definition: [prəˈlɪfəreɪt] ## v. to increase in number or amount quickly    ## abound ##  ## That role eroded in the nineteen-eighties and nineties, when Republicans and Democrats reduced the constraints, allowing junk mortgages and the exotic financial products based on them to proliferate.

flashcards.name: prolix
flashcards.definition: [prəʊ'lɪks] ## adj. using too many words     ## verbose, long-winded ##  ## I had no idea how Word made this calculation, but I noticed that it rewarded prolix sentences with a higher “grade.”

flashcards.name: prominent
flashcards.definition: ['prɒmɪnənt] ## adj. easily notice or seen     ## conspicuous, salient ## 71 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Hamed Sinno, the lead singer and lyricist of the Lebanese group Mashrou’ Leila, may be the most prominent gay musician in the Arab world.

flashcards.name: promise
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɒmɪs] ## (1)n. an indication of future success or improvement        ## (2)n. a reason to expect that something will happen in the future    ##  ## Instead of demonstrating the promise of archaeological applications of electronic remote sensing, the pioneering study became, to some skeptics, an illustration of the imprudence of interpreting sites based on virtual archaeology.

flashcards.name: prompt
flashcards.definition: [prɒmpt] ## (1)v. to cause to do something     ## (2)adj. performed readily or immediately     ##  ## He’d file a petition to prompt an immediate vote on the Bridge Act.

flashcards.name: prophetic
flashcards.definition: [prəˈfetɪk] ## adj. forestelling events      ## prescient ##  ## The line seemed to describe, prophetically and a bit self-consciously, the mood that might await the nation on Wednesday morning.

flashcards.name: propitious
flashcards.definition: [prəˈpɪʃəs] ## adj. likely to have or produce good results     ## auspicious ##  ## So Mary and Michael put off declaring their intentions to leave each other—and while they await the propitious moment to do so, they rekindle their sexual relationship, in effect having an affair with each other and cheating on their lovers.

flashcards.name: proponent
flashcards.definition: [prə'pəʊnənt] ## n. a person who argues for or supports something     ## defender, champion ##  ## Lucius Riccio is the originator and chief proponent of pothole analytics. Thanks to him, we understand paving much better.

flashcards.name: proprietary
flashcards.definition: [prəˈpraɪətri] ## (1)adj. used, made, or sold only by the particular person or company that has the legal right to do so      ## (2)adj. kept private by an owner       ##  ## Shaw was loyal to the growers who depended on his cultivars and uninterested in working with proprietary companies like Driscoll’s.

flashcards.name: prosaic
flashcards.definition: [prə'zeɪk] ## adj. dull or ordinary     ##  ## In this prosaic pursuit they sometimes kick loose aesthetic revelation.

flashcards.name: protean
flashcards.definition: [ˈprəʊtiən] ## (1)adj. able to change into many different forms or able to do many different things        ## (2)adj. displaying great diversity or variety       ## versatile ##  ## Twenty-five years after his death, the protean musician Arthur Russell has become a kind of deity among a new generation of fans.

flashcards.name: protract
flashcards.definition: [prəˈtrækt] ## (1)v. delay, defer     ## (2)v. to extend forward or outward    ##  ## Schiff mocked the pianists who protract the long third movement to show that “we are very deep and profound.

flashcards.name: provenance
flashcards.definition: [ˈprɒvənəns] ## n. the origin or source of something    ## origin ##  ## Professor Pieixoto has just presented a paper, titled “Problems of Authentication in Reference to the Handmaid’s Tale,” which explains the provenance of the Handmaid’s story.

flashcards.name: provincial
flashcards.definition: [prəˈvɪnʃl] ## (1)adj. not knowing or caring about people and events in other places      ## (2)adj. of, relating to, or coming from a province    ## insular ##  ## The irony of digital networking is that it can produce more provincialism than did the geographical confinement it supposedly transcended.

flashcards.name: provocative
flashcards.definition: [prəˈvɒkətɪv] ## (1)adj. causing discussion, thought, argument, etc.      (2)adj. serving or tending to provoke, excite, or stimulate     ## inflammatory ##  ## The provocative thinker Sunaura Taylor speaks out against the tyranny of ableism.

flashcards.name: proximity
flashcards.definition: [prɒkˈsɪməti] ## n. the state of being near    ##  ## She was not stimulated by the proximity of violence and privation.

flashcards.name: prudent
flashcards.definition: [ˈpru:dnt] ## adj. having or showing careful good judgment     ## circumspect, provident ## 72 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The spokesman gave no reason for the abrupt cancellation, but said that al-Baghdadi no longer felt that meeting with Penn would be “prudent.”

flashcards.name: prying
flashcards.definition: ['praiiŋ] ## adj. trying to find out about other people’s private lives           ##  ## Stubbs, Westworld’s hunky head of security, is apparently the only one other than Bernard who has noticed that poor Elsie, Bernard’s prying assistant, vanished two episodes ago.

flashcards.name: pseudonym
flashcards.definition: [ˈsu:dənɪm] ## n. a name that someone uses instead of his or her real name        ##  ## The new book “Manly Health and Training” collects a series of advice columns that Whitman wrote under a pseudonym in 1858.

flashcards.name: pugnacious
flashcards.definition: [pʌgˈneɪʃəs] ## adj. showing a readiness or desire to fight or argue     ## truculent, belligerent ##  ## It’s probably what you’d expect from someone with a personality not unlike our President’s—thin-skinned and pugnacious, with a tendency to treat women as chattel.

flashcards.name: puncture
flashcards.definition: [ˈpʌŋktʃə] ## (1)v. to weaken, damage, or destroy suddenly or in a way that causes surprise or embarrassment       ## (2)v. to make a hole in with a sharp point    ##  ## She knew that she had very little time to puncture Thurmond’s “camera” persona.

flashcards.name: purport
flashcards.definition: [pəˈpɔ:t] ## (1)v. to claim to be or do a particular thing when this claim may not be true         ## (2)n. the main or general meaning of something    ##  ## In its title and introduction, the book purports to be conversant with contemporary discourse in the field, but in its actual analysis of Wharton’s work, it is marked by a very old-fashioned approach.

flashcards.name: purview
flashcards.definition: [ˈpɜ:vju:] ## n. an area within which someone or something has authority, influence, or knowledge    ##  ## Despite the movie's broad purview, Rouquier maintains a documentary-based interest in the details of farm life and in family relations. ## put to rest ## phrase.    ## eliminated ##  ## In American Indian art, the supposed distinction between modern and traditional was fabricated by critics, and when artists have control over interpretation of their own work, the distinction appear, happily, to have been put to rest.

flashcards.name: quaff
flashcards.definition: [kwɒf] ## v. to drink a large amount of quickly    ## imbibe ##  ## Press it to your lips and quaff, quaff till you’re breathless.

flashcards.name: qualify
flashcards.definition: [ˈkwɒlɪfaɪ] ## (1)v. to give the necessary skill or knowledge to do a particular job or activity       ## (2)v. to limit or modify the meaning of    ##  ## Later in the book, the author takes pains to qualify the claims she had made earlier, as though she recognizes their implausibility and wants to quell skepticism by narrowing their scope.

flashcards.name: quash
flashcards.definition: [kwɒʃ] ## (1)v. to suppress or extinguish summarily and completely     (2)v. to nullify especially by judicial action    ##  ## The difference is that, in the past, Brazilian politicians could quash any investigation that threatened them.

flashcards.name: query
flashcards.definition: ['kwɪərɪ] ## v. to ask questions or express doubt about    ##  ## The anthropologist queried the claim that the Neanderthal remains must represent an immediate family because they belong to the same mitochondrial lineage, noting that some chimpanzees with identical mitochondrial are not closely related.

flashcards.name: quiescent
flashcards.definition: [kwiˈesnt] ## adj. marked by inactivity or repose          ## abeyant, calm ##  ## It was also a simple acknowledgment that, with inflation quiescent and economic growth still tepid, there isn’t a good case for raising rates.

flashcards.name: quirky
flashcards.definition: ['kwɜ:kɪ] ## adj. odd or unpredictable in their appearance, character, or behavior.      ## unconventional ##  ## The reissue of Moore’s original work will shift the perception of Moore from a quirky but somewhat cold formalist to a restlessly imaginative experimenter. ## 73 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: quixotic
flashcards.definition: [kwɪkˈsɒtɪk] ## adj. hopeful or romantic in a way that is not practical       ## idealistic ##  ## Hadreas, who has described himself as a “gloomy bitch,” has a dry, quixotic sense of humor.

flashcards.name: quotidian
flashcards.definition: [kwɒˈtɪdiən] ## (1)adj. ordinary or very common          (2)adj. done each day     ## workday ##  ## In “Salad for President,” Julia Sherman explores the idea that even artists’ most quotidian practices, including cooking and eating, inform their work.

flashcards.name: radical
flashcards.definition: [ˈrædɪkəl] ## (1)adj. having extreme political or social views that are not shared by most people      ## (2)adj. very basic and important         ##  ## What I’m trying to cultivate is not blind optimism but what the philosopher Jonathan Lear calls radical hope.

flashcards.name: raillery
flashcards.definition: [ˈreɪləri] ## n. friendly joking about or with somebody     ## banter ##  ## Instead, the movie plunges into the mid-sixteen-seventies, with Charles II (John Malkovich) long since restored to the throne and an elegant raillery unloosed upon the stage.

flashcards.name: rally
flashcards.definition: [ˈræli] ## v. to muster for a common purpose       ##  ## The true believers are persistent, critiquing each new study that challenges their views, and rallying to the defense of disgraced researchers whose work was retracted.

flashcards.name: rampant
flashcards.definition: [ˈræmpənt] ## adj. growing quickly and in a way that is difficult to control          ## luxuriant ##  ## The unexpected election of Donald Trump is said to owe debts to both niche extremism and rampant misinformation.

flashcards.name: rant
flashcards.definition: [rænt] ## (1)v. to talk loudly and in a way that shows anger     (2)v. to scold vehemently      ## diatribe ##  ## Trump has been on the road for the past couple of days, continuing the scorched-earth campaign he set out on last week, ranting about a giant conspiracy involving the 'global power structure,' a nefarious media, and the Hillary Clinton campaign.

flashcards.name: rapacious
flashcards.definition: [rəˈpeɪʃəs] ## adj. excessively grasping or covetous     ## avaricious ##  ## In general, my friend loathes what he perceives as the rapacious capitalist cynicism of all the money-grubbing liars.

flashcards.name: rapprochement
flashcards.definition: [ræ'prɒʃmɒ̃] ## n. the development of friendlier relations between countries or groups of people who have been enemies    ## reconciliation ##  ## The end of the “wet foot, dry foot” immigration policy could buttress President Obama’s historic rapprochement with Havana.

flashcards.name: rationale
flashcards.definition: [ˌræʃəˈnɑ:l] ## n. the reason or explanation for something           ##  ## He also dismissed as “clowns” the right-wing contingents that descended on Charlottesville, and made a broader indictment of “ethno-nationalism,” the rationale for those groups’ existence.

flashcards.name: rattle
flashcards.definition: [ˈrætl] ## v. to make nervous         ##  ## The occasional mix-ups rattle candidates on the trail despite the presence of political strategist’s plotting every event with the tactical precision of military commanders.

flashcards.name: reactivate
flashcards.definition: [riˈæktɪveɪt] ## v. to make it work again after a period in which it has not been working ##  ##  ## The idea that he had a “story” to tell appeared to strike him as unseemly, as if the details could reactivate the past—an attitude that hurt him during his legal proceedings.

flashcards.name: readable
flashcards.definition: [ˈri:dəbl] ## (1)adj. clear and easy to read        (2)adj. easy and enjoyable to read       ## intelligible ##  ## At this distance the words on the screen that accompanied the images were just barely readable.

flashcards.name: realize
flashcards.definition: [ˈri:əlaɪz] ## (1)v. to understand or become aware of      (2)v. to achieve    ## achieve ##  ## The painter’s problem, like that of an author whose early literary masterpiece exhausts the themes it embodies, is how to realize his first highly acclaimed efforts with works of comparable significance and presence.

flashcards.name: rebuff
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈbʌf] ## v. to refuse in a rude way    ## 74 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Immediately after Macron’s victory last week, Merkel and other German politicians appeared to rebuff Macron’s proposals.

flashcards.name: recant
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈkænt] ## v. to publicly say that you no longer have an opinion or belief that you once had      ## repudiate ##  ## The last time Detroit’s C.E.O.s came to the White House, in 2011, President Obama got them to agree, grudgingly, to increase average fuel economy to 54.5 miles per gallon, a pledge they now hope to recant.

flashcards.name: recapitulate
flashcards.definition: ['rikə'pɪtʃə'let] ## v. to give a brief summary of something    ##  ## Thinking that she could add credibility and detail to his work on the sporelike cells, he asked her to recapitulate the study, employing the latest techniques in stem-cell research.

flashcards.name: recast
flashcards.definition: [ˌri:ˈkɑ:st] ## v. remodel, refashion    ##  ## Anthropologist Jane Goodall was stalwart in her determination to anthropomorphize the animals she observed with such empathy, and so resisted her editors’ attempt to recast her descriptions in more dispassionate language.

flashcards.name: reckon
flashcards.definition: [ˈrekən] ## (1)v. to regard or think of as     (2)v. estimate, compute    ## gauge ##  ## The first season of “Westworld” fused the robot-rebellion genre with mythology of the American West, but it failed to reckon with the racial implications of its fictional civil war.

flashcards.name: recoil
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈkɔɪl] ## v. to quickly move away from something that is shocking, frightening, or disgusting       ## shrink ##  ## Modern readers may recoil, or laugh; so did some nineteenth-century ones, among them Mark Twain, who, in 1870, wrote a parody, titled “The Story of the Good Little Boy Who Did Not Prosper.”

flashcards.name: reconciliation
flashcards.definition: [ˌrekənsɪliˈeɪʃn] ## n. the act of causing two people or groups to become friendly again after an argument or disagreement    ## rapprochement ##  ## Is reconciliation possible after the election?

flashcards.name: recondite
flashcards.definition: [ˈrekəndaɪt] ## adj. not understood or known by many people       ## esoteric, arcane, abstruse ##  ## His works bristle with recondite influences and ideas.

flashcards.name: recrudescent
flashcards.definition: [,ri:kru:'desnt] ## adj. breaking out again     ## resurgent ##  ## Ironically, it was when Russia was ruled by a Georgian—Stalin—that cruelty toward people of the Caucasus was most vehemently recrudescent.

flashcards.name: redouble
flashcards.definition: [,ri'dʌbl] ## v. to greatly increase the size or amount of      ##  ## Which Republicans in the Senate and House might redouble their commitment to the Russia investigation, and which will continue to help the White House deny the story?

flashcards.name: redundant
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'dʌndənt] ## adj. repeating something else and therefore unnecessary     ##  ## Measuring these parameters accurately enough might even make the race itself redundant, allowing the winner to be anointed in the lab before the starting gun fires.

flashcards.name: regular
flashcards.definition: ['rɛgjəlɚ] ## adj. happening or done very often      ## abundant ##  ## Precipitation is not regular in the Atacama Desert west of Andes mountains, and water scarcity is compounded by problems with water appropriation, the existence of agro pastoralists is in jeopardy.

flashcards.name: rehabilitate
flashcards.definition: [ˌri:əˈbɪlɪteɪt] ## v. to restore to a former state    ## restore ##  ## The treatment program implemented there was contingent upon the idea that work itself proffers enough distraction and purpose to help rehabilitate an addict.

flashcards.name: rehash
flashcards.definition: [ˌri:ˈhæʃ] ## v. to present again in a slightly different form          ## recycle ##  ## I'm hoping that, if we lose, it's in a super-undramatic way that won't be memorable enough for ESPN to rehash to death.

flashcards.name: rein
flashcards.definition: [reɪn] ## v. to control or direct with or as if with reins       ##  ## Trump can rescind any of Obama’s executive orders at the stroke of a pen, and he can shift the regulatory machinery of the executive branch so that Obama’s climate-change plan and rules reining in Wall Street are upended.

flashcards.name: reinvent
flashcards.definition: [ˌriɪnˈvɛnt] ## v. to make major changes or improvements to    ##  ## Women who reinvent themselves are as varied as their ambitions for distinction. ## 75 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: rejection
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'dʒekʃn] ## n. the action of rejecting       ## liberation from ##  ## Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron have become symbols of either the ratification or the rejection of the populist wave that led to Brexit and Trump.

flashcards.name: relic
flashcards.definition: [ˈrelɪk] ## n. something that is from a past time, place, culture, etc.    ## vestige ##  ## In 2017, Linkin Park’s sound—a convulsive and visceral synthesis of rock, rap, and industrial music—feels like a curious relic of some long-ago era.

flashcards.name: relief
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈli:f] ## n. the removal or reducing of something that is painful or unpleasant     ## respite ##  ## An organization worked to bring relief to Houston residents following the disaster. It didn’t occur to them that they were victims, too.

flashcards.name: relinquish
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'lɪŋkwɪʃ] ## v. to give up    ## cede ##  ## The process, she suggests, is twofold: first you relinquish the thing you loved, then you relinquish the part of yourself that loved it.

flashcards.name: relish
flashcards.definition: [ˈrelɪʃ] ## v. to enjoy or take pleasure in    ## delight in ##  ## When I was young it meant time with my dad, and now that I’m a father myself I relish the long summer days spent with my own children.

flashcards.name: reluctant
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈlʌktənt] ## adj. feeling or showing doubt about doing something: not willing or eager to do something      ## unwilling, loath ##  ## Some displaced people have returned, reluctantly, to Mosul, Ablaha told me, because the local government said they would have to come back soon to reclaim jobs—and paychecks—from before the isis takeover.

flashcards.name: remarkable
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'mɑːkəbl] ## adj. unusual or surprising: likely to be noticed        ##  ## Vang’s “Afterland” and Matthews’s “Simulacra” are remarkable, virtuosic collections from young poets.

flashcards.name: remedy
flashcards.definition: [ˈremədi] ## (1)n. a medicine or treatment that relieves pain or cures a usually minor illness       ## (2)n. a way of solving or correcting a problem       ## (3)v. to solve, correct, or improve       ## panacea ##  ## Steve goes into the bathroom at the party in search of a remedy. While he’s going through Chloe’s medicine cabinet, he keeps an eye out for prescriptions that might be suppressing her desire for him.

flashcards.name: remiss
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈmɪs] ## adj. not showing enough care and attention     ## dilatory ##  ## The F.B.I. would be remiss to turn a blind eye to such collaborations.

flashcards.name: renaissance
flashcards.definition: ['rɛnəsɑns] ## n. a period of new growth or activity    ## revival ##  ## Kasparov declared that “now, here in St. Louis, we are facing the renaissance of the great game of chess.”

flashcards.name: reprehensible
flashcards.definition: [,rɛprɪ'hɛnsəbl] ## adj. deserving very strong criticism       ## deplorable ##  ## The fact that Betsy DeVos reportedly had concerns about the safety of transgender kids makes her capitulation to Trump and Jeff Sessions all the more reprehensible.

flashcards.name: repudiate
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈpju:dieɪt] ## (1)v. to refuse to accept or support       ## (2)v. to refuse to having anything to do with  ...     ## recant ##  ## President Trump’s remarks today repudiate his forced remarks yesterday about the KKK and neo-Nazis.

flashcards.name: requisite
flashcards.definition: [ˈrekwɪzɪt] ## adj. needed for a particular purpose     ## essential ##  ## He also has the requisite power suit, thanks to the patronage of Tony Stark (Robert Downey, Jr.), but he needs to earn his stripes before he can join the noble regiment of Avengers.

flashcards.name: resemblance
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈzembləns] ## n. the state of looking or being like someone or something else    ## homogeneity ##  ## The new show stars the alter kakers George St. Geegland and Gil Faizon, who bear a curious resemblance to the comedians John Mulaney and Nick Kroll.

flashcards.name: reserved
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈzɜ:vd] ## (1)adj. restrained in words and actions          ## (2)adj. kept or set apart or aside for future or special use     ## 76 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Even the man was reserved in his speech, he thoroughly understood his mother, which made him far from simple as people usually thought.

flashcards.name: resolve
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈzɒlv] ## (1)v. to find an answer or solution to     ## (2)v. to make a definite and serious decision to do something     (3)n. a strong determination to do something    ## tenacity ##  ## People enjoy listening to the governor’s inspiring speeches, and his eloquence lulls his adversaries into underestimating his resolve, the tempered steel beneath the sleek suits.

flashcards.name: resonate
flashcards.definition: [ˈrezəneɪt] ## (1)v. to have particular meaning or importance for someone           ## (2)v. to continue to produce a loud, clear, deep sound for a long time      ## (3)v. to relate harmoniously    ## ring true ##  ## I would like to stop reading about this disaffected sliver of the electorate and instead read about attempts to mobilize progressives and people of color around a platform that might even resonate with W.W.C. voters, wherever they live.

flashcards.name: respite
flashcards.definition: [ˈrespaɪt] ## n. an interval of rest or relief    ## lull, relief, break ##  ## Ted Cruz’s big win over Donald Trump on Tuesday in Utah has only given anti-Trump Republicans, like Mitt Romney, a brief respite. But it was a significant one.

flashcards.name: responsive
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈspɒnsɪv] ## adj. quick to react or respond       ##  ## Instead of starting a “one-off school,” he would create an educational “ecosystem” that was unusually responsive to the interests of children, feeding them assignments tied to subjects they cared about.

flashcards.name: restive
flashcards.definition: [ˈrestɪv] ## adj. feeling bored or impatient while waiting for something to happen or change       ## fractious ##  ## He was writing about “A Doll’s House,” his proto-feminist masterwork, which concludes with Nora Helmer, a restive Norwegian housewife, walking out on her husband, Torval

flashcards.name: restorative
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈstɔ:rətɪv] ## adj. having the ability to make a person feel strong or healthy again        ## tonic ##  ## At his new restaurant, Jean-Georges Vongerichten serves meatless dishes, juices, and restorative tonics, but he won’t call it vegetarian.

flashcards.name: restrain
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈstreɪn] ## (1)v. to prevent from doing something     (2)v. to keep under control    ##  ## Even there he can’t restrain himself from the already-clichés of the series, and vitiates the mighty and terrifying vision of sexual violence, moral horror, and emotional dislocation with grandstanding ornamental fancies.

flashcards.name: resurgent
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'sɜːdʒənt] ## adj. experiencing or tending to bring about renewal or revival     ##  ## In a climate of resurgent anti-Semitism, homophobia, and hostility to immigrants, the success of “Indecent” feels defiant, if not triumphant.

flashcards.name: retain
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈteɪn] ## v. to keep in a position, job, etc.    ##  ## On Sunday, the people of France annoyingly retained their traditional right to claim intellectual superiority over Americans, as millions of French citizens paused to enjoy just how much smarter they were than their allies across the Atlantic.

flashcards.name: reticent
flashcards.definition: [ˈretɪsnt] ## adj. not willing to tell people about things     ##  ## The music sometimes surges in a big wave, but the choreography will be reticent, even sweet: fluffy little lifts, or developpé lifts.

flashcards.name: retreat
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈtri:t] ## n. movement away from a place or situation especially because it is dangerous, unpleasant, etc.    ##  ## Residents who initially opposed the retreat came around after repeated inundations, and the government’s initiative helped not only them but also many thousands of others downstream.

flashcards.name: reverence
flashcards.definition: ['rɛvərəns] ## n. honor or respect that is felt for or shown to    ## veneration ##  ## Throughout his political life, John McCain has enjoyed bipartisan respect and even reverence.

flashcards.name: reverse
flashcards.definition: [rɪ'vɜːs] ## v. to change to an opposite state or condition       ##  ## Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is being dispatched to Pyongyang in what the White House is calling a high-stakes mission to reverse North Korea’s years of progress in math and science. ## 77 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: revision
flashcards.definition: [rɪˈvɪʒn] ## n. a change or a set of changes that corrects or improves something     ## emendation ##  ## Last year, Gold pulled the production from Theatre for a New Audience’s upcoming schedule, citing artistic differences— apparently his revision of the text was too out-there.

flashcards.name: revolutionary
flashcards.definition: [ˌrevəˈlu:ʃənəri] ## adj. causing or related to a great complete change      ##  ## After the death of revolutionary leader Ayatollah Khomeini, in 1989, Rafsanjani engineered a constitutional amendment that eliminated the position of Prime Minister and transferred power to an executive President.

flashcards.name: riddle
flashcards.definition: [ˈrɪdl] ## n. a mystifying, misleading, or puzzling question posed as a problem to be solved or guessed   ## conundrum, enigma, puzzle ##  ## Pericles falls in love with a princess, then, by correctly guessing the answer to a riddle, discovers that she’s ensnared in an incestuous relationship with her tyrannical father, the king, who threatens to kill him.

flashcards.name: ridicule
flashcards.definition: [ˈrɪdɪkju:l] ## n. the act of making fun of someone or something in a cruel or harsh way     ## v. to laugh at and make jokes about in a cruel or harsh way    ## derision ##  ## As of late Saturday, the plans for the protest had drawn ridicule from Kellyanne Conway, a trusted Trump adviser.

flashcards.name: rigor
flashcards.definition: ['rɪgɚ] ## n. the quality or state of being very exact, careful, or strict    ##  ## Despite Brown’s insistence on the rigor of Fitzgerald’s thinking, the book suggests that he was ensnared by the very social trappings he disdained. ## ring true ## phrase.      ## resonate ##  ## Caricature can be revealing as well as amusing, and Ager’s novel is both: Ager’s delineation of class, ethnic, and generational struggle is exaggerated for comical effect, but it rings true nonetheless.

flashcards.name: risible
flashcards.definition: [ˈrɪzəbl] ## adj. deserving to be laughed at     ## ludicrous ##  ## A belief that we are exempt from the true horrors of human behavior and the accompanying false sense of security have led to nearly risible responses to Trumpism.

flashcards.name: ritualize
flashcards.definition: [ˈrɪtʃuəlaɪz] ## v. to make a ritual of  ...    ##  ## In the same way that poker ritualizes capitalism and North Korea’s mass games ritualize totalitarianism, the people’s mike ritualizes horizontalism.

flashcards.name: robust
flashcards.definition: [rəʊˈbʌst] ## (1)adj. strong and healthy      ## (2)adj. successful or impressive and not likely to fail or weaken       ## strong ##  ## This aesthetic of robust preciousness is so much a part of our lives now that we take much of it for granted.

flashcards.name: routine
flashcards.definition: [ru:ˈti:n] ## adj. of a commonplace or repetitious character       ##  ## The bombing at Atatürk International Airport was the sixth major terrorist attack in Turkey this year. The response to these events has become almost routine.

flashcards.name: row
flashcards.definition: [ro] ## n. a noisy disturbance or quarrel    ##  ## The incipient row regarding taxes could affect trade between the two countries much more than the festering dispute over banana imports, which has been going on for years. Unfortunately, the trade regulators seem to be ignoring both disagreements.

flashcards.name: rudimentary
flashcards.definition: [ˌru:dɪˈmentri] ## (1)adj. basic or simple      ## (2)adj. not very developed or advanced        ## primitive, sketchy, embryonic, sketchy, elemental ##  ## Most of our industries require people who can read, write, and do arithmetic, even in a rudimentary way. ## rule out ## phrase.    ## preclude ##  ## Analysis for the structural feather that were thought to rule out kinship between the two species prompted an investigation that dispelled that presumption and revealed that the two share a family history.

flashcards.name: ruminate
flashcards.definition: ['rumɪnet] ## v. to think carefully and deeply about something      ##  ## I knew that whatever happened I would ruminate upon this case for years.

flashcards.name: sacrifice
flashcards.definition: [ˈsækrɪfaɪs] ## n. something given up or lost    ## 78 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Punk is contingent upon the body, and there are few artists whose physical sacrifice has felt as generative or as essential as Iggy Pop’s.

flashcards.name: sacrosanct
flashcards.definition: [ˈsækrəʊsæŋkt] ## adj. too important and respected to be changed, criticized, etc.          ##  ## Most significant, the week after Trump signed his now unravelling travel ban, the Museum of Modern Art replaced seven works in its sacrosanct fifth-floor galleries.

flashcards.name: safeguard
flashcards.definition: ['sefɡɑrd] ## v. to make safe or secure    ## preserve ##  ## At its head sat a barely literate man, rude and reckless, a rascally treasure hunter installed by a beleaguered group of purists eager to safeguard their privileges and padlock their ranks.

flashcards.name: salient
flashcards.definition: [ˈseɪliənt] ## adj. very important or noticeable         ## visible, prominent, obtrusive, conspicuous ##  ## It is in this respect that Le Pen’s book seems most salient at the present, when women in several countries are playing crucial roles in promoting and sanitizing far-right populism.

flashcards.name: salubrious
flashcards.definition: [sə'lubrɪəs] ## adj. making good health possible or likely       ##  ## The fare in this shanty doesn’t follow today’s trends, which insist that the ocean’s bounty should be light, salubrious, and, hopefully, mercury free.

flashcards.name: salutary
flashcards.definition: [ˈsæljətri] ## adj. having a good or helpful result especially after something unpleasant has happened     ##  ## He also gave us a salutary fable, showing how vital that new arrival’s contribution might be—how it might enrich a culture that extends back before even forgotten Anglo-Saxon chiefs—when good will prevails.

flashcards.name: sanctimonious
flashcards.definition: [ˌsæŋktɪˈməʊniəs] ## adj. pretending to be morally better than other people             ## preachy, didactic ##  ## I couldn’t figure out if he was the most sanctimonious guy I ever met in my life, or the most arrogant.

flashcards.name: sanction
flashcards.definition: [ˈsæŋkʃn] ## (1)n. an action that is taken or an order that is given to force a country to obey international laws by limiting or stopping trade with that country, ## by not allowing economic aid for that country, etc.         (2)v. to officially accept or allow    ## endorse ##  ## And if anyone shall be led by his cupidity or arrogance to break this truce, by the authority of God and with the sanction of this Council he shall be anathematized.”

flashcards.name: sanguine
flashcards.definition: [ˈsæŋgwɪn] ## adj. confident and hopeful     ## optimistic ##  ## Hafner is sanguine about the trade-off that climate change has presented. “What we should do as archeologists is use the situation and learn as much as possible,” he said.

flashcards.name: sanity
flashcards.definition: [ˈsænəti] ## (1)n. the condition of having a healthy mind       ## (2)n. the condition of being based on reason or good judgment       ##  ## In the interim, there are lots of ways to get involved and retain your sanity.

flashcards.name: sartorial
flashcards.definition: [sɑr'tɔrɪəl] ## adj. of or relating to clothes         ##  ## He reminds his hip-hop-elder-statesmen peers that “Tupac had a nose ring”—a defense of the flamboyant sartorial choices of today’s youth.

flashcards.name: scant
flashcards.definition: [skænt] ## adj. very small in size or amount     ## limited ##  ## Rappers and punks are among the only folks getting paid in cash these days, anyway: scant amounts handed off in full, ahead of the set, no matter whether the cops shut the show down or no

flashcards.name: scarce
flashcards.definition: [skeəs] ## adj. very small in amount or number     ## deficient ##  ## As water and food become increasingly scarce, neighbor will turn against neighbor.

flashcards.name: scaremonger
flashcards.definition: [ˈskeəmʌŋgə] ## n. one inclined to raise or excite alarms especially needlessly        ##  ## He was a scaremonger, railing against “Communistic labor-leader racketeers” and politically controlled newspapers. ## 79 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: schism
flashcards.definition: [ˈskɪzəm] ## n. a division among the members of a group that occurs because they disagree on something    ## factiousness ##  ## The biggest schism today is between Al Qaeda and isis, the world’s two deadliest terrorist groups.

flashcards.name: scrutinize
flashcards.definition: [ˈskru:tənaɪz] ## v. to examine carefully especially in a critical way      ##  ## If we want to find ways to save the lives of young black men, we must scrutinize the failures of our criminal-justice system, the lack of rehabilitation services during and after incarceration, and the role of systemic racism.

flashcards.name: secondhand
flashcards.definition: ['sekənd'hænd] ## adj. not original     ##  ## I was still tacking down the secondhand Persian carpet on the stairs as these people walked in.

flashcards.name: secure
flashcards.definition: [sɪˈkjʊə] ## (1)v. to get secure usually lasting possession or control of     (2)adj. protected from danger or harm         ## capture, earn ##  ## The phrase “bread and circuses” refers to early Roman politicians’ plans to secure the votes of the poor by handing out cheap food and entertainment.

flashcards.name: self-aggrandizing
flashcards.definition: ['selfə'grændɪzmənt ] ## adj.                ##  ## This might not surprise you if you are familiar with O’Reilly’s self-aggrandizing temper, his fondness for the phrase “shut up” when he’s speaking to or about people he deems insufficiently patriotic or submissive.

flashcards.name: self-effacing
flashcards.definition: [selfiˈfeisiŋ] ## adj. not like talking about themselves or drawing attention to themselves ##  ##  ## Canadians, like all self-effacing secret egomaniacs, would, if so charged, profess shock.

flashcards.name: self-evident
flashcards.definition: [self 'evɪdənt] ## adj. clearly true and requiring no proof or explanation       ## manifest ##  ## Here was a harder truth, which seemed both shameful and self-evident: for a person of color, assimilation in America is akin to the physical manifestation of Zeno’s dichotomy paradox.

flashcards.name: self-perpetuating
flashcards.definition: [ˈselfpəˈpetjueitiŋ] ## adj.     ##  ## His company, no mere local startup, is a self-perpetuating engine of innovation, built around continuity, development, delegation, and mentorship.

flashcards.name: seminal
flashcards.definition: [ˈsemɪnl] ## adj. having a strong influence on ideas, works, events, etc., that come later      ##  ## “The Ballad of Sexual Dependency” was the seminal photography collection of the eighties, capturing the era’s lawless bohemianism.

flashcards.name: senescence
flashcards.definition: [sɪˈnesns] ## adj. the state of being old or the process of becoming old    ## decrepitude ##  ## The senior Methfessels were Bishop’s age, but were conservative Pennsylvania country-club Republicans with whom Methfessel had nothing “in common” but “our mutual past,” and they were declining into a nattering senescence.

flashcards.name: sequential
flashcards.definition: [sɪˈkwenʃl] ## adj. of, relating to, or arranged in a particular order or sequence          ## successive ##  ## In place of brutal detentions and bigotry, the musical presents sequential lessons in toleration: a Muslim passenger, the victim of unearned suspicion, is shown to be a benevolent chef, worthy only of affectionate respect.

flashcards.name: sequester
flashcards.definition: [sɪ'kwɛstɚ] ## v. to set apart    ##  ## Arthur’s first instinct was to sequester himself with Conkling, but he ended up spending much of this period by himself, a lonely widower often weeping inside his Lexington Avenue brownstone.

flashcards.name: sever
flashcards.definition: [ˈsevə] ## v. to put or keep apart       ##  ## The three joined a growing list of nonprofits that have severed ties with the exclusive, Trump-owned resort.

flashcards.name: shackle
flashcards.definition: [ˈʃækl] ## (1)n. something that prevents people from acting freely     (2)v. to put shackles on    ## stifle ##  ## A pair of Hitchcockian handcuffs serves first as an accessory to sex and then as a shackle to bind the hero while the villain, in the next room, plies his demonic trade.

flashcards.name: shallow
flashcards.definition: ['ʃælo] ## adj. penetrating only the easily or quickly perceived     ##  ## The two succeeding episodes—on “History’s Worst Medical Advice” and “The Drug That Changed the World”—match the première in being rather shallow and arbitrary. ## 80 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: sham
flashcards.definition: [ʃæm] ## n. cheep falseness        ##  ## The thing always to remember about Trump—and this week has merely confirmed it—is that he is a sham populist.

flashcards.name: shirk
flashcards.definition: [ʃə:k] ## v. to avoid doing something that you are supposed to do    ##  ## The sprawling concept album, once threatened by the song-centric demands of the MP3 era, has lately reëmerged as a status symbol for pop stars who can afford to shirk the demands of old-fashioned hitmaking.

flashcards.name: shoddy
flashcards.definition: ['ʃɑdi] ## adj. poorly done or made       ##  ## Two Mexicans busted through the wall today. Turns out that they didn't even want to come to America—they just wanted to show us how shoddy our craftsmanship is, then go back to Mexico, which they prefer.

flashcards.name: short-lived
flashcards.definition: [ˈʃɔ:tˈlaɪvd, -ˈlɪvd] ## adj. living or lasting for a short time     ## ephemeral ##  ## The “defenders of the White House” and their sympathizers joyfully celebrated their victory, but their euphoric mood, along with the sense of moral clarity and righteousness, proved to be short-lived.

flashcards.name: shortcoming
flashcards.definition: [ˈʃɔ:tkʌmɪŋ] ## n. an imperfection or lack that detracts from the whole    ## fault ##  ## Ambition is a necessary quality for anyone who wants to be President. But Hillary Clinton’s ambition is often portrayed as a shortcoming.

flashcards.name: shrewd
flashcards.definition: [ʃru:d] ## adj. having or showing an ability to understand things and to make good judgments     ## canny, artful ##  ## The shrewd dark comedy, starring Alia Shawkat, basically invents a new genre: the noir sitcom.

flashcards.name: shriek
flashcards.definition: [ʃri:k] ## v. to make a loud, high-pitched cry    ## caterwaul ##  ## She shrieked as I imagined an eagle would shriek.

flashcards.name: shrink
flashcards.definition: [ʃrɪŋk] ## (1)v. to quickly move away from something shocking, frightening, or disgusting        ## (2)v. to become smaller in amount, size, or value       ## recoil ##  ## Will Republicans fight to shrink the Supreme Court?

flashcards.name: shun
flashcards.definition: [ʃʌn] ## v. to avoid    ## eschew ##  ## Tin’s experience highlights a blind spot in the global investment community, which has been eager to throw cash at the next food- delivery or ride-sharing app but tends to shun products by and for women.

flashcards.name: shy away
flashcards.definition: [ʃai əˈwei] ## phrase.    ##  ## Many fairy tales are complex narratives of wish fulfillment. They teach the reader that a struggle against severe difficulties in life is unavoidable, that it is an intrinsic part of human existence, and that if one does not shy away, but steadfastly meets unexpected and often unjust hardships, one masters all obstacles and at the end emerges victorious.

flashcards.name: sidestep
flashcards.definition: [ˈsaɪdstep] ## v. bypass, evade    ## circumvent ##  ## Their pairing on a tour, including a stop at Terminal 5 on March 30, is just as intriguing as their lyrics: two vivid personalities who sidestep common pop tropes, and who stoke young devotees aspiring to a similar tone.

flashcards.name: sift
flashcards.definition: ['sɪft] ## v. to go through very carefully in order to find something useful or valuable    ##  ## It was telling that Biden had to sift through nearly a half century of history to find a precedent for the current malaise among liberals and progressives, but the comparison was not entirely fitting.

flashcards.name: signal
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɪgnəl] ## (1)n. sign, indication        ## (2)v. to be a sign of     ## (3)adj. very important or great         ##  ## Kenny would have added significantly to his book’s value had he more effectively signaled the influence of ancient philosophy on the subsequent tradition.

flashcards.name: signify
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɪgnɪfaɪ] ## v. to be a sign of    ## betoken ##  ## His words increasingly signify his confusion about who he is and what he has got himself into.

flashcards.name: simplicity
flashcards.definition: [sɪmˈplɪsəti] ## (1)n. the state of being simple, uncomplicated, or uncompounded     (2)n. lack of subtlety or penetration    ## artlessness ##  ## Günter Seeger is a new European-accented place that serves ten-course meals with exquisite simplicity. ## 81 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: singular
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɪŋgjələ] ## (1)adj. of or relating to a separate person or thing      (2)adj. distinguished by superiority       ## (3)adj. departing from general usage or expectation     ## unique ##  ## The Queens producer’s songs beguile with their singular focus, as on her self-titled E.P. of whispery slow-blooming dance tunes.

flashcards.name: skeptical
flashcards.definition: ['skeptɪkəl] ## adj. having or expressing doubt about something     ## unimpressed ##  ## Republicans are skeptical and will continue to seize on this historical judgment to undermine the broader conclusions.

flashcards.name: sketchy
flashcards.definition: [ˈsketʃi] ## (1)adj. roughly outlined      ## (2)adj. wanting in completeness, clearness, or substance: slight, superficial      ## rudimentary, superficial, undeveloped ##  ## He plans to keep Photoshopping his daughter into sketchy situations: “I’m really looking forward to showing her these when she is older.”

flashcards.name: skittish
flashcards.definition: ['skɪtɪʃ] ## adj. easily frightened or excited      ## restive, fractious ##  ## Pair with oversized sunglasses for a touch of glam, and chuckle knowingly at the skittish twentysomethings on the other side of the pool struggling to look relaxed while sucking in their stomachs and never laying their legs out flat.

flashcards.name: skullduggery
flashcards.definition: [skʌlˈdʌɡəri] ## n. secret or dishonest behavior or activity    ##  ## Once upon a time, the quaint bend in this serpentine alley (previously known, unsubtly, as the Blood Angle) abetted all manner of ambushes and skullduggery during gang warfare.

flashcards.name: slapdash
flashcards.definition: [ˈslæpdæʃ] ## adj. quick and careless     ##  ## Despite its shambling, slapdash manner, it shares overly much in the very media gloss that it lampoons; the movie is both soigné and clumsy, unable to break through its own sheen.

flashcards.name: sleazy
flashcards.definition: ['sliːzɪ] ## (1)adj. dirty and in bad condition form being neglected      (2)adj. dishonest or immoral          ## sordid ##  ## During the recent James Comey hearings, Pratt again invoked the genre’s sleazy tactics: “The producers gotta give this cast some more drinks.”

flashcards.name: slight
flashcards.definition: [slaɪt] ## (1)v. to offend or insult     ## (2)adj. very small in degree or amount       ## disparage ##  ## On Sunday, the vibe in Hopkinsville was a charged laziness, calm but anticipatory, and the weather was humid enough to leave a slight sheen covering everyone’s skin.

flashcards.name: slippery
flashcards.definition: [ˈslɪpəri] ## (1)adj. not precise or fixed in meaning: ambiguous, elusive             ## (2)adj. not to be trusted      ## elusive ##  ## Time may seem slippery and maddeningly abstract, but it’s also deeply intimate, infusing our every word and gesture.

flashcards.name: sluggish
flashcards.definition: [ˈslʌgɪʃ] ## adj. moving slowly or lazily     ## dilatory, listless ##  ## Sharon Jones sang and moved in a way that seemed so pure and instinctive it made every other performer in her orbit appear calculated and sluggish by comparison.

flashcards.name: slumberous
flashcards.definition: ['slʌmbərəs] ## adj. marked by or suggestive of a state of sleep or lethargy     ## lethargic ##  ## I don’t know the answer, but if the notoriously squeamish and slumberous members of the Academy can pull themselves together and face “Monster,” they should know whom to vote for as the best actress of the year.

flashcards.name: slur
flashcards.definition: [slɜ:] ## (1)n. an insulting or disparaging remark or innuendo     (2)v. to make indistinct  ...   ## aspersion ##  ## I think cultural appropriation is a racial slur against white people.

flashcards.name: smother
flashcards.definition: [ˈsmʌðə] ## (1)v. to try to keep from happening     (2)v. to kill by depriving of air       ##  ## Musicals often smother the fun out of movies that weld real and fantastical elements. But “Groundhog Day,” starring Andy Karl in the Bill Murray role, has it mostly figured out.

flashcards.name: snag
flashcards.definition: [snæg] ## n. a concealed or unexpected difficulty or obstacle    ## hitch ##  ## Donald J. Trump’s foreign trip hit a snag on Tuesday, when the remaining countries on his itinerary announced that they would rather “wait a month” and meet with the next President instead. ## 82 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: snub
flashcards.definition: [snʌb] ## v. to ignore in a deliberate and insulting way    ## slight ##  ## The university’s once snubbed department of economic history has lost prestige and transmogrified into a department of management and marketing.

flashcards.name: sobering
flashcards.definition: [ˈsəʊbərɪŋ] ## adj. making you feel serious and thoughtful     ## staid ##  ## The revelation that the team was vulgarly “ranking” female players is a sobering reminder that sexist behavior can’t easily be stamped out through rules alone.

flashcards.name: sociable
flashcards.definition: ['səʊʃəbl] ## adj. inclined by nature to companionship with others of the same species      ## gregarious ##  ## At the Rock County Job Center, Matt took a test called JobFit. The test assessed his manual dexterity, math skills, and sociability, and concluded that he should become a database developer, a podiatrist, or a nurse.

flashcards.name: solemn
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɒləm] ## adj. very serious or formal in manner     ## somber ##  ## Meatyard was a great admirer of O’Connor’s, but if his photographs are filled with signifiers of the gothic, with stuffed birds and solemn-faced children, it’s also true that his pictures evoke delight more often than dread.

flashcards.name: solidarity
flashcards.definition: [ˌsɒlɪˈdærəti] ## n. a feeling of unity between people who have the same interests, goals, etc.    ## camaraderie ##  ## Last week, Pope Francis brought his message of solidarity to the ancient world and the new.

flashcards.name: somber
flashcards.definition: ['sɒmbə] ## (1)adj. of a serious mien      ## (2)adj. of a dull or heavy cast or shade     ## solemn ##  ## At the Bill Cosby trial this week, concerning the comedian’s alleged sexual assault of Andrea Constand, two witnesses have briefly electrified the somber courtroom.

flashcards.name: somnolent
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɒmnələnt] ## (1)adj. tired and ready to fall asleep      (2)adj. causing a person to fall asleep     ## lethargic ##  ## It was 5:30 a.m. Honolulu time, on February 28th, when the somnolent campaign was jolted awake by the thirty-four-year-old Hawaii congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard.

flashcards.name: soothe
flashcards.definition: [su:ð] ## (1)v. by please by or as if by attention or concern     (2)v. relieve, alleviate    ## deflate ##  ## For almost as long as I can remember, I, too, have found that fictitious fears can help to soothe the real ones.

flashcards.name: sophist
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɒfɪst] ## (1)n. a captious or fallacious reasoner      (2)n. philosopher     ##  ## You ask why the world needs an entire book devoted to the subject, and we know the answer: who wouldn’t want to read about a certain variety of smug sophist buying the farm?

flashcards.name: sophisticated
flashcards.definition: [sə'fɪstɪketɪd] ## (1)adj. highly developed and complex      (2)adj. finely experienced and aware     ##  ## He looked the way he wrote and spoke, combining the folksy, conversational idioms of classic Dempsey-age sportswriting with a sophisticated searching curiosity about what impels people—makes them the way they are.

flashcards.name: sordid
flashcards.definition: ['sɔːdɪd] ## (1)adj. very dirty      ## (2)adj. very bad or dishonest          ##  ## Trump said that, in order to deny Bill Clinton the Presidency, he was prepared to scrutinize “every nook and cranny of Clinton’s sordid personal life.”

flashcards.name: sound
flashcards.definition: [saʊnd] ## (1)adj. in good health      (2)adj. free from mistakes      (3)adj. solid and strong     ## unassailable, valid ##  ## Although the vast weight of evidence supports the contention that the products of agricultural biotechnology are environmentally sound, many people still find them intrinsically unsettling.

flashcards.name: sovereignty
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɒvrənti] ## (1)n. unlimited power over a country          ## (2)n. a country’s independent authority and the right to govern itself     ##  ## On Saturday, Hong Kong will mark the twentieth anniversary of the British handover of sovereignty. ## 83 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: spartan
flashcards.definition: [ˈspɑ:tn] ## (1)adj. marked by simplicity, frugality, or avoidance of luxury and comfort      ## (2)n. a person of great courage and self-discipline         ##  ## I grew up as a bike rider in Manhattan, and I also worked as a bike messenger, where I absorbed the spartan, libertarian, every- man-for-himself ethos.

flashcards.name: specious
flashcards.definition: [ˈspi:ʃəs] ## adj. falsely appearing to be fair, just, or right     ## artificial, forged, fabricated, spurious ##  ## Undaunted, Helms moved to have King’s F.B.I. files declassified, so that the Senate might explore the specious claim that he was a Communist stooge.

flashcards.name: spectacular
flashcards.definition: [spekˈtækjələ] ## adj. causing wonder and admiration     ## dramatic ##  ## The same is not true of Venus at thirty-six, though she is still capable of playing spectacular matches.

flashcards.name: speculation
flashcards.definition: [ˌspekjuˈleɪʃn] ## n. ideas or guesses about something that is not known    ## conjecture ##  ## Discrepancies in ISIS’s claim of responsibility for the Manchester bombing have spurred speculation about the organization’s command of foreign operations.

flashcards.name: spontaneous
flashcards.definition: [spɒnˈteɪniəs] ## adj. done or said in a natural and often sudden way and without a lot of thought or planning     ## intuitive ##  ## In fact, there was only one fully spontaneous moment I witnessed, not at the Convention but on MSNBC, once the news that Melania’s speech had plagiarized Michelle Obama’s leaked from Twitter.

flashcards.name: sporadic
flashcards.definition: [spə'rædɪk] ## adj. occurring occasionally, singly, or in irregular or random instances      ## occasional, fitful ##  ## Del the Funky Homosapien, who leads an unhurried career of cherished offshoot projects and sporadic appearances, materializes at Brooklyn Bowl.

flashcards.name: spur
flashcards.definition: [spɜ:] ## v. to incite to action or accelerated growth or development    ## foster ##  ## welder puts together part of a bicycle frame at the Detroit Bikes facility. The upstart bicycle manufacturer is hoping to spur a revival of a made-in-America industry in the city.

flashcards.name: spurious
flashcards.definition: [ˈspjʊəriəs] ## adj. not genuine, sincere, or authentic     ## artificial, implausible ##  ## For years, spurious journals have proliferated online, promising academic credibility in exchange for cash. ## Day 7 ## I have nothing to offer but blood, boil, tears and sweat.

flashcards.name: spurn
flashcards.definition: [spə:n] ## v. to refuse to accept    ## flout ##  ## Even the album’s cover art explicitly channels the mind-set of teen-agers and twentysomethings who, liberated by the Internet, spurn labels and celebrate eccentricity.

flashcards.name: square with
flashcards.definition: [skwɛə wið] ## phrase.  ...   ## conform to ##  ## Even though his opponent is currently trying to portray him as a wild-eyed radical, voters will likely reject this charge because it does not square with his moderate political record.

flashcards.name: stability
flashcards.definition: [stəˈbɪləti] ## n. the quality or state of something that is not easily changed or likely to change    ## order ##  ## What matters most are those things that endure for decades and centuries: democracy, rule of law, a civilian-led military, political stability, and freedom of speech and movement.

flashcards.name: stagnate
flashcards.definition: [stæg'neɪt] ## v. to stop developing, progressing, moving, etc.    ##  ## It anatomized how the federal government was failing to enforce immigration laws, and how immigration was causing wages to stagnate and unemployment to persist.

flashcards.name: staid
flashcards.definition: [sted] ## adj. serious, boring, or old-fashioned         ## sober ##  ## The vinyl stools and linoleum-topped tables fill up with grizzled drinkers, staid couples in their sixties, and flannelled young professionals, all scruff and asymmetrical haircuts.

flashcards.name: stale
flashcards.definition: [steɪl] ## adj. tedious from familiarity         ## banal ##  ## He travelled with a collection of old newspapers and stale crackers; he liked to wear several layers of clothing. ##          84 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: stalwart
flashcards.definition: [ˈstɔ:lwət] ## (1)adj. marked by outstanding strength and vigor of body, mind, or spirit      ## (2)adj. very loyal and dedicated         ##  ## year and a half ago, the world got a new heavyweight boxing champion, when an unpredictable Englishman named Tyson Fury found a way to wrangle Wladimir Klitschko, the stalwart Ukrainian.

flashcards.name: stanch
flashcards.definition: [stɔntʃ] ## v. to stop something (especially blood) from flowing       ##  ## Another man left town, cut his throat in a field, regretted it, and tried to stuff grass into the wound but was unable to stanch it.

flashcards.name: standstill
flashcards.definition: [ˈstændstɪl] ## n. a state in which all activity or motion is stopped    ##  ## The crowd below was at a standstill, necks craning, phones out to record the moment.

flashcards.name: startling
flashcards.definition: ['stɑrtlɪŋ] ## adj. very surprising, shocking, or frightening       ##  ## Shortly after an amiable meeting with the Emir of Qatar, President Trump threw him under the diplomatic bus in a series of startling tweets.

flashcards.name: starvation
flashcards.definition: [stɑr'veʃən] ## n. suffering or death caused by having nothing to eat or not enough to eat    ##  ## The modern reader will recognize these as symptoms of anorexia, the means by which the body struggles to stave off the effects of its own starvation.

flashcards.name: staunch
flashcards.definition: [stɔːntʃ] ## adj. very devoted or loyal to a person, belief, or cause         ##  ## We have yet to learn just how closely the views of the Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch resemble those of the late Justice Antonin Scalia, a staunch conservative and a standard-bearer for the legal philosophy known as originalism.

flashcards.name: stave off
flashcards.definition: [steɪv ɔf] ## phrase.    ## forestall ##  ## I get something new from it every time that I read it, and the most recent time I found a quiet koan in it about how only hard work and human ingenuity can stave off our profoundest existential loneliness.

flashcards.name: stem
flashcards.definition: [stem] ## (1)v. to check or go counter to     ## (2)v. to occur or develop as a consequence    ## check ##  ## “Self-care” is newer in the American lexicon than “self-reliance,” but both stem from the puritanical values of self-improvement and self-examination.

flashcards.name: sterling
flashcards.definition: [ˈstɜ:lɪŋ] ## adj. very good     ##  ## Given the sterling reputation of the committees and the exhaustive nature of its investigation, it would be unreasonable to gainsay the committee’s conclusions at first glance.

flashcards.name: stifle
flashcards.definition: [ˈstaɪfl] ## v. to stop from doing or expressing something    ## shackle ##  ## What happened to the Daily Stormer wasn’t a violation of the First Amendment—private companies are allowed to stifle speech —but it enraged people on the right, many of whom were already deeply skeptical of the puppet masters in Silicon Valley.

flashcards.name: stingy
flashcards.definition: [ˈstɪndʒi] ## (1)adj. not liking or wanting to give or spend money      (2)adj. small in size or amount     ## parsimonious ##  ## “Anastasia” (at the Broadhurst) and “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” (at the Lunt-Fontanne), both aimed at kids and each with diametrically opposed artistic faults. One is too sumptuous, the other too stingy.

flashcards.name: stratified
flashcards.definition: ['strætɪfaɪd] ## adj. divided into different classes or social layers           ## hierarchical ##  ## The film, which shot to No. 1 at the box office, brazenly inhabits the anxieties that surround miscegenation in our still racially stratified country.

flashcards.name: striking
flashcards.definition: [ˈstraɪkɪŋ] ## adj. attracting attention or notice through unusual or conspicuous qualities       ##  ## Vang writes strikingly, often chillingly visual poems, their images projected one at a time, like slides in a lecture, or perhaps in a trial.

flashcards.name: strip away
flashcards.definition: [strip əˈwei] ## phrase. to remove it completely    ## remove ##  ## Jackie Wullschlager's biography of Hans Christian Andersen stripped away the insipid sweetness with which Andersen coated his life and reveals a vulnerable gingerbread man with a bitter almond where his heart should be.

flashcards.name: stubborn
flashcards.definition: [ˈstʌbən] ## (1)adj. refusing to change your ideas or to stop doing something      (2)adj. difficult to deal with, remove, etc.      ## intractable ##        85 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## Grain elevators are a stubborn target for urban renewal, because it’s so difficult to use them for anything but cleaning and storing grain

flashcards.name: stun
flashcards.definition: [stʌn] ## v. to surprise or upset very much     ##  ## Officers confiscated bricks, sticks, hammers, and makeshift wooden shields, and herded one group of counter-demonstrators away from the park with pepper balls and stun grenades.

flashcards.name: stymie
flashcards.definition: [ˈstaɪmi] ## v. to stop from doing something or to stop from happening    ## hinder ##  ## How could one mouse seemingly stymie the virus? Could the answer behind this mystery explain why only some human fetuses exposed to Zika suffer from microcephaly?

flashcards.name: subordinate
flashcards.definition: [səˈbɔ:dɪnət] ## (1)adj. in a position of less power or authority than someone else        ## (2)adj. less important than someone or something else      ## (3)n. someone who has less power or authority than someone else    ##  ## The filmmaker appears to allow the performances an unusual degree of freedom to create their actions in front of the camera, but the images never seem either subordinate to performance or constraining of it.

flashcards.name: subsidize
flashcards.definition: ['sʌbsə'daɪz] ## v. to help someone or something pay for the costs of       ##  ## Uchitelle thinks we ought to subsidize manufacturing more, and more rationally.

flashcards.name: subtle
flashcards.definition: ['sʌtl] ## (1)adj. hard to notice or see        (2)adj. difficult to understand        (3)adj. able to make fine distinctions     ##  ## “Hidden Figures” is a subtle and powerful work of counter-history, or, rather, of a finally and long-deferred accurate history, that fills in the general outlines of these women’s roles in the space program.

flashcards.name: successive
flashcards.definition: [səkˈsesɪv] ## adj. following one after the other in a series     ## sequential ##  ## Against the complex techniques of postwar Western composition, Riley, a native Californian, posited a piece with a one-page score, entrusting a group of musicians to sing or play fifty-three brief musical fragments in successive, overlapping waves.

flashcards.name: succumb
flashcards.definition: [səˈkʌm] ## (1)v. to stop trying to resist something     (2)v. to die    ## yield ##  ## President Obama urged Americans not to succumb to fear. We may not be up to it.

flashcards.name: suffocate
flashcards.definition: [ˈsʌfəkeɪt] ## (1)v. to impede or stop the development of     (2)v. to stop the respiration of    ##  ## These movies and others in their vein—starting with but not limited to such Oscar candidates as “The Big Short” and “Spotlight,” “The Danish Girl” and “45 Years”—suffocate in their makers’ intentions.

flashcards.name: sullen
flashcards.definition: [ˈsʌlən] ## adj. dismal, gloomy       ## surly, grumpy ##  ## He realized what his fate would be and he just walked off with a sullen look.

flashcards.name: superficial
flashcards.definition: [ˌsu:pəˈfɪʃl] ## (1)adj. concerned only with the obvious or apparent      (2)adj. lying close to the surface     ## shallow ##  ## North Korea represents a chance for the American and Chinese Presidents to move beyond moments of superficial understanding.

flashcards.name: superfluous
flashcards.definition: [su:ˈpɜ:fluəs] ## adj. beyond what is needed     ##  ## In the realm of Holocaust dramas, László Nemes’s first feature is ambitious and provocative but nearly superfluous.

flashcards.name: supplant
flashcards.definition: [səˈplɑ:nt] ## v. to take the place of    ##  ## Is Donald Trump seeking to create an enduring America First movement that will eventually supplant the Republican Party?

flashcards.name: supple
flashcards.definition: ['sʌpl] ## (1)adj. readily adaptable or responsive to new situations            ## (2)adj. capable of being bent or folded without creases, cracks, or breaks     ## flexible ##  ## He wrote his own songs, creating irresistible melodies with seeming ease; he had a supple voice with an impressive range, capable of crazy falsetto, effortless belting, real intimacy. ## 86 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: supplicate
flashcards.definition: ['sʌplikeit] ## v. to ask humbly and earnestly of    ## entreat, solicit ##  ## You look into the victims’ faces: some have already given up, while one or two beg, supplicate, appeal to the humanity of the men with the guns.

flashcards.name: suppress
flashcards.definition: [sə'prɛs] ## v. to end or stop by force       ##  ## The fact that the government can’t suppress it, even in a time of growing alarm about the rise of hate crimes, reveals our uniquely optimistic faith in free expression as protection against tyranny.

flashcards.name: surfeit
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɜ:fɪt] ## n. an amount that is too much or more than you need    ## glut, plethora ##  ## In the “Girls Trip” scene, wearing stolen wigs, the posse alternates between choreographed blows and twerks until, exhausted, they fall over, splaying their arms, smacking their thighs—a surfeit of unworried vulgarity.

flashcards.name: surly
