flashcards.definition: [ˈsɜ:li] ## adj. irritably sullen and churlish in mood or manner     ## sullen ##  ## An illuminated sign above the bar declares “WELCOME,” though bartenders tend toward the surly, except to drinkers who could place in a Rick Rubin lookalike contest.

flashcards.name: surmise
flashcards.definition: [səˈmaɪz] ## (1)v. to form an opinion about something without definitely knowing the truth     ## (2)n. a thought or idea based on scanty evidence    ## infer ##  ## One might also surmise that Brennan had reached a bogeyman’s conclusion about the recent demographics of Crown Heights.

flashcards.name: surrender
flashcards.definition: [səˈrendə] ## (1)v. to agree to stop fighting, hiding, resisting, etc., because you know that you will not win or succeed     ## (2)v. to give the control or use of to someone else     ## (3)v. to allow something to influence or control you    ##  ## The establishment need not surrender before the battle has really even begun.

flashcards.name: surreptitious
flashcards.definition: [ˌsʌrəpˈtɪʃəs] ## adj. done in a secret way       ##  ## We are deeply concerned that if surreptitious, unauthorized videos or recordings were made, these individuals could make deceptive edits to create unfair, malicious, and false impressions.

flashcards.name: susceptible
flashcards.definition: [sə'sɛptəbl] ## adj. easily affected, influenced, or harmed by something       ##  ## In the Antarctic Peninsula, which extends farther north than other parts of the continent and is thus more susceptible to global warming, the relatively diminutive Adélie penguins, Cherry-Garrard’s subjects, have been in decline.

flashcards.name: sustain
flashcards.definition: [səˈsteɪn] ## (1)v. to provide what is needed for to exist, continue, etc.     (2)v. to hold up the weight of    ##  ## By creating a single currency without the institutions to sustain it, the E.U. wound up with low growth, high unemployment, and popular disaffection.

flashcards.name: sway
flashcards.definition: [sweɪ] ## (1)v. to fluctuate or veer between one point, position, or opinion and another     ## (2)v. to exert a building or controlling influence on    ##  ## Can Obama’s hope sway the French election?

flashcards.name: sweeping
flashcards.definition: ['swipɪŋ] ## adj. including or involving many things     ##  ## It was the pictures themselves that conveyed a sweeping and indelible portrait of American poverty, and continued Richards’s work as a descendant of photographers from Jacob Riis to Walker Evans.

flashcards.name: sycophantic
flashcards.definition: [ˌsɪkə'fæntɪk] ## adj. fawning, obsequious     ## obsequious, adulating ##  ## Throughout the 2016 Presidential race, the Enquirer embraced Trump with sycophantic fervor.

flashcards.name: sympathetic
flashcards.definition: [sɪmpə'θetɪk] ## adj. feeling or showing concern about someone who is in a bad situation     ##  ## Anti-Trump conservatives have responded to its largely empathetic portrait of poor, white Americans, which they see as an alternative to the less sympathetic theories about Trump’s least affluent supporters.

flashcards.name: synonymous
flashcards.definition: [sɪˈnɒnɪməs] ## adj. having the same connotations, implications, or reference     ## tantamount ##  ## Tim Ho Wan, long synonymous with premier dim sum, was anointed with the honor in 2009 in its native Hong Kong.

flashcards.name: synoptic
flashcards.definition: [sɪ'nɑptɪk] ## adj. affording a general view of a whole     ## abridged ##       87 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## We have three major works with Damon as the central figure: “The Bourne Identity” (2002), “The Bourne Supremacy” (2004), and “The Bourne Ultimatum” (2007), known collectively to scholars as the synoptic Bournes.

flashcards.name: synthesis
flashcards.definition: [ˈsɪnθəsɪs] ## n. something that is made by combining different things        ## fusion ##  ## In 2017, Linkin Park’s sound—a convulsive and visceral synthesis of rock, rap, and industrial music—feels like a curious relic of some long-ago era.

flashcards.name: taciturn
flashcards.definition: [ˈtæsɪtɜ:n] ## adj. temperamentally disinclined to talk       ## laconic, terse, curt ##  ## On Wednesday afternoon, the constitutionally taciturn McConnell took questions from the press for almost half an hour.

flashcards.name: tactless
flashcards.definition: ['tæktləs] ## adj. not showing or having tact     ##  ## Yanagihara deftly outlines the trials of JB, a brilliant but tactless painter.

flashcards.name: taint
flashcards.definition: [teɪnt] ## (1)v. to contaminate morally     (2)v. to affect with putrefaction     ## (3)n. something that causes a person or thing to be thought of as bad, dishonest, etc.    ##  ## Today, the profession risks protecting itself from the taint of politics by withholding expertise from a vital public debate—a situation that seems no less irresponsible.

flashcards.name: tantamount
flashcards.definition: [ˈtæntəmaʊnt] ## adj. equal to something in value, meaning, or effect     ## synonymous ##  ## The Freedom Caucus and the Republican Study Committee, separately said that they will vote against reform bills that include tax credits, which they argue are tantamount to a new entitlement program.

flashcards.name: taxing
flashcards.definition: [ˈtæksɪŋ] ## adj. requiring a lot of effort, energy, etc.     ## arduous ##  ## On his latest recording, he plays some of the most taxing piano writing ever put on paper with stupefying effortlessness.

flashcards.name: tedious
flashcards.definition: [ˈti:diəs] ## adj. boring and too slow or long       ## dreary, boring ##  ## If it wants to compete in the contemporary landscape that it helped to create, it might do better to study the timeless relevance of its “Real World” era than to replicate the tedious, overly polished nostalgia offered by a show like “Siesta Key.”

flashcards.name: teem with
flashcards.definition: [ti:m] [wɪð] ## phrase.    ##  ## Alan Moore’s graphic novels teem with superhumans and phantasms; he himself has spent his life in quiet Northampton, which inspired his latest work.

flashcards.name: temper
flashcards.definition: [ˈtempə] ## v. to make less severe or extreme    ## modulate, mitigate, neutralize ##  ## Frisée salad comes with farm-fresh fingerling potatoes that don’t require much more than salt to temper their earthy sweetness.

flashcards.name: temperate
flashcards.definition: ['tempərət] ## adj. marked by moderation         ## dispassionate ##  ## In 2015, the Times Magazine published a moving story by Chris Suellentrop, a journalist and Kansas native, whose uncle, a state legislator with a serious and temperate disposition, had joined the Brownback movement.

flashcards.name: temporary
flashcards.definition: ['tempərərɪ] ## adj. lasting for a limited time     ##  ## Forty-eight hours later, a federal judge in Los Angeles granted a temporary restraining order, instructing immigration officials to admit anyone with valid immigrant visas.

flashcards.name: tenacity
flashcards.definition: [tə'næsətɪ] ## n. the quality or state of being very determined to do something    ## resolve, endurance ##  ## Maud emerges as a memorable figure, a misunderstood woman who has yet to discover her own brilliance and tenacity.

flashcards.name: tendentious
flashcards.definition: [tɛn'dɛnʃəs] ## adj. expressing a strong opinion       ##  ## Lawler’s tendentious critics lumber past the sense of a personal drama—ethics at odds with aesthetics, and rigor with yearning —that makes her by far the most arresting artist of her kind.

flashcards.name: tenuous
flashcards.definition: [ˈtenjuəs] ## (1)adj. very thin      ## (2)adj. having little substance or strength     ## exiguous ##  ## A tenuous partisan coalition exists in the Senate, and its cohesion depends upon McConnell’s power to persuade.

flashcards.name: tepid
flashcards.definition: [ˈtepɪd] ## adj. not energetic or excited       ##  ## The potholder loom I gave your child last year earned only a tepid thank-you note.

flashcards.name: terrific
flashcards.definition: [tə'rɪfɪk] ## adj. extremely good     ##        88 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The private, lavishly decorated Hello Kitty room is terrific for belting out your favorite Cantopop hit.

flashcards.name: terrifying
flashcards.definition: ['terɪfaɪŋ] ## adj. causing great fear       ##  ## That we are paying attention at all—that a belligerent, proudly debauched rock star suddenly seems as if he might be a viable candidate for public service—is a terrifying new normal.

flashcards.name: terse
flashcards.definition: [tɜ:s] ## adj. brief and direct in a way that may see rude or unfriendly     ## laconic, curt, taciturn, succinct ##  ## Lightfoot, speeding on a country road in a stolen muscle car, picks up the fleeing Thunderbolt and outdrives the gunman for kicks —and experiences a sort of fraternal love at first sight for his terse, coolly confident and worldly-wise older passenger.

flashcards.name: testimony
flashcards.definition: [ˈtestɪməni] ## n. proof or evidence that something exists or is true    ##  ## Republicans control Congress, and I’m skeptical that Comey’s testimony, as thorough and troubling as it was, will change the minds of many Republicans.

flashcards.name: thorough
flashcards.definition: [ˈθʌrə] ## (1)adj. careful about doing something in an accurate and exact way       ## (2)adj. complete or absolute     ## meticulous ##  ## Kraviz posted a thorough analysis on Facebook, explaining precisely how she had used mischievous stylistic digressions and jarring tempo shifts to create a “wild, ravy mix” that confounded expectations

flashcards.name: thrift
flashcards.definition: [θrɪft] ## n. careful use of money so that it is not wasted    ##  ## He presents thrift as liberation rather than as deprivation.

flashcards.name: thrill
flashcards.definition: [θrɪl] ## (1)v. to cause to feel very excited or happy      ## (2)n. a quivering or trembling caused by sudden excitement or emotion       ##  ## It’s a weird thrill to see someone so young hold his own with total aplomb in front of so many people.

flashcards.name: thrive
flashcards.definition: [θraɪv] ## v. to grow or develop successfully    ##  ## Every child deserves to attend school in a safe, supportive environment that allows them to thrive and grow.

flashcards.name: tilt
flashcards.definition: [tɪlt] ## n. slant, bias       ## list ##  ## The tilt in Hillary Clinton’s favor among financial-industry types may have less to do with their love of her than with a rejection of the instability that Donald Trump represents.

flashcards.name: timely
flashcards.definition: [ˈtaɪmli] ## adj. happening at the correct or most useful time     ## opportune ##  ## With her eerily timely “Indecent,” Paula Vogel unsettles American theatre again.

flashcards.name: timid
flashcards.definition: [ˈtɪmɪd] ## adj. feeling or showing a lack of courage or confidence         ## diffident ##  ## Compared to those who defiantly confronted soldiers and police, I was timid and afraid, yet the deed was defining for me.

flashcards.name: tolerate
flashcards.definition: [ˈtɒləreɪt] ## (1)v. to allow to exist, happen, or be done     (2)v. to put up with    ## brook ##  ## Many Americans are unsure if they can tolerate that much additional exposure to Rudy Giuliani, a leading psychologist said on Wednesday.

flashcards.name: tonic
flashcards.definition: [ˈtɒnɪk] ## adj. increasing or restoring physical or mental tone       ## restorative ##  ## Partly, there’s the tonic shock of encountering again, in person, works that are traduced by reproduction, which muffles their keynotes of material, touch, and scale.

flashcards.name: topple
flashcards.definition: ['tɑpl] ## v. to remove from power       ##  ## Even minor fluctuations in temperature have resulted in “food shortages, famines, infectious disease outbreaks, weather disasters, and conflicts over resources that foment social disorder and topple regimes.”

flashcards.name: tortuous
flashcards.definition: [ˈtɔ:tʃuəs] ## (1)adj. having many twists and turns      ## (2)adj. complicated, long, and confusing       ## convoluted ##  ## After weeks of tortuous negotiations, they announced a “cessation of hostilities” that went into effect at sundown on Monday, September 12th.

flashcards.name: totemic
flashcards.definition: [təʊ'temɪk] ## adj. of, relating to, suggestive of, or characteristic of a totem or totemism     ## emblematic ##   89 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The landscape here is post-volcanic, its population shamanic, and the wildlife totemic, in the form of an owl and a snake.

flashcards.name: tractable
flashcards.definition: [ˈtræktəbl] ## adj. capable of being easily led, taught, or controlled         ## compliant ##  ## Only afterward does he realize the possibility that Flicka has inherited not just the speed and strength of the Albino but also the unruliness of his blood—that there is a chance that she might never become tractable.

flashcards.name: transgress
flashcards.definition: [trænzˈgres] ## v. to do something that is not allowed       ##  ## When he enters the White House he will continue gleefully transgressing democratic norms, berating his opponents, throwing out blatant falsehoods, and seeking to exploit his position for personal gain.

flashcards.name: transient
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrænziənt] ## adj. not lasting long     ##  ## In extremely unfortunate cases, retrograde and anterograde amnesia can occur in the same individual, who is then said to suffer from “transient global amnesia,” a condition that is, thankfully, temporary.

flashcards.name: transitory
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrænsətri] ## adj. lasting only for a short time     ## ephemeral, evanescent ##  ## Stars can’t be manufactured, and the fact that no young African-American actors had any major dramatic roles in 2010 will likely prove as anomalous and transitory as the stardom of Steve Guttenberg and Deanna Durbin.

flashcards.name: treasure
flashcards.definition: [ˈtreʒə] ## (1)adj. something that is very special, important, or valuable     (2)v. to value very much    ##  ## In Lower Silesia, treasure hunters are still looking for Klose’s gold and for other riches.

flashcards.name: tremendous
flashcards.definition: [trə'mɛndəs] ## adj. very large or great     ##  ## The Republican front-runner, Donald Trump, said on Tuesday night that he was “tremendously relieved” that the recent controversy linking him to the Ku Klux Klan had apparently not hurt him with voters in Alabama.

flashcards.name: trenchant
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrentʃənt] ## adj. very strong, clear, and effective         ## profound, incisive ##  ## The Brooklyn-based musician and producer Eli Smith curates the Brooklyn Folk Festival’s offerings with an eye toward the diverse, the spontaneous, the countercultural, and the trenchant.

flashcards.name: trepidation
flashcards.definition: [ˌtrepɪˈdeɪʃn] ## n. a nervous or fearful feeling of uncertain agitation    ## misgiving, apprehension ##  ## I followed Duckpenisgate with particular trepidation, since I was one of the co-investigators on the maligned study.

flashcards.name: tribute
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrɪbju:t] ## (1)n. something that you say, give, or do to show respect or affection for someone     ## (2)n. money or goods that a ruler or country gives to another ruler or country especially for protection    ## encomium ##  ## The video, directed by Brett Haley, is a plainspoken, cinematic tribute to love, interracial marriage, and small-town American values.

flashcards.name: trifling
flashcards.definition: [ˈtraɪflɪŋ] ## adj. having little value or importance       ## minimal ##  ## Nearly every critic and music-industry professional I know routinely decries the Grammys as trifling, an arbiter of nothing: they are too white, too docile, too choked by genre, too long, too loyal to outmoded tropes.

flashcards.name: trigger
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrɪgə] ## v. to cause to start or happen    ##  ## Unless you spend much time sitting in a college classroom or browsing through certain precincts of the Internet, it’s possible that you had not heard of trigger warnings until a few weeks ago, when they made an appearance in the Times.

flashcards.name: triumph
flashcards.definition: [ˈtraɪʌmf] ## n. a great success or achievement      ## success ##  ## Dylan’s coronation by the Swedish Academy—which, it may be said, pretty much no one alive in 1965 would have then imagined possible—is just one more sign of the absoluteness of this triumph.

flashcards.name: trivial
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrɪviəl] ## adj. not important      ## inconsequential, immaterial ##  ## On one level, Nash’s contribution to game theory was highly mathematical, and, ultimately, somewhat trivial.

flashcards.name: truculent
flashcards.definition: [ˈtrʌkjələnt] ## adj. easily annoyed or angered and likely to argue     ## pugnacious, bellicose, combative, aggressive ##  ## By turns, Bobby was charming and contemptuous, contemplative and enraged, wise and impulsive, truculent and loose.

flashcards.name: truncate
flashcards.definition: [trʌŋ'ket] ## v. to shorten by or as if by cutting off    ## shorten, foreshorten ##  90 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The plethora of incidents, together with the constraining embrace of De Sica’s sympathies, reduce the film to its plot and truncate the characters’ inner lives.

flashcards.name: tumultuous
flashcards.definition: [tu'mʌltʃuəs] ## adj. involving a lot of violence, confusion, or disorder     ##  ## Here are scenes from a tumultuous time—the victims in Ghouta, the trail of refugees, and the U.N. inspectors looking for evidence of an atrocity.

flashcards.name: turbid
flashcards.definition: ['tɜːbɪd] ## adj. cloudy or muddy         ##  ## In her turbid “Portrait of Myself as My Father,” Chipaumire attacks stereotypes of black masculinity acerbically.

flashcards.name: tyro
flashcards.definition: [ˈtaɪrəʊ] ## n. a person who has just started learning or doing something    ## novice, neophyte ##  ## The relationship with Beauvoir propelled this twenty-six-year-old tyro into the highest reaches of French culture.

flashcards.name: ubiquitous
flashcards.definition: [ju:ˈbɪkwɪtəs] ## adj. seeming to be seen everywhere       ## omnipresent, universal ##  ## Teremok, a low-key purveyor of Russian staples, is almost comically ubiquitous in Moscow.

flashcards.name: umbrage
flashcards.definition: [ˈʌmbrɪdʒ] ## n. a feeling of being offended by what someone has said or done    ##  ## The invention of social caricature domesticated grotesquerie as an easy means for jollity at others’ expense and, when admixed with politics, as a weapon of partisan umbrage.

flashcards.name: unalloyed
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnəˈlɔɪd] ## adj. not mixed with something else     ## unqualified ##  ## The mood at the Inauguration was so joyful, so filled with unalloyed expectation and—there’s that word again—hope, that it seems almost peevish to sound a sour note.

flashcards.name: unambiguous
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnæmˈbɪgjuəs] ## adj. clearly expressed or understood     ##  ## Much of the discussion—at least, in Germany, France, and Great Britain—is centered on their revelations of Heidegger’s deep- rooted and unambiguous anti-Semitism.

flashcards.name: unassailable
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnəˈseɪləbl] ## adj. not able to be doubted       ## sound ##  ## In the run-up to the Iraq war, many in the mainstream media, including the New York Times, lost their veneer of unassailable trustworthiness for many readers and viewers.

flashcards.name: unassuming
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnəˈsju:mɪŋ] ## adj. not having or showing a desire to be noticed, praised, etc.     ## modest, humble ##  ## Much has been written about the unassuming smile that never leaves that tiny head.

flashcards.name: unattainable
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnəˈteɪnəbl] ## adj. cannot be achieved or is not available             ##  ## Throughout the world, young women are compelled, through tradition or religion, to give birth to so many children that a reasonable quality of life is unattainable.

flashcards.name: unbalanced
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˈbælənst] ## (1)adj. appear disturbed and upset or they seem to be slightly crazy.         ## (2)adj. unfair or inaccurate because it emphasizes some things and ignores others      ##  ## The parliament passed a law that imposes fines as high as nearly a million dollars for coverage deemed “unbalanced or offensive to human dignity or common morals.”

flashcards.name: unblemished
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈblemɪʃt] ## adj. not being harmed or spoiled         ## pristine ##  ## These people are healthy-looking in an unpremeditated way, their skin unblemished and tanned and their muscles toned.

flashcards.name: unbounded
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈbaʊndɪd] ## adj. not limited in any way     ## immoderate, expansive ##  ## Trump is vulgarity unbounded, a knowledge-free national leader who will not only set markets tumbling but will strike fear into the hearts of the vulnerable and the weak.

flashcards.name: unceasing
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈsi:sɪŋ] ## adj. never stopping     ## unremitting ##  ## The unceasing traffic of Houston Street and the construction pylons and plastic netting along the sidewalk might distract an unwary passerby from this whimsically elegant wine bar and restaurant.

flashcards.name: unchecked
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˈtʃekt] ## adj. nobody controls it or prevents it from growing or developing        ##   91 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##  ##  ## The Petraeus case shows that among the people who have the most to lose from unchecked surveillance are the people who thought they would benefit from it.

flashcards.name: uncompromising
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈkɒmprəmaɪzɪŋ] ## adj. not willing to change a decision, opinion, method, etc.      ##  ## We naturally associate the composer of the next work, Elliott Carter, with uncompromising modernist dissonance and complexity.

flashcards.name: undeniable
flashcards.definition: [ʌndɪ'naɪəbl] ## adj. impossible to deny       ## unquestionable, irrefutable ##  ## For a great artist, he made remarkably little good art. But his influence on subsequent generations is undeniable.

flashcards.name: undercut
flashcards.definition: [ʌndə'kʌt] ## v. to make weaker or less effective    ## subvert, impair, undermine ##  ## In the opera “Appomattox,” festive orchestral touches ironically undercut grim imagery.

flashcards.name: undermine
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌndəˈmaɪn] ## v. to make weaker or less effective usually in a secret or gradual way       ## impair, subvert, undercut ##  ## Including them in trade agreements undermines the broader case for free trade, by making it look like exactly what people fear— a system designed to put corporate interests above public ones.

flashcards.name: undo
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'du] ## v. to change or stop the effect of        ##  ## Even the Islamic State seeks to undo the old borders.

flashcards.name: unencumbered
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnɪnˈkʌmbəd] ## adj. free of encumbrance      ##  ## His client confessed that the novelty of being unencumbered had him lying awake nights.

flashcards.name: unerring
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈɜ:rɪŋ] ## adj. always right and accurate       ## settled ##  ## Greer pinpoints the 'tiny hidden madnesses in ordinary people' with unerring accuracy, and, in prose littered with sparks, makes palpable the longing for the celestial.

flashcards.name: uneven
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈi:vn] ## (1)adj. not uniform       ## (2)adj. not level or smooth      ##  ## When she won this year’s U.S. Olympic Trials, it was in large part because she easily beat the rest of the field on the uneven bars.

flashcards.name: unexampled
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnɪg'zɑ:mpld] ## adj. having no example or parallel       ## novel ##  ## Mass incarceration on a scale almost unexampled in human history is a fundamental fact of our country today—perhaps the fundamental fact, as slavery was the fundamental fact of 1850.

flashcards.name: unexceptional
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnɪkˈsepʃənl] ## adj. not usually good, interesting, etc.     ## nondescript ##  ## Gessen is most illuminating when she details the historical accidents that allowed an unexceptional bureaucrat to rule Russia.

flashcards.name: unfathomable
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'fæðəməbl] ## adj. impossible to understand       ##  ## It was once difficult to conceive of people capable of such unfathomable cruelty.

flashcards.name: unfeeling
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈfi:lɪŋ] ## adj. not kind or sympathetic toward other people     ##  ## It’s almost pathological, his inability to distinguish his lovers from one another; and yet he doesn’t strike me as a bad guy, or even an unfeeling one.

flashcards.name: unflagging
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˈflægɪŋ] ## adj. not decreasing or becoming weaker       ## unfatigued ##  ## He wrote with unflagging passion on art, society, religion, rocks, clouds, economics, Egyptology, war, and women, with an instinctive grasp of all but the last.

flashcards.name: unflinching
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'flɪntʃɪŋ] ## adj. staying strong and determined even when things are difficult       ##  ## “War/Photography” is deliberately tough and unflinching when it comes to depicting injury and death.

flashcards.name: unfounded
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈfaʊndɪd] ## adj. not based on facts or proof      ## unjustified, baseless, groundless, unwarranted ##  ## President Trump was mostly up to his usual stuff, popping off on social media, peddling unfounded conspiracy theories, and generally acting in an alarming, obnoxious manner. ##    92 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: ungainly
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'ɡenli] ## adj. moving in an awkward or clumsy way          ## awkward ##  ## We’ve come to expect elegance in Olympic victories, but Shaunae Miller’s gutsy, ungainly lunge across the finish line in the women’s four hundred metres reminded us that winning isn’t always pretty.

flashcards.name: unimpeachable
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnɪmˈpi:tʃəbl] ## adj. very reliable and trusted       ## blameless ##  ## When things go wrong—when complaints are filed or there is unimpeachable cause for punishing an officer—department oversight is so lax that it makes “real accountability nearly impossible.

flashcards.name: uninformative
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnɪnˈfɔ:mətɪv] ## adj. not giving you enough useful information       ## inscrutable ##  ## But Sontag also warned that context was key—uninformative captions stir the emotions but can obscure the political and moral implications.

flashcards.name: universal
flashcards.definition: [ˌju:nɪˈvɜ:sl] ## (1)adj. done or experienced by everyone      ## (2)adj. existing or true at all times or in all places              ## omnipresent, ubiquitous ##  ## There are many versions of the idea, but the most interesting is what’s called a universal basic income: every year, every adult citizen in the U.S. would receive a stipend.

flashcards.name: unkempt
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˈkempt] ## adj. messy or untidy      ##  ## “We try to keep that balance between unkempt and orderly,” says Rob Warren, the owner, surveying his domain, a scruffy, comfortable place with an exhaustive Beat Generation section just inside the front door.

flashcards.name: unmistakable
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnmɪˈsteɪkəbl] ## adj. not capable of bing mistaken or misunderstood           ## decisive ##  ## Jones’s touch, always unmistakable, has assumed a new level of intimacy.

flashcards.name: unorthodox
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈɔ:θədɒks] ## adj. different from what is usually done or accepted      ## unconventional ##  ## Elon Musk, whose unorthodox ideas have met with a checkered record of success, has ambitious—and perhaps unattainable— plans for an automated car manufacturing.

flashcards.name: unostentatious
flashcards.definition: ['ʌnˌɒsten'teɪʃəs] ## adj. not ostentatious      ## modest ##  ## The gestures mean very little to the orchestra, which needs only a precise and unostentatious beat to help it perform, any well- trained orchestra is quite capable of making their entrances without the prodding of the conductor.

flashcards.name: unprecedented
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈpresɪdentɪd] ## adj. not done or experienced before       ## abnormal ##  ## The Administration official said that Lynch and Justice Department officials are studying the situation, which he called unprecedented.

flashcards.name: unprepossessing
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˌpri:pəˈzesɪŋ] ## adj. looking rather plain or ordinary       ## unremarkable ##  ## The restaurant’s unprepossessing room and unprepossessing locale promise mere proficiency but deliver profligate flavor and spirited service.

flashcards.name: unqualified
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnˈkwɒlɪfaɪd] ## (1)adj. complete or total            ## (2)adj. not having the skills, knowledge, or experience needed to do a particular job or activity      ## unalloyed ##  ## Kim Jong-un was a “totally unqualified person” who attained his position of power only through nepotism.

flashcards.name: unravel
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'rævl] ## v. to find the correct explanation for       ##  ## The price of S. & P. 500 futures shot upward as Donald Trump began to unravel during the first Presidential debate, on September 26th.

flashcards.name: unremitting
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnrɪˈmɪtɪŋ] ## adj. not stopping or growing weaker     ## unceasing ##  ## His pictures possess no unity of composition, only unremitting energy. Everywhere your eye goes, it finds things to engage it.

flashcards.name: unseemly
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'simli] ## adj. not proper or appropriate for the situation      ## indecorous ##  ## It’s a choose-your-own-adventure game in which you play a director on a casting couch trying to get an actress to take off her clothes and engage in other unseemly behavior.

flashcards.name: unsettle
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'setl] ## v. to make nervous, worried, or upset     ## alarm ##  ## Paglen says that his often blurry photographs of drones and classified surveillance sites are “useless as evidence.” His aim is not to expose and edify so much as to confound and unsettle. ##        93 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: unsurpassed
flashcards.definition: [ˌʌnsəˈpɑ:st] ## adj. emphasizing that it is better or greater than anything else of its kind ##  ##  ## Johan Cruyff’s ability to read the game was unsurpassed, but it wasn’t just his solo skills that set him apart.

flashcards.name: untenable
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈtenəbl] ## adj. not capable of being defended against attack or criticism        ## baseless ##  ## In order to limit the possibility of this untenable change, and restore whiteness to its former status as a marker of national identity, a number of white Americans are sacrificing themselves.

flashcards.name: untether
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'teðə] ## v. to free from or as if from a tether    ## divorce ##  ## One of ayahuasca’s main effects is to untether thoughts from their normal, linear flow.

flashcards.name: untrammeled
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'træmld] ## adj. not confined, limited, or impeded       ## unrestrained ##  ## Some of my fellow feminist journalists saw a paradoxical benefit in Trump’s untrammeled misogyny.

flashcards.name: unwarranted
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈwɒrəntɪd] ## adj. if you describe something as unwarranted, you are critical of it because there is no need or reason for it      ## groundless ##  ## Depression had prevented an unwarranted illusion of control when someone won—and had provided a sense of responsibility when someone lost.

flashcards.name: unwieldy
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈwi:ldi] ## adj. difficult to handle, control, or deal with because of being large, heavy, or complex          ## cumbersome ##  ## In her column “Ask Polly,” Heather Havrilesky attempts to address her readers’ most unwieldy questions about modern life.

flashcards.name: unwitting
flashcards.definition: [ʌn'wɪtɪŋ] ## adj. not intended or planned     ##  ## The gap in the family's existence where a father used to be is an open wound, and one effect of E.T.—his unwitting mission—is to heal it, before he heads back to the stars.

flashcards.name: unyielding
flashcards.definition: [ʌnˈji:ldɪŋ] ## adj. characterized by firmness or obduracy     ## implacable ##  ## Ted Cruz is an unyielding debater—and the far right’s most formidable advocate.

flashcards.name: upend
flashcards.definition: [ʌpˈend] ## v. to cause to be upside down    ##  ## Holmes, who is thirty, is the C.E.O. of Theranos, a Silicon Valley company that is working to upend the lucrative business of blood testing.

flashcards.name: upheaval
flashcards.definition: [ʌpˈhi:vl] ## n. a major change or period of change that causes a lot of conflict, confusion, anger, etc.    ## convulsion ##  ## Three of the nation’s largest airlines could be operating under bankruptcy protection in coming weeks, analysts say, the latest sign of the industry’s upheaval as it lurches through a historic transformation.

flashcards.name: urbane
flashcards.definition: [ɜ:ˈbeɪn] ## adj. notably polite or polished in manner     ##  ## He was now an urbane American figure who could be seen in beer advertisements and judging the Miss America pageant.

flashcards.name: urgent
flashcards.definition: [ˈɜ:dʒənt] ## adj. very important and needing immediate attention         ##  ## HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. (The Borowitz Report)—CNN launched an urgent manhunt Monday after Lester Holt, the moderator of the first Presidential debate of the 2016 general election, mysteriously vanished two minutes into the contest.

flashcards.name: utilitarian
flashcards.definition: [ˌju:tɪlɪˈteəriən] ## adj. made to be useful rather than to be decorative or comfortable      ## functional ##  ## They have proposed “a cramped definition of marriage as a utilitarian incentive devised by and put into service by the state.

flashcards.name: utopia
flashcards.definition: [ju:'təʊpɪə] ## n. an impractical scheme for social improvement         ##  ## Netflix has come to seem like a kind of content utopia, free from the petty tyranny of ratings, and, accordingly, from interference by the suits.

flashcards.name: utter
flashcards.definition: ['ʌtə] ## (1) adj. complete and total      (2) v. to say    ##  ## Buckley argues that the protesters invited repression by chanting “sheer, utter obscenities,” as well as pro-Vietcong slogans. ##    94 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: vacant
flashcards.definition: [ˈveɪkənt] ## (1)adj. being without content or occupant     ## (2)adj. devoid of thought, reflection, or expression       ##  ## The man told St. Petersburg police Thursday he was sleeping in his motorized wheelchair on the porch of a vacant Hooters when the attack happened.

flashcards.name: vacillation
flashcards.definition: [ˌvæsə'leɪʃn] ## n. inability to take a stand      ## irresolution ##  ## Over lunch about a month ago, a friend asked me if I had read any good books recently. After some vacillation, I settled into an eager endorsement of Ben Lerner’s novel “Leaving the Atocha Station.”

flashcards.name: vacuous
flashcards.definition: [ˈvækjuəs] ## adj. having or showing a lack of intelligence or serious thought     ## paucity ##  ## Her story is so vacuous as to almost require the imagination to spackle its holes.

flashcards.name: vague
flashcards.definition: [veɪg] ## adj. not clear in meaning          ## nebulous ##  ## “He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.”

flashcards.name: vainglorious
flashcards.definition: [,vein'ɡlɔ:riəs] ## adj. having or showing too much pride in your abilities or achievements ##  ##  ## It’s hard to see how America’s new leader will recoup from a performance so shallow, irreverent, and vainglorious.

flashcards.name: valediction
flashcards.definition: [ˌvælɪˈdɪkʃn] ## n. an act of bidding farewell    ##  ## Sometimes you can use a valediction that signifies something in addition to “goodbye.”

flashcards.name: valorize
flashcards.definition: ['væləraɪz] ## v. to assign value or merit to    ## exalt ##  ## The bourgeoisie uses the arts to valorize capitalism, whether books, films, drama, music.

flashcards.name: vanish
flashcards.definition: [ˈvænɪʃ] ## v. to disappear entirely without a clear explanation    ##  ## His favorite spots were Verchovyna Tavern, on Seventh Street (vanished in 2005), and the De Robertis pasticceria, where he would get pignoli cookies (2014).

flashcards.name: vaporize
flashcards.definition: ['veɪpəraɪz] ## (1)v. to change into a vapor or to cause to change into a vapor     (2)v. to cause to become dissipated    ##  ## The ultimate objective of a video game—unlike that of a book, film, or poem—is to achieve a high score, vaporize falling blocks, or save the princess.

flashcards.name: vehement
flashcards.definition: [ˈvi:əmənt] ## adj. showing strong and often angry feelings     ##  ## Like “Atlas Shrugged,” it’s a vehemently pseudo-Nietzschean film, the subject of which is not the power of desire but the power of beautiful people.

flashcards.name: venal
flashcards.definition: [ˈvi:nl] ## adj. willing to do dishonest things in return for money            ##  ## The dramatic device that links the three stories is that of a venal young person who becomes a murderer; yet—as in the director’s later films—the strongest influence on behavior seems to be architecture.

flashcards.name: venerate
flashcards.definition: [ˈvenəreɪt] ## v. to feel or show deep respect for    ## honor, respect ##  ## Beethoven transformed music—but has veneration of him stifled his successors?

flashcards.name: veracity
flashcards.definition: [vəˈræsəti] ## n. truth or accuracy    ##  ## While “Arcadia” draws its veracity from historical facts, which the author manipulates in a variety of ways, they’re as intellectually digestible as pork stuffing.

flashcards.name: verbose
flashcards.definition: [vɜ:ˈbəʊs] ## adj. using more words than are needed     ## prolix, long-winded ##  ## My guess is that disciplines that are populated by smart, well-educated people who are good readers but are nevertheless characterized by crummy, turgid, verbose, abstruse, abstract, solecism-ridden prose, are usually part of a discipline where the vector of meaning.

flashcards.name: verisimilitude
flashcards.definition: [ˌverɪsɪˈmɪlɪtju:d] ## n. the quality of seeming real    ## realism ##  ## If you come from anything like Angelou’s admired family, you will recognize the verisimilitude of her words, and how Cash fits her body into them. ##    95 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: versatile
flashcards.definition: [ˈvɜ:sətaɪl] ## (1)adj. able to do many different things        (2)adj. having many different uses      ## protean, fickle, volatile, flighty, erratic, capricious ##  ## The Redskins knew they'd have the versatile and reliable Jamison Crowder back for 2017.

flashcards.name: vestige
flashcards.definition: [ˈvestɪdʒ] ## n. the last small part that remains of something that existed before       ## relic ##  ## The vestiges of Jim Crow live with us every single day.

flashcards.name: vigilant
flashcards.definition: ['vɪdʒələnt] ## adj. carefully noticing problems or signs of danger     ## careful ##  ## Today our very survival depends on our ability to stay awake, to adjust to new ideas, to remain vigilant and to face the challenge of change.

flashcards.name: vigorous
flashcards.definition: ['vɪgərəs] ## adj. done with great force and energy       ## spirited ##  ## British authorities are promising to prosecute hate crimes committed online as vigorously as those that take place face-to-face, recognizing the growth of hate speech on social media and the potential for such crimes to affect large numbers of people.

flashcards.name: violate
flashcards.definition: [ˈvaɪəleɪt] ## (1)v. break, disregard     (2)v. interrupt, disturb    ## contravene ##  ## A ban on plastic bags came into force Monday in Kenya and those found violating the new regulation could be receive maximum fines of $38,000 or a four-year jail term.

flashcards.name: virtue
flashcards.definition: [ˈvɜ:tʃu:] ## (1)n. morally good behavior or character     (2)n. a commendable quality or courage    ##  ## Traditionally, handwriting was elevated to the realm of the virtues. Accordingly, every technology that made writing easier had to be treated with contempt.

flashcards.name: visible
flashcards.definition: [ˈvɪzəbl] ## (1)adj. capable of being discovered or perceived       (2)adj. conspicuous     ## salient ##  ## Repressed by generations of Puritanism, the era longed for bright, visible and blatant beauty presented in a public form the simple citizenry could understand.

flashcards.name: vitiate
flashcards.definition: [ˈvɪʃieɪt] ## v. to ruin or spoil    ## impair ##  ## Hannah’s little smile in the shot that follows, when she’s lodged in the back seat of a taxi behind Adam’s bike and between him and Marnie, says it all, signifies it all—and vitiates the drama, turning it into television.

flashcards.name: vitriolic
flashcards.definition: [,vɪtrɪ'ɑlɪk] ## adj. bitterly scathing       ## acerbic, opprobrium ##  ## Like the conversations found on message boards, some of the opinions were vitriolic, if not blatantly racist.

flashcards.name: vivacious
flashcards.definition: [vɪˈveɪʃəs] ## adj. happy and lively in a way that is attractive     ##  ## I could not match these facts in my mind with the vivacious woman who greeted me so warmly.

flashcards.name: volatile
flashcards.definition: [ˈvɒlətaɪl] ## adj. likely to change in a very sudden or extreme way     ## fickle, versatile, flighty, erratic, capricious ##  ## The sensible solution would be for investors to put their money into low-cost index funds and just keep it there. But that’s hard to do when the market is extremely volatile.

flashcards.name: voluble
flashcards.definition: ['vɑljəbl] ## adj. talking a lot in an energetic and rapid way     ##  ## The voluble and irrepressible playwright and director Young Jean Lee swivelled in her seat to take in the audience.

flashcards.name: voracious
flashcards.definition: [vəˈreɪʃəs] ## (1)adj. having a huge appetite      (2)adj. excessively eager       ## prodigious, insatiable ##  ## The energy sector, even with the recent drop in oil prices, has a voracious appetite for exploration and drilling.

flashcards.name: wane
flashcards.definition: [weɪn] ## (1)v. to become smaller or less        ## (2)n. a time of phase of gradual decrease     ## ebb, decline ##  ## Lindsay has been busy since early summer releasing graphs and chart that seem to indicate that the narcotics problem in the city was on the wane long before September 1st, when the Rockefeller bill went into effect. ##       96 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: wanting
flashcards.definition: [ˈwɒntɪŋ] ## adj. not having all that is needed or expected      ## flawed ##  ## That the book’s argument was wanting became clear as soon as reviews appeared: there were holes, and reviewers delighted in pointing them out.

flashcards.name: wayward
flashcards.definition: [ˈweɪwəd] ## adj. following one’s own capricious, wanton, or depraved inclinations      ## errant, unpredictable ##  ## In her career as an editor, she pruned and shaped many a writer’s wayward prose into crisp lucidity.

flashcards.name: wealth
flashcards.definition: [welθ] ## (1)n. a large amount of money and possessions     (2)n. a large amount or number    ## profusion ##  ## A wealth of related material in the show includes Manet’s masterpieces “The Dead Christ and the Angels” and “The Dead Toreador.”

flashcards.name: well-defined
flashcards.definition: ['weldi'faind] ## adj. easy to see or understand     ##  ## He said victory would be well-defined, but outlined only vague benchmarks for success.

flashcards.name: welter
flashcards.definition: [ˈweltə] ## n. a state of wild disorder      ## hodgepodge ##  ## It was thematically strong, bringing to the surface a rich and nasty welter of racism, sexism and disdain not merely for elites, but for all expertise.

flashcards.name: wherewithal
flashcards.definition: [ˈweəwɪðɔ:l] ## n. the money, skill, etc., that is needed to get or do something             ##  ## Trump also lacks any civilian staffers with the knowledge and wherewithal to put an unconventional solution onto the table.

flashcards.name: whimsical
flashcards.definition: [ˈwɪmzɪkl] ## adj. subject to erratic behavior or unpredictable change       ## capricious ##  ## She also designed the festival’s whimsical official poster, which will be available free to all festival-goers.

flashcards.name: wide-ranging
flashcards.definition: [ˈwaɪdˈreɪndʒɪŋ] ## adj. dealing with or affecting a great variety of different things     ##  ## The wide-ranging investigations have swept up many business people, politicians and bureaucrats.

flashcards.name: wield
flashcards.definition: [wi:ld] ## v. to have and use (power, influence, etc.)       ## exert ##  ## From him and nine others—some who wield corporate power, others who have observed it—here are ten of this year’s most memorable quotes about business and the economy, presented in chronological order.

flashcards.name: wistful
flashcards.definition: [ˈwɪstfl] ## adj. having or showing sad thoughts and feelings about something that you want to have or do and especially about something that made you ## happy in the past           ##  ## Wistful memories and sweet moments intermingle as she recalls what she has lost and how she has learned to heal herself.

flashcards.name: witless
flashcards.definition: [ˈwɪtləs] ## adj. very foolish or stupid     ## dense ##  ## Even if cleared of any wrongdoing, Kushner has shown himself to be witless, if not corrupt.

flashcards.name: wondrous
flashcards.definition: ['wʌndrəs] ## adj. causing wonder     ## amazing ##  ## Our tiny computers get a little tinier and a little more wonderful. Inevitable wonders eventually cease to be wondrous.

flashcards.name: woo
flashcards.definition: [wu] ## v. to seek to gain or bring about       ##  ## Jeb hopes to woo voters with ad featuring worst president in U.S. History.

flashcards.name: yield
flashcards.definition: [ji:ld] ## (1)v. to produce or provide     ## (2)v. to surrender or submit to another    ## succumb, engender, output ##  ## The nation apparently once held the view that investing in science and even math could yield accomplishments that would be a source of national pride.

flashcards.name: zealot
flashcards.definition: [ˈzelət] ## n. a person who has very strong feelings about something and who wants other people to have those feelings     ## extremist, ideologue ##  ## A violent movement is being whipped up by a new Presidential candidate, Andrew Steele Jarret, a Texas senator and religious zealot who is running on a platform to “make American great again.” ##     97 ## (OG+150+PP2+PPO)+    1100                                              The New Yorker, Nytimes, The Economist, The Washingtong Post GRE                    “    ”      ##  ##  ## GRE     ##

flashcards.name: zealous
flashcards.definition: [ˈzeləs] ## adj. feeling or showing strong and energetic support for a person, cause, etc.         ## impassioned, fervent, fiery, passionate ##  ## Africa also serves as a kind of totem, a stand-in for the vague aspirations of his early 20s and his zealous search for increasingly dangerous and sometimes illegal adventures.
